pros:
I didn't know where to start but i have been working here since before HP was separated into HP inc & HPE. I work my way up from working in the HP service center, then finance, and later sales. 

The best thing about working here probably because you grew along with the people you work with, you develop friendship over the years. I have seen people come and go. But the actual perks here it's because the office is within a huge mall, right in the center of south jakarta most happening area. The office provide flexibility in working, coming to the office didn't feel like a burden to me. 

The overall situation in the office is very casual plus the multicultural setting create an atmosphere working with people from other countries very much enjoyable and didn't let you stuck working limited only with local people. 

The pay is pretty good depends on your workload and your job level. If your manager is good you will be pampered.
cons:
There is no clear career ladder here. You work your way up on your own. No overtime pay but sometimes you are required to work overtime. The culture here is too regulating somehow even it feels your are being micro manage everytime. And they kicked you out just like that during covid breakdown. But, hey i was just about to leave anyway and it leads me to early retirement package in 2020. So long HPE, it's been a hell of ride.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Terrible Place for Sales Positions, Decent Base Pay & Benefits
pros: Most of the time it is a low stress environment. Base pay is decent for the amount of work required, usually. Benefits are good and generally ethics are considered a priority and most of the people I worked with were great.
cons:
Unbelievable compensation issues for commission and sales incentive work. Account rostering, systems used for crediting sales, etc. are all defunct. More than one occasion had pay RETROACTIVELY taken and awarded to other account teams whose only job is to sit and "claim" deals in Salesforce.

The above is exactly the problem; there are too many "old guard" leaders and workforce members that have made a career out of doing no work and claiming the work of others. Good leadership from acquisitions and internal growth are alienated and let go, in favor of underqualified legacy HPE managers. 

No one listens to these issues and people use their one counterexample as a way to wave off problems.

Confirmation bias is the thing that kills this place.
Advice to Management
Stop letting good leaders go, stop rewarding useless leaders internally that shouldn't have their current position, let alone promotions.

pros: A paycheck. Some benefits are good.
cons:
Oh so many. Where to start.

Compensation: below market
Stability: minimal, stealth workforce reductions
Politics: backstabbing and undercutting common,
Culture: islands of sanity surrounded by decaying mounds of silos
Company direction: none. This ship is rudderless.
Company growth: via M&A, which they then destroy.
Product offerings: obviated by cloud, not as good as competitors.

Summary: They really don't know what they are. They keep buying companies they don't need, gutting them and losing their value, so it is never accretive. They don't grasp how the market has changed, and believe people will still buy from them, because reasons. The politics and backstabbing drove me out, as it did with many of my colleagues.
Advice to Management
Find a buyer, quickly. Stop acquiring companies. Stop destroying what you acquire.

pros: Flexibility of working from home, very supportive immediate manager and great collaboration across teams. Salary is ok but could be more competitive
cons:
Politically influenced with emphasis on diversity and inclusion to the extreme. CEO was very quick to assume Asian hate when the spa shooting happened in Georgia without having more facts about the case. Also just announced that all employees will be required to get Covid shot to work in the office regardless of preference or medical condition. This type of decision should be made by individuals and not by the employer.
Advice to Management
Stop being so woke and politically influenced. Treat US employees with more respect despite the political climate. In the US vacation hours top out at 20 years of service. How about giving more vacation hours with each 5 year increments after 20 years. Develop talent internally to reduce reliance on consulting firms as this has been very costly and difficult for HPE employees. Need improvement of internal support to resolve technical issues for employees.

pros: The atmosphere is good if you have a proper manager which is not very common. The installations tend to be quite nice. Good input for your CV. Serious company. A bit above average salary. Good flexibility (depending on your manager).
cons:
Managers outside the US are micro managers. If you are not in the USA, there is no growth whatsoever in your career or salary: only lateral movements are possible. The profit sharing is a joke. The salaries, while not bad, are not good either. The company is in a constant state of change with no clear destination. Took pandemic as a pretext to shorten budget at the expense of the employee's tools. There is a clear sensation of subordination if you are not in the USA. When a problem arises, you are completely alone vs the company. The company talks about a magnificent internal culture that is not really applicable in the daily life of the common employee.
Advice to Management
Focus MUCH more on creating a good company to work in: the HP way is completely lost and going below zero. Lacking of economical and labor growth is extremely discouraging. Give more to the employee in every sense before asking to step up for the company. Be coherent with the policies and the culture being promoted and the actual way the common employee is managed.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
Good benefits: the core benefits are at parity with the industry, i.e. 401K(company match up to 4%) , healthcare, dental, vision, life ins., etc. 

Some extra perks include a monthly wellness Friday, which was recently expanded to 2 Fridays a month during the summer months Jun/Jul/Aug. 

Tuition reimbursement: need to know the details here however, there are some nuances but it is achievable and available.
cons:
Some of the business units lack good direction. So if you are part of a business unit that is doing well and has a great roadmap then there are many opportunities for growth and longevity. If you are unfortunate to be part of a business unit that is shrinking or is changing direction drastically then layoffs are common and swift.

Was recently laid off and the severance was not equitable vs. years of service.

review_title: Very hit or miss place to work depending on your role and who you know
pros: Benefits are amazing, fun work environment with great people, you get a lot of free stuff (food, swag, prizes, etc.), and lots of options to change roles if you don't like yours or you want to advance your career
cons:
Low pay compared to its competitors, tons of attrition & change, issues with commissions, micromanagement with useless KPI's set by upper management, raises/promotions were based on politics rather than performance, and there was a clear bias for outside (field) sales over inside sales. 

Basically- they hire inside sales reps either with little or no experience so they can underpay them with the hopes of sculping them into exactly what they want. But most reps figure this out within a year or so and go elsewhere for more pay and less bs.
Advice to Management
Fix the painfully obvious issues. Pay reps more, don't change every aspect of their job annually, promote people fairly etc etc. It's not hard to figure this out. Then maybe the avg tenure would be more than 1-2 years.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Don’t expect to grow career wise.
pros: Great people. Great culture. Great benefits. Decent pay. A little below average for our industry.
cons:
They DONT promote within. 
They DONT promote those that do amazing work. 
They’ve hired from outside the 3-4 times for a position has opened up above me that I have applied for. 
I wasn’t even interviewed.
Been told I would be promoted numerous times and when I follow-up, mgmt always responds with, “we are working on it. We should have something to present to you soon”. 
It has been going on for years. It’s actually funny now.
Advice to Management
Practice what you preach when it comes to holding on to talent and rewarding those that do great work. 

And keep up the good work everywhere else!

pros: Good benefits portfolio the company offers!
cons:
There are many cons! The compensation is below market value. HPE pays their employees less than their competitors. The pay structure is set so that middle and upper management get the bulk of the salary increases and bonuses. The culture at HPE is everyone for themselves. It is extremely hard to get promoted and pay raises with the company. The management team consists of re-treads that under performed in other roles that get "lateral" opportunities to stay in management roles. So they re-cycle low performing managers to other management positions. This creates a culture of have vs have nots. The company is filled with people that gossip and brown nose to keep their positions. Upper management prefers to have people around them that "think like them"! There is a lot of political division within the workforce that permeates through clicks and employee silos! People spend a lot of time trying to figure out who the next WFR will be. When people are WFR'd they are usually the last to know. News and rumors travel fast at HPE in Houston. Don't ever get on the bad side of management because they will purposefully make your life miserable! They will lie on you and get the other management contemporaries onboard to craft a negative narrative that will follow you throughout your career. A bunch of "good old boys and girls" playing corporate games to keep themselves in power. Please be careful working here! Get in there learn what you can and then take your experience where you will be better compensated and don't have to deal with the far right culture that is overtly prevalent in the workplace at the Houston campus!
Advice to Management
Clean house on the middle managers and bring in fresh, forward thinking managers, that respects employees privacy, and that are not tainted by the existing culture. Push for a more diverse management team that embraces all cultures, thoughts, ideas, and perspectives. Clean up the culture!!!
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Very Slow and Steady Growth and Opportunities
cons:
ltant in Bangalore
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Great Work Culture 
Good Benefits and Perks
Employee Centric when it comes to work culture. You get regular goodies and gifts. 
Good Mediclaim features
Stock options available
Work Pressure is less when we compare Vmware or Dell.
Cons
Not much to learn or explore
Same traditional work 
Legacy technologies are still on
Edge to Cloud is still not heavily used 
GMS cloud is pretty new to establish its roots with the likes of Vmware Vcloud Suite or Oracle cloud. 
No proper hike.
Salary is below industry standard.
Internal Job Posting requires good amount of Skills and experiences and under the table ways to crack in. Later being the most prominent way to get a designation upgrade !!
Advice to Management
Please recognise core talents and hardworks
Managers should be more agile to find out who's doing what. Rather than only recognising them who flatters well. Favouritism should STOP.
Pay hike and Salary should be at par industry standard
More internal movements should be done so that HPE Don't lose out on potential employees to others 

PS.: Managers depends from team to team and so is the work.

Luckily i got a very good manager but not a great team. The kind of work i do is not satisfying.
There's nothing you can learn for sure. Growth is negligible.

review_title: Being treated like slaves, lot of politics because of old employees who are incompetent
pros: They show that they have good culture but in actual they are bunch of insecure people who doesn't have good skills and are incompetent to change jobs in the current markt. So they are lying in HPE doing politics, favouritism. Since, they are highly incompetent to get jobs in the current market, they will try to show everyone the same and expect their tem members to work live slaves.
cons:
Manager expects you to work long hours. Lot of people who in HPE for a long time. They feel insecure about their jobs and hence, do a lot of politics, also they will work long long hours and force the other teammates to do the same. 
Almost no hike during appraisal. No internal job change opportunity. Even if it is there, Your current manager will kill it so you remain their slave. 
Negligible hike during appraisal. There is a huge salary between current employee and a new hire for the same job level.
Advice to Management
Why can't you give hike with a promotion. There is a huge gap in salary of current employee and new hire at same job level. Also, clean up your old employee population who are incompetent and do nothing apart from politics or working like slaves.

ant Change and Burn-out
11 May 2021 - Process and Capabilities Manager in Plano, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
If you hate your current manager, you'll probably have another one in 3-6 months.
Depending on your management team, you may be able to work remotely for awhile - in my case, about 6+ years but it might also be the reason why they lay 
you off.
You get to put a Fortune 500 company on your resume.
Relatively diverse experience on a lot of different teams / projects.
There used to be amazing and super smart people that worked at HP/HPE, unfortunately, a lot of them probably got laid-off.
Cons
Constant change / instability-Even if you were a consultant and love change, HPE will probably give you PTSD. Org changes were every 3-6 months. 
You will be worked-to-death (nearly) because of the constant layoffs, acquisitions, and spin-offs. There will not be any work-life-balance. 
Difficult to 'officially move-up' even though they may give you a lot of new titles and more responsibilities (excellent ratings/bonuses), you may never officially move past the HR title given to you. 
Pay/salary is lower than their competitors in tech. and you may never get beyond that without leaving/going back.
Neurodiversity Issues - Don't ever tell your manager you're ADHD or that being on "Skype is distracting" when you have multiple projects and a gazillion deadlines because HR will want to speak to you (despite being a high performer / HR is clueless about ADHD /autism spectrum/etc) - Say NOTHING. HR is not your friend.
"Transformation" is a code-word for downsizing / org changes. 
Unique processes that may not translate to other tech companies.
When HPE talks about 'agility' or Lean 6 Sigma, or most other key terms in the industry, their version will, most likely, not be the standard that you are used to. They make it up as they go = agility.
Advice to Management
Learn to 'walk-the-walk' of what you preach to your external customers. Instead of constant change, learn to stabilize, at least until you can figure out if something is or is not working and that isn't 3 months into the process/policy change and then abandon the initiative! You might actually become a better company if you went private again like Dell did...think about it. You were always so beholden to Wall Street that you sacrificed 30,000+ employees that were critical to your operations and customers. Some of the smaller consulting firms that were involved with 'hiring/strategy' were actually abusive to the employees that were farmed out to HPE and I really wondered where the oversight was? I really felt like senior management was out-of-touch with what was going on most of the time. Employee engagement / happiness should be a focus and not an after-thought because the research is out there, your company would probably be performing better if you actually practiced what you preached instead of burning out your best and brightest and then throwing them out like garbage. Honestly, of all the acquisitions you made, Aruba was probably the smartest. You should really take their advice on their innovation / people management / agility instead of going down the same path you have been on since the separation (again, beholden to Wall Street).
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Used to be a great company to work for until it became HPE
pros:
Used to have great industry intelligence 
Used to have Industry experts 
Used to have World recognised certifications and training 
Used to have Leaders working as one team
cons:
Unless you are part of a old boys network - you will have no hope of developing your career 
Layers and layers of management with no proved sales track record 
Talk a lot about inclusion and diversity but do not practice this themselves 
Very toxic environment 
Cannot retain staff or attract high skilled resources 
Very junior people in senior positions and have no credibility with customers and their team 
Too many employees there and waiting for a package
Many occasions where harassment had taken place and has been brushed under the carpet 
No clear direction or strategy in the company 
Each GEO working in different directions with no clear worldwide direction
Many ERG groups but funding drastically reduced
Functions such as training supply chain and IT all outsourced - layers and layers of processes for any approvals 
Slow and mundane processes not what you would expect in an IT ‘industry leading’ company
Advice to Management
Shape up of GEO leadership level required urgently

review_title: Better culture to work than most tech companies
pros:
work/life balance
people are more laid back
cons:
pay can be low unless you move around
they get rid of their best people every few years in the never ending cost cutting
Advice to Management
Trying to compete with amazon is pie in the sky kind of nonsense after you laid off of all the best engineers. While you can try, it is a race between what will tank faster, the server market or HPE's cloud play. Also, the whole diversity/inclusion push is weird; we already are and have been for many years. Trying to drink silicon valley cool-aid and virtue signal is just pathetic. And frankly your hiring guidelines are illegal and you will get sued if they are ever published. Focus on engineering and let your inclusive and diverse workforce do the rest.

review_title: The grass is greener away from here (before DXC merger)
pros: On a rare occasion there were some hidden gems in the company willing to take you under their wing.
cons:
Older SMEs reluctant to share knowledge as they don't want you to take their job.
Management were not in touch with their staff
If your a grad then the light shines out your bottom and you can do anything as you have a degree in media studies.
Promotions never unless your best friends with the manager giving them
Reported sexual assault which was swept under the carpet
Constant redundancies
Advice to Management
I don't blame HPE for who they have in charge but the people at a certain level think they are invincible. These people now work for DXC since the merger. If CEO were aware of some of the behaviours I think they would have been disappointed.
When sexual assault is reported rather than giving the guy in question a redundancy package when you say you are investigating do so. The situation was to scary to get the police involved and no investigation was done by HR.
I believe the work ethics of each account and their management are different. There was one account and it was amazing. It had a real expert dynamic, I say this to make sure anyone that does read this I did have some good times.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Just another large legacy IT equipment provider
pros: Great staff, solid products, decent customer support for now. Some of the finest folks in the industry work or worked for HPE. Co-workers and managers were always ready to help and assist. Truly enjoyed the people there. A few real good product lines, like Aruba, as well. Also the CEO articulates sound strategies, but execution fails.
cons:
Inability to execute. Legacy business models and offerings have forced the company to be a commodity provider relying on selling solid, but me-to products. This is a space much better suited for nimbler entities. Especially for a company that tries to reinvent itself annually. HPE has bewildering back office procedures, which cripple its ability to bring differentiated products and services to market in a timely or cost effective manner. Like many old behemoths the right hand simply doesn't know what the left hand is doing.
Advice to Management
Streamline business processes. I would completely eliminate all back-office functions and start from scratch! Yes, they are completely broken. Just ask any front line sales about specialised pricing or procurement, ask your customers about accessing appropriate Support resources. It's broken, dont fix it, replace it.

review_title: In overall, a good "big company" to work for.
cons:
ltant in London, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Very relaxed environment
Great people to be around and work with
Decent projects
Very flexible working schedule
Learning benefits
Very limited travel for client work (even pre covid)

It doesn't come with the office politics, the people that are willing to step over dead bodies to go up the ladder and the amount of red tape other big consultancies are notorious for, which makes it a much friendlier place to be in and much easier to aclimitise when you first join. Projects can also be very interesting and you can gain a lot of knowledge, as long as you end up in one of the interesting ones.
Cons
Lacks the skillset that other companies have in certain IT areas
Projects can be uninteresting at times
Rotation between projects can be difficult
No structured way of sharing knowledge
Recognition is there, but promos can be a bit slow
Not a very clear path of where one can go after the "manager" level
Advice to Management
Offer more structured ways of sharing the knowledge. Attempts have been made in the past but they're always going stale after a while and people just stop caring about this part of their job. Siloed knowledge and skillset end up creating cult groups.

Offer more responsibility to people who are ready to take it.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Excellent company, Great benefits, questionable top leadership
pros: Benefits are second to none. The mid-level and below leadership are very high quality and if you are willing to accept the long term risks, in the short term it's a great place to work.
cons:
The company as a whole is abandoning the strengths that have gotten them the success they have so far, to "pivot" to the "as a service" model and deemphasizing the servers and direct install software lines. In my opinion, that will be the beginning of the end for the company as a whole and it will spiral downward over the next several years.
Advice to Management
Realize that you're late to the "as a service" party and don't abandon your strengths while trying to make this pivot.

review_title: HPE is a "fine" company - not horrible, not great
pros: Able to work autonomously which is nice. All depends on your manager
cons:
Lots of disarray in my group. No tools, need sales teams to follow up. Vacation time is not up to par. You get 3 weeks, but HPE makes you take 1 week at Christmas. So essentially you have 2 weeks of vacation that you can use when "YOU" want to take vacation.
Advice to Management
Fix vacation time off. It's far below industry standard. Most companies do shut down between Xmas and New Years, but don't make people take PTO.

pros: I work from home and make my own hours with no pressure at all. I've been working in Longmont office for Todd now for several years. On average, I put in two days a week and goof off the rest of the time and nobody notices. It took a while to get used to, but I now I spend a lot of time surfing the web, watching TV and playing video games to chew up the day. I make $130k+10% bonus, you can't beat the money for the minimal amount of work required. Especially now, who wants to go look for a job in this pandemic?
cons:
It takes a while to get used to the boredom. Thank God for video games, TV and surfing the web.
Advice to Management
Don't change a thing at my office and let us continue to work from home with no supervision! :)

review_title: Good for Blore ,Chennai and Mumbai location not in gurgaon
pros:
1. Ok culture , desi lala company with few WW teams with MNC culture
2. Ok benefits
3.good focus but too slow to evolve
cons:
Lala favouritism culture in India from HR teams to leaders assistants to Sales teams highly encouraged from top to bottom in structure .

1. Too many 40-60 yr olds associated with this company for over 20 years hence the problem is political powerhouses created with no space for MNC culture and I am the boss do as i say attitude with less risk takers , or enthusiasm to contribute .Tech teams lack knowledge and the managers are more than required in number and also highly insecure than in any other MNC hence focussed on themselves completely and busy appreciating themselves in each recognition platform showcasing their own good work and lack leadership broader vision , team spirit and good team practises 

2. HR culture only on paper , HR teams are the ones growing by being inline to top managers say 100%

3. Diversity on paper , good for entry of women n girls from colleges with whom they have tieups or yes 15 yr old in company or some current employees relative 

4.People are insecure to share knowledge , work together and take risks .. too many old timer managers afraid of change or something new or acknowledging others work .. its like a PSU sir culture totally 

5. Only managers no leaders here hence do not expect anything work for money no growth And leave on finding something better ...
Advice to Management
Please broaden the mindset especially develop leadership as manager culture is much like a PSU. People work and leave but in any PSU managers keep sitting in organization and growing for decades at a place eroding the very basic concept of let others also grow and progress . I am the boss so I cannot help , 2.he is my favourite so he does not need to work , 3.the other is someone elses relative hence do not expect from him , 4. the 5th is 15 yr old here with deep knowledge hence take guidance do not expdct contribution ... out of 6-7 in a team hardly 1-2 working and making others grow for obvious reasons .

This culture wont take any organization farther and is dated impractical and less productive and demotivating for obvious reasons

review_title: Solid company that is redesigning itself
pros: The people and the dedication. Lots of very good people and solid mix of experience of background and experience. CEO is more contemporary in his approach than a number of the prior CEO's before him. He came up thru the company starting in a Call Center so he has a very deep and broad level of company knowledge which is very good for the company. Solid products thru internal development and thru acquisition. If the company executes on the AAS shift from solely HW and services, the future is very bright....They will need to seize the window of opportunity that is available.
cons:
Solid people are let go during reorgs just for being in the wrong place at the wrong time. There is little, if any, effort to retain talent that can still help the company. Decision making and execution is slow which is not unique for a company of this size.

review_title: Some great people and some horrible leaders
pros:
Had a wonderful experience working on some of the industry-leading products in Enterprise Storage.

Great people in Bangalore
cons:
Working with the Nimble team was a shocker which eventually prompted me to resign. 

The lack of information, no transparency, bossing-around, and passive-aggressive behavior of some of the leadership (San Jose) team in Nimble are just difficult to deal with.
Advice to Management
The HR refuses to take feedback. 

which was shocking. but, other than that, the people I came across in the HPE Bangalore office are friendly and great to work with. 

I hope you would implement a streamlined Employee Exit process that doesn't result in having to deal with your HR folks. They are not a friendly bunch.

review_title: Great company but needs to change more with the times
pros:
- Great CEO
- Good perks in line with other companies like paid holidays, 401k match, Wellness Friday, etc
- Overall company focus on work life balance, unless you are on stressful programs
-
cons:
- Product focused company
- Company culture is like a 100+ year company, which leads to slow speed of execution
- needs to work on empowering women at executive levels and driving more inclusion and diversity
Advice to Management
While the CEO drives the vision, it needs to trickle down to the people who drive change.

 It is essential to ensure that people driving change are recognized for how difficult that is in the current company culture Vs being dinged on growth opportunities due to internal people centricity metrics as they focused on larger org priorities - otherwise you will have people fearful of making Bold moves.
Be the first to find this review helpful

cons:

review_title: HPE does not value the HP Way
pros: Some great individual contributors, who only want the best for the company and fellow employees. Many seasoned people are great in sharing their knowledge, while a lot of early career hires are eager to learn and make a difference. Executives have worked hard to align the company values with the old "HP Way" which Bill & Dave, (Hewlett & Packard), began the company with, being the employees are the most valuable asset.
cons:
Middle Management and former Compaq values have destroyed the company. After the HP/Compaq merger, much of the Compaq management were put in charge of manufacturing & supply-chain decisions which put HP back 20 years in the streamlined processes, and ethical dealing, (i.e. supply-chain management accepted items which could be construed as 'gifts' which influenced decisions). When HP employees expressed better ways of doing things, they were threated with the jobs and told by the Compaq management, "We've Always Done Things, This Way". HP's open door policy was pushed aside, as the Compaq management talked out of both side of their mouths, saying they want to hear new ideas, and got angry when people did not follow, "The Chain of Command". Managers, not individual contributors, are rewarded significantly with bonuses when meeting 'metrics' that are mostly made up numbers, while individual contributors are told they must make those metrics or fear loosing their jobs. Little to no opportunity for advancement, as recruiters are compensated for hiring from outside the company, or if an employee does everything, (ethical or not), to make their management look good to get bonuses.
Advice to Management
Not sure if there is a chance to turn things around, even though a lot of middle management has been removed, but think it is a mistake moving the headquarters to Houston, where the values are not the same as Palo Alto had. Take away the bonus structure for management, and bring back the profit sharing program for all employees that is not tied to each business unit.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: HPE provides fantastic benefits and, for the most part, really cares about the employees. 6 month paternity/maternity leave for everyone. Stock purchase program, etc.
cons:
The roles are constantly being redefined and changed with no feedback from those in the roles. 
For example, my current role has lost 3 support roles that we are now responsible for and none of this came with any sort of pay raise or compensation. 

It also feels as though there is no opportunity for career growth at this point. Part of what made the culture so huge and successful was working onsite, due to strategy and COVID we are all remote and it is truly showing all the holes in the company now.
Advice to Management
Before making changes, have frank and open discussions with those in the role. Don't expect people to be happy when you add lots of responsibility without compensation and without asking for feedback.

review_title: Lack of direction and loyalty to employees
pros: work life balance, culture, colleagues
cons:
constant layoffs, minimal raises, no direction, lack of career growth .
Advice to Management
quit laying off the long term employees that know how things work. This creates a knowledge vacuum that can not be replaced. also, decide what you want to be and stick with it. quit changing directions every 2-3 years. all the top talent has left or is leaving or being ran out of the company. I enjoyed my time at HPE, over 10 years but the political games, constant change and low pay definitely wear you out. Its a great place to start your career but don't think they will let you retire there. get your experience and move on to your next job where you can make a career. What's left of Senior Mgmt needs to gracefully move on and let others lead this once great company.

review_title: Jack of ALL TRADES Master of all
pros:
-Relatively decent salary at the start, considering the average salaries in Romania.
-Was lucky and came in a team where the colleagues are really nice people and I love them
-Opportunity to learn new things and further develop your career at least for me
cons:
-Manager is not aware of how many biases they have, but keeps talking about them like they're the perfect human being.
-Favoritism and nepotism are in season here, outweighing actual skill, knowledge, ability to comprehend, communication skills and so on. The bigger the lamb you are the more your favored for positions like TL/project lead/manager.
-Salary increase non existent, if you ask "there are no funds". Yearly increase debatable, 3% to max 2 people in the team IF they "exceed expectations". I exceeded all expectations in my yearly review and got 3%.
-You're promoted, but you don't get a salary increase. unless it's TL or Manager promotion. Being promoted to a new and completely different role, does not mean you discard your previous roles. So Outlook signatures look like lists of employees in a team, even though they're all roles for 1 single person.
-Job Description for which you are hired is tripled after the first month and not even on paper. They just keep giving you tasks until you reach a point where you work 15hrs a day and start getting heart spikes and fatigue. They pretend to care, but then they ask about deadlines and tasks pending :)) so hypocrisy at it's best.

Who here LOVES this sentence "HAPPY MONDAY EVERYONE" :))) followed by a trillion tasks you need to do "yesterday".

-HORRIBLE WORK STATIONS, like let's be frank, a decade old G3 HP laptop(which is definitely NOT a workstation), in a job position where you work with PHOTOSHOP and ADOBE SUITE in general, with CODE, with HUGE Excel files of tens of thousands of rows filled with data (try performing VLOOKUP's or pivot tables on that, good luck), which was handed to you day 1 with a burned out battery, which reboots randomly when you're in the middle of important past deadline work, which apparently goes into sleep mode or lock screen whenever it feels tired, which besides being a 14" screen, doesn't even have a functioning HDMI slot, come to think of it IT DOESN'T HAVE ONE AT ALL, it only has VGA which is broken. You got to admit, HP laptops have a mind and personality of their own!
-Last millennia's tools, outdated programs which barely function and make your work even harder. (combined with the very performing G3, woo you got the perfect combo right there).
-With the covid situation, we were told that we can request extra screens and desk chairs to have a more comfortable WFH experience. I put in my request 3 months ago. Guess what, still using MY OWN. Manager did not care until I asked and when I asked they blamed me for not putting in the request, when THEY were supposed to put them in, let us know when they get approved and THEN we would log in a ticket to either go pick them up, or to pay 100 lei to have them delivered directly to our house. 

There's a lot more to say, but I guess this is enough to get the gist of what HPE really means.
Advice to Management
change them.

review_title: Great at the local team level, but too big for a family atmosphere.
pros:
- Lots of provided training
- Incentivized rewards/bonuses
- Top Tier HW vendor globally, significant name brand power
cons:
- long since lost the "one big happy family" feel that Dave and Bill wanted for their company. You're a line item on a spreadsheet, and if some nameless, faceless bean counter looks at your line and doesn't see value, you will be cut loose.
- continuous growth/downsizing cycles. Layoff 10000 bodies one quarter, hire 5000 a couple quarters later, like most of the large HW vendors.
- they talk about work/life balance, but to overperform like they want, you are working 60-80 hours a week.
Advice to Management
Make an effort to foster the "one big HPE family" mentality again. Make employees feel appreciated and valued. Plan for sales trends better to stop the slaughter/hire cycle.

review_title: Improving culture but still Lots of other areas to work on.
pros:
Culture is improving significantly with a strong focus on employee welfare. 

CEO leadership is strong and developing, with strong experience and roots across the company.

Benefits (not salary) are on par with peer organisations.

A fair degree of autonomy is afforded (with most managers) and trust can be earned quickly.
cons:
Some leaders are stuck in formulaic approach with little innovative thinking.

Salary increments are very low compared to the industry (despite what HR say).

Cliques and favorites are prevalent with managers, leading to a lot of hiring in their own image, limiting diverse thinking.

Global functions have often been ineffective with respect to the country-level organisations. This leads to Global functions perceiving themselves to be above country orgs in the hierarchy, acting with a bias to transmit versus discuss, and a lack of accountability to the front line staff.

review_title: Not a good company to work for!
pros: Flexible working (from home or from the office).
cons:
Very unpleasant leadership. It is a terrible organisation with constant turnmoil and WFRs. People are scared to speak up because of retaliation from leaders. Very low employee engagement scores in my organisation. No career development opportunities. No learning and development. Only poor quality online training.
Advice to Management
Get rid of all senior HR execs. Start with Chief Talent Officer. She is the worst HR person I have ever seen in my career. People are the greatest asset of an organisation but not according to HPE's Chief talent officer. I have never heard a senior HR leader to speak so disrespectfully of employees. She sees people as 'cost', as a 'burden' that we need to get rid of rather than an 'asset'. She fired the best leaders in the organisation, so she doesn't look so incompetent. It is such a shame! This is a classic example of a poor leader who destroys an organisation. Leadership matters more than anything else.

review_title: Exactly what you would expect in the current economy
pros: The benefits offered are good. These include life insurance, group legal, and discount programs. They offer excellent starting PTO (15 days plus a bunch of holidays). They recently deployed a terrific parental leave program that affords new parents (mothers and fathers) 6 months of paid leave. Prior to the suspension of the 401k, the match was decent. They are a mature organization when it comes to operating in a remote work setting.
cons:
Tools/programs for completing work are half-baked and frequently run out of funding. Constant name changes for different business units based on the director of the week. WFR culture is the modus operandi. Good luck getting promoted or raises. Salary for individual contributors is well below market rate.
Advice to Management
Stop failing your workforce. There are way too many bumps on the log that have no real skills outside of HPE, so they panic when they hear WFR. Stop making decisions based solely on employee costs. Instead, consider how you can retool the current workforce. The 10-15% pay reduction turned out to be completely unnecessary given the massive WFR in November and December. Stop partaking in political movements that are garbage and subjecting employees to "sensitivity training".

review_title: Not a bad place to work
pros: The people I worked with on a day-to-day basis were generally exceptional. Benefits were
cons:
No consistency in corporate vision or culture. Things that should be fundamental and immutable parts of our core were thrown out and replaced with shocking regularity. No one bothered trying to remember the "core values" because they kept changing so often. 
The quality of the people in senior leadership positions varied greatly. Some of the VPs were excellent, inspirational leaders but they were the exception rather than the rule. For some reason, the culture at HPE tends to put clueless, empire building ass-kissers into key senior leadership positions. Failures of leadership are clearly to blame for most of HP's big problems over the years. 
I despised the system of forced ratings distributions for performance evaluations. No more than 10% of the people in a team can receive the top rating and at least 7% MUST get the worst rating, regardless of the circumstances, no exceptions. As a manager, this gave me an incentive to tolerate, even encourage, poor performance in some people just so I could have justification for giving the poor performance ratings at the end of the year. Its a stupid, counter-productive and demoralizing policy.
Advice to Management
Make some real commitments and show some loyalty to your remaining US workforce. The majority of the folks left in the US feel that the writing is on the wall and its only a matter of time before what's left of R&D is moved to India, where it will die a slow death.

review_title: Overall fair/good company but not the best in class.
pros: Great benefits options. Executive management is transparent. Remote working options. Promote work life balance. Many outside vendor discounts available to employees. Past five years more fair pay increases and annual bonus.
cons:
Individual contributor pay is far below industry. Continual cost cutting for company provided older PCs models, significant medical insurance increases every year. Recent U.S. layoffs were not organized at all. They used a sword instead of surgical knife. Some remaining U.S. individuals may not know where they land long term for up to 2 or 3 months. It was "shocking" news to all groups that were affected.
Advice to Management
Find a way to reduce or eliminate continual cost cutting. Never let cost cutting get in the way of quality. Find your way back to keep quality employees and products. Profits will follow quality.

review_title: Fairly nice place to work at
pros: It pays well; my starting salary $70,000 and I ended with $72,000 after 2 years. The atmosphere is pretty relaxed; there is a gym and a ping pong table. The work is interesting with interesting projects. My coworkers and manager were friendly, helpful, and accommodating.
cons:
Some of my coworkers complained that new hires leave too quickly, and yet I was let go as part of workforce reduction at the end of the project; most of my coworkers in the Chippewa Falls, WI office were over 40 years old and worked there for several years. Of the three recent college graduates in the team, 2 of them were let go (including me), so take away whatever you want from that. Much of the software tools that I used were proprietary and unique to the team, so I found out that much of the work experience is relatively useless when finding a new software engineering job

Recommend

Pros

This may not the be the situation of whole company but my project experience was really disappointing.
Advice to Management
Please keep your employees first and treat them nicely.

review_title: Leave your brain at the door, toxicity abounds in the CDC.
pros: Decent pay and subsidized food in the restaurant.
cons:
A self proclaimed "world class" cyber defence center. You know they're not world class when they have to actually say that and when they're the only one's saying it. A group made up of people from penneys, bars, hotels, IT repair shops etc. A lot of which have no prior experience and trained by people from similar backgrounds with almost none of the staff having experience beyond a few years in the job.
Hardly what anyone else would qualify as world class security professionals.

In the job bullying is encouraged from the leads, by lower management and expected to be accepted. Expressing a dissenting opinion or even disagreeing with an opinion of someone more senior is the quickest way to be ostracized in a clique based environment where compliance is mandatory. Complaining is also a sure way to know that you won't be kept on beyond the 11 months contracts as noted with other interns who are gone now. The illusory job at the end seems to be something lower management wants to dangle over your head so they can have you do all kinds random other things beyond your working hours or duties. Insincerity is rife, with a number of fake brown nosers about and ultimately the status quo of toxicity has to be maintained at all costs, so yeah don't complain, you're privileged to be here in this hellhole.

Leave your brain at the door as you won't be able to do the slightest and most rudimentary tasks without getting permission each and every time regardless of how basic it is and how repetitive some of the alerts are. Your opinion does not count. In any way. Only those with marginally greater experience does, or a lead. Follow what they say no matter what, EVEN, if they contradict each other. Only what the lead on shift says is valid.

You may have been great in other jobs and valued a lot. In here, comply always and forever in everything, don't think. The most controlling place i've worked in despite some aspects of the work being incredibly basic.

You hire people to become analysts and then train them become monkeys and forgo their own thinking. I shudder to think what might happen when a crisis hits and these people who have been trained to just obey have to use their independent thought. Sounds like a crisis waiting to happen.
Advice to Management
If you do manage to hire smart people, help them to develop as analysts including their own autonomy, and thinking, instead of killing their drive with the above mentioned. Show trust to them over time and stop stifling them by not even letting them do menial repetitive tasks or some of the basic alerts that a 12 year old could do without permission. You're stifling their autonomy, enjoyment of the work, development as security analysts and feeling of actual ownership for what they're working on.

Stop allowing leads and maybe even lower management to treat the interns like they are nothing and remove some of the cut throat leads who do this. There are leads at HPE that can teach and can be really good at that and can develop the people in there. Encourage that kind of behaviour and start treating people with respect. You will lose more people to this, especially if they have experience in better environments or value being treated any way decent.

Working for HPE in the CDC ain't as marvellous as you guys want to have the interns believe. The only reason you're getting away with it is because the interns don't know any better. For most of them this is the only corporate job they've had and that's abused to the max here.

review_title: A great brand with the best people and the worst systems and tools
pros: Smart, competent employees who truly care about doing what is right for the customer and to help each other. Employees support each other; Relatively flat hierarchy; clear priorities. Great technology portfolio and continuous acquisitions.
cons:
Many manual systems and processes; do not use SFDC effectively so many excel spreadsheets needed to manage workloads; silos of information; no support to gain experience in other areas, despite requests.
Advice to Management
Management tends to speak in "corporate speak" and it is not authentic. In every employee meeting, every Executive talks about how they are "so excited" about whatever they are announcing, even if it bombs later. Antonio Neri is outstanding but the next levels on down are weak. They are currently restructuring, and employees have waited months to find out their new role. They use a Voice of the Workforce survey, then do nothing to address the gaps and concerns. They talk about being the kind of company that everyone wants to work for, but do nothing to invest in systems and processes to minimize the administrative burden on employees. I bet it gets better as the market demands efficiency and effectiveness.

pros: Surrounded by many competent engineers
cons:
Poor benefits. -- expensive and high out-of-pocket expenses.
Really horrible at acquisition integration.
Very communicative about irrelevant successfulness of "the business".
For years they told us how valuable our division was until it was suddenly shut down. Basically, our product was commoditized. Would you like SimpliVity fries with that enterprise order?
Had many touchy feely meetings at the beginning of the COVID-10 crisis telling us how important family was and that we were part of the "HPE family. Right up until they laid off well over 100 employees right in the middle of the pandemic. The layoff was not pandemic related. The reason was purely pure greed. I am sure executives made great bonuses for the quarter. HPE announced a new acquisition the very same day the SimpliVity division was closed.
Advice to Management
Enough of the disingenuous rhetoric. You could have been truthful and given your "HPE family" members time to look for a job while they still able to provide for their real families during the pandemic. You know, like our spouses and children who need food, shelter and, yes, medical coverage during the pandemic.

review_title: Decent Money but no Annual Increases / Admin & Process Heavy / Beware the Layoffs
cons:
ltant in London, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- You can join on a decent package
- They try to ensure Sales & PreSales earn close to OTE with SPIF's on occasion
- Largely left to get on with things how you see fit in the field
- Some decent Managers
Cons
- No annual Salary or package increases, not even cost of living / RPI related, so your income effectively erodes over time
- Increasingly plaguing PreSales with SFDC related admin that's unnecessary - activity time logging and suchlike
- Process & red tape to do simple things like get competitive pricing out to customers is plain silly
- Layoffs are a frighteningly regular occurence with 'Workforce Reduction' type initiatives every year I've been here with a large scale WFR programme underway currently leaving it hard to feel any sense of job security
- Removed car allowance from many staff out of the blue saying that they hadn't done enough mileage to qualify when up until then everyone that had it included when they joined thought it would alway be guaranteed income like their basic. Those staff effectively lost thousands from their annual packages
Advice to Management
Stop with the frequent layoffs and don't nickle & dime employees with things like the car allowance removal and not even inflationary salary increases to cover cost of living increases. Remove the unnecessary admin & process burden from your field sellers to give them more time to spend on revenue generating activities.

2020 has clearly been a difficult year but navigating onwards needs a steady hand and nerve, NOT knee-jerk reaction in terms of WFR. A move to increasingly early career Inside Sales people largely lacking in experience is not the way to beat the seasoned competition. Working with the channel is very necessary but channel resellers increasingly rely on us to do the heavy lifting for them - getting rid of that in-house skills and experience will not bode well and those same channel partners will look elsewhere to Vendors that can do the heavy lifting and pay them decent margin.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Nice colleagues and work life balance.
cons:
Benefits could be improved. Pay was below market value. After going through a couple splits with the company, employees were not treated well and it was a pretty demoralizing place to work. No perks, benefits were cut, budgets were so tight. The kitchen didn't have any utensils or plates... something as basic as that shows how company focuses on squeezing pennies at the expense of employees' well being to meet the bottom-line. Great people ended up leaving the company one by one. The work was pretty dry with no real innovation. Very bureaucratic. I didn't get to exercise my creative thinking and take lead on my work, so when I left the company to join a place where that was encouraged, it was a culture shock to me.
Advice to Management
Value your employees.

pros: Work life balance flexibility, dress code flexibility
cons:
Compensation below market average
Not ethnically diverse, very minimum Black/African Americans in management roles or promoted within.
Promotions and talent replacement are not based on skills, but who you know not what you know and it is reflected in team morale.
Strategies are not always clear, therefore, goals do not align.
Does not understand the dynamics of retaining employees with knowledge and history, does not properly train/prepare workforce for unforeseen transitions and changes.
Management, needs more training as well as more cross-cultural training and preparations.
Advice to Management
Stop allowing managers to bring in talent and promote based on relationships and not skills. Be true to the inside workforce and diversify, train and promote workers.
Treat your employees better than your partners and all else will fall into to place. A happy employee will do more for your company than an unhappy customer. A happy employee you will not have unhappy customers.
Verify educational credentials, not everyone who has a degree listed truly holds a degree and for those who have HONESTYLY worked hard and earned a degree deserve the actual credit.

review_title: If you value yourself there are plenty other better companies out there.
pros: They have good benefits like health insurance, wellness programs and paid maternity leave (but beware, you might get laid off upon return or even while pregnant, I know of one employee that got fired at 7 months of pregnant just for workforce reductions impact.
cons:
HP- HPE has been on a transformation journey for decades, and with that thousands of layoffs have been the constant. During almost 11 years I never felt any type of job security. I absorbed at one point 3 people’s jobs as they let them go and I started because I was ridiculously underpaid. 
There is no control over the amount of work or effort that it takes to do a certain role, so some people might be doing nothing while others are being overworked.

There’s no real career path, although they sell you that the sky is the limit, I was never longer than 2-3 years on a role before a new reorganization or transformation would hit and another arbitrary role would be assigned. 
Applying for jobs to try to move or escalate internally is all a lie. 
Roles are pretty much given by who you know, you will get interviews, because obviously there’s an HR process to follow, but they will ask you whatever just to make the “quota” and tell you that they selected someone else, and that you lacked skills that they did not even bother to ask if you had.
They keep bringing people from Dell, Cisco and other competitors hoping that they will provide competitive insight, and these people will start laying off people to bring in their new buddies and cycle starts.
Being a USA employee is really hard, as their location strategy is to send all to low cost countries. So most jobs in US tend to be moved to Mexico, India or Low Cost countries in Europe.
They also love to let go people with long careers in the Company, I am taking with about 20+ years, by forcing them on early retirement, regardless if they are ready or not. I know a bunch of people that went through it and are now trying to look for a job in their late 50’s early 60’s. A pretty bad way to thank loyal employees who invested their whole lives in the Company. 
They did change their benefits being really altruistic by offering 26 weeks of parental leave. All of this happened while I was already pregnant, so I was pretty exited about that! 
I came from maternity just to realize they had hired a replacement in a low cost country , and they laid me off a month an a half after returning from maternity leave.
I would not recommend this company to work for if you value yourself, and or if you are looking for career growth and stability.
Advice to Management
Value the employees that are about to retire instead of getting rid of them.
Workforce reductions will help you with your balance sheet but is it a sustainable strategy? You have let go so many talent that is being taken by the competition and then wonder why you keep struggling to meet you goals.

review_title: Behind the times and struggling to cope
pros:
Very nice pleasant people. Seriously everyone works and acts with kindness. 
Great work life balance and accommodating personal needs.
cons:
Monumentally behind the times and totally in capable of acting efficiently. 
Nothing gets done without an 8-12 month road map and months of documentation. This could in theory be great and lead to better organization but in reality it means there's constant delays and a lack of competition with more modern nimble competitors. 
There's also an enormous and costly reliance on DXC for any technical task and an extreme lack of even slightly technical people outside of IT/engineering. 
The work life balance is nice in some ways but there are very many employees working at half capacity because they can or because no one is encouraged to automate or be productive. Lots of very manual work done very slowly. 
Data is a complete disaster despite using best of breed solutions and reps struggle to find info as basic as order data or even install base. 
Adding to all this management made it a month into the pandemic before cutting pay across the board and laying off many employees. All the while making more large acquisitions of barely competitive companies. If it took weeks to lead to a covid melt down at an enterprise company where everyone worked remote anyway it can't bode well for the future.
Advice to Management
Build internal talent and cut DXC loose. 
Remove unproductive employees and foster an environment of productivity vs manual work arounds.
Develop more nimble processes.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Work-life balance, nice people and respectful culture
pros:
1. Work life balanced
2. I like 99% of the people that I've worked with here
3. Very diverse demographic and inclusive culture. Here I have the chance to work with cross-continental teams 
4. The company is big and internal transferred is encouraged after 2 years for the first role. There are tons of opportunities to pursue within the organization
cons:
1. Non-stop re-org
2. Employees on average have been with the company for 10+ years so newbies have fewer opportunities to be empowered or get promoted.
3. Salary not as competitive as other silicon valley tech company 
4. Not very fast-paced and sometimes lack of efficiency
Advice to Management
Re-org needs to be implemented fast, precise, and not so frequent. Employees lose confidence when the company keeps doing WFR/re-org for a long period of time especially when a team has no leader for a long time or when an employee has got 10 different managers over 2 years.

review_title: Generally a good place to work
pros: The people are great, the pay is good, and the benefits are solid. Up to 6 months of paid parental leave are available.
cons:
Layoffs happen about every two years; Covid-19 is what caused my position to be "eliminated." Their severance package was generous, though (11 weeks). They even let me keep my work computer (middle-of-the-road laptop).
Advice to Management
Since inclusion has been a focal point at HPE as of late, be conscious about how unspoken expectations for employees to do extra projects on top of normal duties puts people with families at a disadvantage. It's very difficult for those of us that have children with special needs to put in extra time to compete with our colleagues who are single and/or childless.

"catered friday lunches" are comprised of three options that are cycled through until you want to actually go pay for your own expensive garden bar salad. They are 6 hour own burritos, even older Pizza, and even older sandwhiches. The work you do is all what I like to call redo work. anything that a program catches and managers can pull and look at themselves, they make the employees manually keep track of and then report to them.. This takes hours and hours to do during the week.
Advice to Management
This is to upper management since middle management will take your criticism or idea and put them right where there management style comes from, in the trash.

review_title: Good work life balance, constant reorgs
pros: Work life balance is great. The company is slower paced which can be good and bad, depending on your preferences. Easy job as long as you do as your told. Good benefits, flexible WFH options
cons:
Constant threat of layoffs due to reorgs. Management finds it convenient to cut labor expense than own up to strategy failures in other ways. Organization is very hierarchical with some micromanaging at each level. Age discrimination can be a thing depending where you are.
Advice to Management
Instead of improving bottom line by cutting jobs, have more accountability at the top so major strategic decisions don't just affect ICs. Enable more autonomy amongst the employees - it will driver more accountability and better results.

- Medical premiums are high.

Adopt to the latest and greatest tools and technologies at work place.

ltant
22 June 2020 - Senior Storage Consultant in Alpharetta, GA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Overall pretty good pay and benefits. Upper Management do try to promote a positive culture but it can get a little cheesy at times.
Cons
Mostly have to self-train, and some PDFs/videos are not enough for technically complex products. Getting approval to cross-train to improve skills is very difficult. I was not officially trained on most of the products I was expected to support at a 3rd level. 
They have an historical pattern of outsourcing/laying off, losing clients/contracts because of poor service, then hiring again, outsource, lay off. Rinse, repeat.
Advice to Management
REAL training, like classes/labs, not just CBTs. Stop outsourcing. It never ends well.

pros: Great company culture, good pay, and nice benefits with many options for health insurance. Two weeks of paid vacation annually. Company-sponsored travel to conferences. Company card for business expenses.
cons:
The onboarding process is a bit disjointed at times. Training materials are lacking for some essential aspects of the job and you're expected to just know who's who in a large worldwide organization that has tens of thousands of employees scattered across a myriad of departments in hundreds of locations worldwide. Also, there is an expectation that you will participate in many extracurricular company activities even if you have a family and small children at home. Each manager has at least a few esoteric, unspoken expectations that you have to meet to get good reviews.
Advice to Management
Make expectations clear. Don't act as though something is optional when it really is not. Be more inclusive of people who may not be able to participate in certain "optional" activities due to child care responsibilities. Provide a list of essential contacts to each new employee and provide a concise explanation of what the new employee's relationship with each contact is expected to be.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Decent culture but lacking in many places
pros: The teams I’ve worked on have all been full of helpful and smart individuals for the most part. There’s always someone willing to help or point you in the right direction. A wide portfolio of partnerships and solutions is nice and helps the cause.
cons:
There feels like little room for growth even though it is talked about often. In 5+ years of being with the company I have only truly been permitted to grow vertically once and it took a significant amount of effort to force upper managements hand. Layoffs tend to be somewhat common and the benefits I’ve received are nothing special. If anything I feel that many employees are undervalued for the work they put in and responsibilities put on them.
Advice to Management
Provide more reason to retain your teams and the ability to learn solutions, not only products.

review_title: Graduate scheme scrapped half way through
pros: Great graduate scheme when happening, dragons den competition, training in roles and ITIL training to all graduates. Loved working here.
cons:
Graduate scheme ended half way through - I had moved across the country (4 hour drive) to be part of a graduate scheme to ensure I gained the right training and the graduate scheme was scrapped half way through.

I was used to replace someone else's job they were making redundant. Placed in a hostile environment due to knowledge transfer. I was left managing the work of a team which used to be 50 people by myself with no manager.

It was a rotational scheme every 6 months, I was refused the move to another team for 2 years due to not having anyone to take over from my role.

Only offered a pay rise due to handing in my notice.
Advice to Management
Follow through on what is promised as part of the scheme.

review_title: Decent W/L Balance, cheap on benefits
pros: It's a big company with resources if you need it. My part of the company was purchased recently (former HPC company), and that group has been exceptional to work with.
cons:
It's a big company with a massive emphasis on only one thing: shareholder value. This is good from an investors point of view, but bad when it comes to investing in anything that will add true value down the road. 

Every chance they get, they attempt to decrease costs in a way the is not transparent. Health benefits seemed acceptable, until I started using them. The (high) deductible is split into 4 groups, in-network/out of network and medical vs pharmacy, and all that costs me (for myself and my husband) around $500/mo. All other benefits tanked after the acquisition as well, and my old company wasn't a big, they just treated people right. 

Work/life balance is reasonable, but most people that have been there long enough seem to just be getting through it. Not much excitement for innovating or doing anything new. It seems like a great place to be a salesman, not a great place to be an engineer, as all the innovation they make is purchased from other companies. 

There's also a massive hierarchy and tons of red tape for almost everything. My manager has been great at keeping it from being my issue, but I can see the toll it's taken on him and others in management.
Advice to Management
Be more transparent with people and invest in new technologies. Try to break down the silos between different groups that de-incentivizes collaboration. There's a chance for this company to do great things, but massive changes are needed from the top level down.

review_title: Inside Sales Account Manager - complete disappointment
pros:
Great team members.
Just recently implemented one work from home day a week (must be in office every Monday and Friday). 
Wellness Friday - able to leave at 2pm every second Friday of the month. 
Point system to acknowledge good work allowing for online store purchases.
cons:
There is a colossal issue with compensation - the team complains time and time again about inconsistencies with little to no resolution. 
There is no explanation on how you are compensated on each deal. 
There is not a lot of career advancement opportunities for HPE Canada. 
The office culture is very archaic and you need to be in a cubicle 4 days a week from ~9-5. 
You spend one fiscal year in a territory building relationships with customers and then are moved to another the following year to start over. 
There is no formal onboarding training for HPE Canada - you must ask busy coworkers how to do each task every day until you are savvy. 
There are weekly pressures to forecast deals in which you have little control with closing. 
This is not really a sales job - more so administrative.
Advice to Management
There are no real managers by definition for the inside sales team. 
The role of the current managers are to simply relay information from their direct ordinates to their subordinates. 
There needs to be coaching, training and career development conversations in order to fulfill a true management role. 
Keep fighting for workplace culture improvements, compensation consistency and job flexibility.

review_title: Okay for Short-Term but Prepare for Turmoil
pros:
Good work life balance
Supports working from home but depends on manager
cons:
I would not recommend this company because the pay and benefits are lower than average and definitely not competitive, the company does not invest in tools for their engineering groups and the type of work you mostly end up doing is cleaning up other people's messes.

* Company is behind on the technology curve with their products, trying to catch up with distributed system design with microservices
* The recent company change laid off almost all their senior engineers and increased the amount of lower paid, less experienced, offshore engineers from 30% to 60%. Now this new group is expected to transform their monolith products to a microservice architecture???
* Engineering groups are asked to develop leading products with poor tools and limited budgets. This is a company that supports business people, not engineers.
* Engineers spend most of their time fixing someone else's defects and rarely get to work on something new.
* Below average pay for what you are asked to do. Benefits (especially insurance) are more expensive and not competitive.
* The company makes it difficult to move positions within the company for career growth.
Advice to Management
* Invest in good tools for your engineers or what you get is "garbage in, garbage out".
* Offer competitive pay and benefits are truly reflective of the market versus lowest common denominator 
* Build a culture of software quality (more CI/CD) so engineers are not frustrated with cleaning up other people's messy code with lots of defects.

pros: In its heyday, up until around 2006, HP was THE place to work. "The HP Way" was that management's job was to tell their people what the objective was, then "let them loose" to accomplish it. And it worked, exceedingly well. Management was there to provide support and enable their people. "Micro-management" didn't exist at HP. People felt proud to contribute, to "break rules" if needed, and innovation was a "given." Bill & Dave treated everyone as a friend or family. This type of managment was unheard of back when HP was just beginning, and at the time other CEOs literally laughed at their business model. They stopped laughing very quickly, but found it difficult to become "Another HP;" It takes very unique skills that the founders were blessed with.
cons:
However, eventually Bill & Dave passed on and we brought in a CEO who outright disliked everything HP was. (One example: HP had "profit sharing" and we had a good year and the rewards were quite good. The new CEO was angry at "having" to spend those monies on people and rushed to make profit sharing a thing of the past.) And we purchased, in an attempt to "be bigger" a company that also didn't fit the HP Way model. From there, the company changed almost overnight. And the change took away what was truly a unique company and replaced it with becoming just another cold, even heartless one. I left HP as a result, as did most of my coworkers. The HP I left had promised me my job back, and I followed up only to find they had a "policy change," and once you left you were not welcomed back. Instead they hired new people, people who know nothing about the old HP, and assumed all companies were the same, job security was always a concern, rewards are rare, and you felt "disposable." My heart breaks to see such a miracle disappear.

And my title here, "It's not HP anymore" was something a friend who stayed. When she heard I was thinking of coming back she said I shouldn't, and she too wished she had left but was getting closer to retiring. But like most of us "Old timers," seeing what happened to HP is, in a word, painful.
Advice to Management
Watch (At least) one documentary, I suggest "HP Origins." It does a very good job about how HP started, about Bill & Dave, and primarily, what "The HP Way" truly is. It's well-worth the 1/2 hour. Good luck to all.

review_title: Only there 2 mths and not impressed.
pros: Good pay. OK benefits (minus health because of the surcharge fee they have for adding dependants) Wellness Fridays seemed cool and good idea.
cons:
Our small but mighty tech company was recently acquired by HPe. My position was eliminated in the process. My end date rolled into the first months of them acquiring us, which was odd and didn't seem necessary. We had to enroll in benefits, payroll, IT systems, only to lose them a month later when we ended. Although they provided some career transitional support, it wasnt at all at the level it should have been. Any questions we had around the process we were pushed into a generic "ask HR" email address that would get a response 3 weeks later, or not at all. Their never seemed to be anyone who knew answers or could provide help. We were constantly told to "go to links" for info. No personable feel at all. It was a terribly disconnected process and the communication was always broken. The right hand never seemed to be talking to the left. You were made to very much feel like just a number during the process and I could feel the growing curve from a small personable company to a cold tech giant company in which no one seemed to care what you did before the acquisition, or know how to help with anything. The culture started to drastically shift, which was sad. The IT onboarding process on our first day was terrible and I have never been treated so rude by IT people. After leaving, I was told my completion bonus would go in on a certain date, and it didnt. I spent hours back and forth with HR trying to get answers as to why that changed and was not communicated to me. On top of that, noone from HPE confirmed with the state the information I submitted for unemployment benefits, so I was left waiting for a response, and finally the state took it in their own hands to confirm the info with me so I could get my eligibility. I was very unimpressed that such a large company like HPe would not have a handle on taking care of the people affected by an acquisition layoff. Once again...they made you feel irrelevant and like a number. I expected more from a company of this size. It has nothing to do with getting laid off. It happens, its the corporate world we live in,but its about ethics, taking care of the people, and making the offboarding experience as easy as possible for those leaving. Didnt happen. It was a circus over there from the second they acquired us, and it was starting to ruin the great culture our company had into place before HPe came in and swallowed us up. I hope they can improve this experience for future situations like this, because I have such a bad taste in my mouth from HPe, I dont think I would ever work there or recommend them to other peers. Whats sad too, is they bought us because they couldn't beat us. I just hope they can carry the legacy and incredible work we did. There is a reason we were number one in our industry. Time will tell if they will carry our flag or sink our ship..
Advice to Management
Better handle on acquisitions and the people affected by them. More personable. Better communication. Better IT customer service.

pros: Solid Products, okay benefits, friendly people
cons:
HPE throws away their entire Q1 by making huge adjustments during the end of the calendar year, they pay their people under market for the roles they hire for, there's a level of "playing the game" internally that hinders the true top performers from progressing, the upper management hides behind the smoke and mirrors of executive privilege while they overwork and underpay all positions, there are fundamental alignment issues in sales teams, understanding what sales reps get paid on is more complex than rocket science, supply chain issues compound the already impossible quota attainment issues, and people threatening to leave are being rewarded with raises and roles in order to stay while more tenured folks on the floor are being paid less than those being hired fresh out of college.

This is all in conjunction with every role internally being converted, essentially turning the entire building into a call center.
Advice to Management
Learn to not divide your people in every way imaginable. The people you undercut will eventually leave for competitors and apply salt to the self-inflicted wound HPE has successfully acquired. This company has the potential to do great work, but it is the management internally that are hindering the success with a poor professional brand, abysmal decision-making, and an absolutely deplorable excuse for a start-up culture. Take a weekend and re-write the entire system, starting on page one.
