review_title: HPE - Aruba very good place to test your limits.
pros:
I was with HPE for close to 5years, Joining as a Junior Dev Engineer and I was a Senior Software Dev engineer when I left.
I was part of HPE-Aruba networking BU so I will keep my review relevant to this BU alone.
Excellent place if you really like the development activity as part of your job.
This BU is always growing, innovating and looking to compete with the best in the industry, hence there is always lot of feature development opportunities for engineers.
There is a real scope of understanding standard as well as new technologies as there is so much work involved.
Pros as per me :
1) Excellent development work and great platform to learn and improve your knowledge with respect to Networking protocols
2) Very good and experienced seniors who have a overall knowledge in their respective fields
3) You can test yourself as you will be involved from the design phase to delivery for customer stage. You will understand the whole process very well.
4) Help is always available if you ask for it.
5) Decent Hikes year on year.
6) Management and leaders have a good vision of what they want in next 3-4 years.
cons:
Though the company offers great oppurtunity to build career, it does have cons as I have seen. Here are the cons with the BU I worked :
1) No Work-Life balance.
2) There is a lot of obscure activity expected from the developers. Which could have been easily performed by other teams. This takes too much time other than the actual work being assigned and the worst part is it is these obscure activities are not even considered as work even if it takes a lot of time.
Hence the pressure is high on developers.
3) The process involved in getting a feature to completion is so tedious. It sometimes feels like developers are running the company.
4) Management is very much involved in micro-managing.
5) Other than working on technologies and becoming knowledgeable in the technology part, there is no career plan for employees.
It is like management just want you to work a lot but they have no plans to help build your career. 
6) Though it has decent hikes, the bonuses they offer on yearly basis is literally peanuts. Worst in the industry.
7) No Flexibility, no WFH options.
Advice to Management
1) Stop micro-management, trust your engineers to deliver the feature.
2) Improve compensation benefits.
3) Treat developers as humans, Please come up with a program to offload lot of the obscure activity which the developer is not equipped with to other teams. This helps the developers improve their efficiency.
4) Appreciate your engineers regularly, they work so hard. They deserve it.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Pays Well, No coaching, myopic thinking for go to market strategies
pros: Pays well. Large company for exposure to other brands and opportunities.
cons:
Thoughts on how to improve are not welcomed. Any idea which isn't coming from the top down isn't worth mentioning. No mentor program to get up to speed. No coaching from management - you have to chase the manager down for attention unless there is negative attention coming to you.
Advice to Management
Pay attention to the staff, listen to them, understand the reason they reach out to you and try empathy. Not everyone works the same way, and there will always be personality conflicts in life. Work to better understand your people and what motivates them to push the needle vs. the need to push the needle and not understanding why is isn't.

review_title: Inside Sales Account Manager" - not sales more like a call center rep
pros: Health benefits, Friendly culture ,Location
cons:
Too many to mention .....

-Upper management are clueless on what actually goes on 
-Management turning a sales org into a call center
-Managers micro manage on a daily basis 
-New tool every day that makes hard to keep up with all 
-This is territory based sales so you better be lucky other wise you are not making money 
-Field is over paid and inside is overworked and under paid 
-Account alignment was a joke in FY19 with unrealistic quotas and bad accounts that don t fall under correct segments
-Re org with out notice an people placement is unorganized 
-Reps who are praised either got lucky with accounts or they play the "game" your efforts does not matter at HPE 
-For a big company like HPE they sure have an HR department that is lost and out of touch with employees 
-do not expect to move up unless you suck up to management
Advice to Management
Do not over promise and hype up employees unless you can back it up. 
Pay your employees industry standards especially inside sales. 

Make sure that job descriptions align because as an employee I made the move to HPE not be doing a lower level job

review_title: Company culture is fantastic (and still improving) but the work itself is not
pros:
It is rare to truly see a company-wide difference when it comes to a new CEO but since Antonio took over we have really seen a difference in company culture.
There have been new benefits added like additional vacation, upgraded paternity/maternity leave, new events on site and ability to work from home. Just from a culture standpoint, this is the best company I've ever worked for and it is really appreciated that they are working to make it better.
cons:
Tools, data and processes. Working in an installed base sales environment you need quick tools with data you know is accurate - we have neither. Our tools are so cumbersome and slow that to make a small/simple change to quotes it will take multiple days to complete. If I were to rate the company on how easy it is to do my job without internal roadblocks, I'd give it a 1 star. Supposedly they are working to fix some of these tools but from what I have seen, it is just a re-skin of the same tools we have.
Also, and maybe it is just my area, but it does not seem like there is a lot of room for growth internally. There is no natural promotion in my business unit.
Advice to Management
Find different ways to provide data. Don't provide the same data re-skinned. Find new ways to organize. We should be able to find information about what we sold a customer easily. Stop providing roadblocks for sales/account management. 

I understand that IB/Renewals aren't "sexy" but we keep the lights on.

pros:
Competetive salary
Flexible working
Initiatives from up-the-chain try to motivate staff and make them feel valued.
cons:
Initiatives from above completely overridden by poor local management.
Poor team management.
Too many excellent engineers left doing menial tasks.
Very little delegated responsibility & accountability.
No feeling of buy-in to the product.
Technical "leaders" are not leaders
Advice to Management
Management training
Mangers need to understand people and their motivations. A "free lunch" is not an incentive when the work's completely unfulfilling.

Listen (and ensure technical "leaders" listen) to the, often valuable, advice from experienced developers.

- Absolutely no vision, no understanding of the market, no products (only slides), no investment in new products;
- Product documentation is 10 years old or more ("nothing changed")
- Bullying management and least skillful management I ever had
- Customers are being constantly lied and projects are delivered with years of delay
- There is NO HPE Cloud, NO IoT, nothing, regardless of the nice slides prepared by Marketing
- Unrealistic sales targets (10-15x vs. average of previous 3 years)
- Unrealistic expectations ("we want to be #1 or #2 in all markets") - with no products and no investment in new technologies
- Internal divisions fight against each other and do not support common business

I have only one thing to say - stay away. You learn nothing, you get no value for your career. Unless you hold a Director or higher position - you are NO ONE. You're better off elsewhere.
Advice to Management
Stop lying customers. Stop bullying people. Start investing in products - you need to spend some to get some. Start firing morons. Shred off 3 management levels - there are more people doing nothing than people actually working. Get to work. Get a life.

review_title: Technical Account Manager and Critical Event Manager
pros:
Totally flexible. Understanding leadership and management.

Unlike the competitors, The business strategy is quite open to include Hybrid cloud where public and private cloud can be almost any leading solutions. From traditional infrastructure to Devops, they have solutions to support almost every workloads - traditional and cloud ready. And the devices do top in TPC losing just a couple of benchmarks to Korean hardware.

They have strong focus on Data Science and everyday i see at least a full-house of resources working to build AI/ML solutions from the most expensive location on earth. This didnt happened by sitting on laurels but by careful acquisition of Aruba, Nimble, Cray, Qattrolab, Plexi , Simplivity BlueData etc
They started spending extensively on employees and started grabbing the top 10% talents which will surely be reflected in the brilliance and quality of upcoming solutions and products.
This company definitely holds a considerable share in all the future technology. 
So if you are doubting over a long term investment in-terms of your career, stocks or buying technology - do not hesitate. HPE will not let you down and that is in the DNA of the company.
The
cons:
There is a slight bunch of senior managers who haven't got enough of the vision. Sometimes they happen to be in the most critical delivery pipeline and we lose all the hope of being at our best version. Rarely but definitely we still have to spend 3+ weeks to convince some managers that automation is beneficial. They are definitely the best managers, but they havent trusted and bought the vision sold by the experts above them. 
If you happen to be in such a team, please raise the voice through VOE. The management and HR do listen and take VOE seriously. This feedback loop is definitely working and kudos to HR for implementing it - its in progress but not perfect.
Advice to Management
Firstly ----Keep it up, thank you for making me proud to be an HPEian. 

Well, a lot of us know that these guys are doing above and beyond the mark to make HPE the best place on earth when it comes to Customer satisfaction and Innovation. 
I got the opportunity to listen to them casually and understand their strong belief system which is the driving force behind all these dramatic changes.

Im not delusional enough to think that i stand a chance to advice this brilliant management. But just an amber light warning that there are a few vents which may drain all the energy and efforts of you guys instead of reaching it to customers. I'm sure in this road towards total perfection, you guys will identify them and close it out.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: It's a job, not a career.
pros: Decent benefits coverage, remote work with some flexibility, and in my experience your "work family" really does feel like a second family.
cons:
Low pay, zero promotion potential even for top performers, super reactive decisions by leadership that don't give any chance for a direction to work or take shape or see if it's going to work before another reactive decision turns it in another direction entirely, layoffs at the drop of a hat and for no reason that makes any sense to anyone affected, time off seems good until you realize they require you to use a week of it for the December mandated shut down, you're just a number and they have zero loyalty to loyal employees. They mask having a "great culture" with certain improvements that are long overdue, touting this awesome place to work and yet don't follow through with other things that matter even more, like leveling salaries and whatnot (they talk about doing this but it never happens). Get ready to be underpaid and laid off, because it's not a matter of if, it's a matter of when.
Advice to Management
Bill and Dave are rolling in their graves seeing how their once-awesome-at-taking-care-of-employees company has turned out. Do better.

pros:
Health benefits
Friendly culture
Young sales floor
cons:
Upper management has too many initiatives that they roll down to ISAMs. 

Directors make unrealistic promises to upper management which leads to management micromanaging sales reps to the nth degree which stops all productivity.
 
Field reps put in zero effort and are paid two and three times as much as inside reps even though they do not contribute to closed business. It’s demoralizing. 

The pay is below industry standard and is inconsistent across the floor.

Territory planning for FY19 was a mess and many reps are stuck with a quota that is too high for the number of accounts they have.
 
Your success is based on which manager you work for.
Advice to Management
Be more selective with the initiatives you want sales reps to focus on. They can do two jobs poorly or one job excellently. 

Do not promise upper management 150% for the segment when the segment was carelessly rearranged. 

Stop glorifying field reps who do not contribute to closing business. 

Quit micromanaging. You hired these reps. Trust them to do their jobs. 

Pay reps the industry standard. 

Take better care when mapping accounts and territories for FY20.

WAY TOO MUCH EMAIL - Internal email from all over the organization and some how you are expected to read it all and action anything that is asked of you.
Advice to Management
Define Job Roles. Define each job and who is the direct manager or director. 
Allow more women in! HP is a bit of an old boys club.

review_title: Too many clients and not enough time.
pros:
Support and assistance from other techs.
Most clients are friendly and helpful in resolving their issues.
No supervisors on site looking over your shoulder. 
Long as you can resolve all scheduled work you set your own routes and schedules.
Most managers don't micromanage. 
Company car and fuel card with unlimited personal mileage.
cons:
Some clients are rude, loud and overall aholes.
While general training is given (one to two weeks in Boise) most of the experience you acquire will be working on (newer) equipment you have never worked on before. If you don't have the confidence to tear down a machine you've never seen before you might reconsider this job.
Few but some managers do micromanage and don't allow the techs to schedule their own routes or schedules, regardless of the tech's proven abilities.
Low pay considering the amount of required work.
Charged $60 to $85 per check for your company car.
Advice to Management
Give employees that have proven their skills and quality of work the freedom to work their own schedules (this doesn't apply to most managers).
Increase the pay. Working as hard as is required deserves more pay than the current rates.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: HPE is a good company to start out a career in sales. The job function consists of 25% sales 75% support/management. Easy job to enter the technology industry. The people here are great, always willing to help, fun to work with etc. Lower management is young and easy to get along with. Tons of upward mobility because of industry standard turnover. working with channel partners creates an expansive professional network. work life balance is great. Very easy to play corporate politics.
cons:
This is a very boring job. Internal processes are always changing so its hard to keep up. Change is constant. It seems as if the role changes every 6 months. middle/upper management does not fundamentally understand the role of an inside sales rep. HPE strategy is unclear and not defined. HPE places heavy emphasis on its enterprise run-rate business. We are getting killed in the small/middle market space by competition due to lack of resources and poor go to market strategy. Pay is garbage and confusing. HPE cannot figure out employee compensation and its concerning.
Advice to Management
Understand volume vs value compute and decide where you want to play in the market. The storage team internal structure is misaligned with its corresponding segments. Aruba is carrying the weight of struggling business units. gotta "give to get" management does not really care about this company and fails to motivate employees.

review_title: Continuous changes in the organisational structure
pros:
If you are a senior then you will fit right at home with colleagues in your own age.
Furthermore, there are opportunities to grow within the company if you are interested in marketing or sales roles.
cons:
The employee age range is on the very high end and most likely, only sales and marketing career opportunities will be available in the local country offices. 
From having been a solid long term employer one could pursue a career within, HPE has developed a global hub type of mindset with global hubs in Tunisia, Bulgaria, USA and India. In other words, all other type of roles than local sales and marketing should be considered short term and very likely to be subjects of the workforce reductions that have been ongoing at HP(E) for the last decade.
Advice to Management
Value your accrued employee knowledge and understand that NPS scores will be severely impacted by past employee experiences

review_title: Good employees stuck in the same position for years
pros:
Remuneration
Perks (concierge, gym on site, discounts from partners, etc.)
Work/Life Balance
cons:
Even if you are clearly the best performer, they may give promotions to people with more years at HP, so it is hard for newcomers to grow.
Language is a barrier for a lot of people. HP is famous for its acronyms. The same acronym may mean different things in different departments. HP has a whole wiki for all their acronyms.
WFRs (Work Force Reduction) - Periodically, HP mandate managers to lay off their bottom performers. In a strong or small team, a bottom performer may be significantly better than other employees in other teams. Even if the manager doesn't want to lay off the employees, this is usually non-negotiable. The company keeps losing precisous talent.
Advice to Management
Stop with the WFRs.
Formalize a rotational program (improves culture and processes).

review_title: One of the Worst Cultures I've Encountered
pros:
Casual dress code
Good location from a cost of living standpoint
cons:
Disengaged workforce
No regard for lower level employee satisfaction
No mentorship or career development
No regard for merit
Treat employees like machines, not individuals
Advice to Management
There is no formal career development process; I've seen senior analysts take 4+ years to be promoted one level whereas higher level executives are promoted once a year or so. Higher level executives get to go on all-expenses paid retreats with guests whereas lower-level employees are paid under the market and take years to be promoted. There is no regard to merit or prior accomplishments in this sense - you rotate after 24 months and you can only be promoted after 4 years - but this is not a guarantee. Frustrating work mostly surrounds correcting other (higher level) employees' work and having to pull together analysis with system crashes or crap data due to OS infrastructure from the 1990s. Also, we're a tech company but have no dedicated IT arm - that's all been outsourced to India. Also, my work is duplicated by Deloitte which for some reason is always in the building. It just seems like they have a couple hundred people at the top, thousands of apathetic/incompetent employees, and management keeps making retarded decisions. I for one am OUT.
4 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Great opportunity spoiled by poor management and selfish employees
pros:
Competitive pay, Easy but fulfilling work, Day-Evening-Overnight shifts available, Great location, Free Parking garages,
 Various online training/courses available freely, A few great Supervisors, Open Door policy, Free food for overtime days, 
Free coffee, Full time hours.
cons:
Often hostile work environment due to angry supervisors, All shifts were constantly pitted against each other for product output
 and caused resentment and complete division amongst shifts instead of a healthy team environment, Lots of lay offs,
 Floor workers were not respected by Office employees, Does not often hire internally and most supervisors know nothing about 
the manufacturing process and often derailed production due to their own misinformation or unwillingness to listen to more
 seasoned employees, Too many pointless meetings, Majority of contract and direct labourers did not care enough to work a minimal 
amount of work and constantly put down the company instead of trying to change the situation and give constructive criticism
 to management but unfortunately management probably wouldn't listen anyway, Employees would break tools, steal, and damage
 products or HP property just because, Blatant favouritism by management, Threats and warnings to fire employees, 
Unfair treatment by supervisors due to untrue rumours or assumptions, Training was basically non existent.
Advice to Management
Supervisors need to focus more on everyone being a team instead of setting up competition with threats of being fired or moving
 areas because of lesser numbers than other lines or shifts. Supervisors need to be more fair and considerate to all employees
 and keep emotions in check and especially stand up for the employees underneath them instead of throwing them under the bus to 
save themselves. Management needs to learn more about products, processes, and areas they're over so they can be better informed 
when making changes and communicating with their employees. Management needs to understand that proper training is crucial to
 solid work output and is a far better than giving minimal training. Focus less on how pretty the buildings look and more on
 functionality and practicality.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Okay Stepping Stone, Not a Long Term Home
pros:
- looks great on a resume currently
- young workforce, easy to make friends
- not much traffic in the morning
cons:
- low morale
- detached leadership
- continuous failed promises about pay and progression
- unreliable middle management
- gossipy floor
- this tech giant is stuck in the 80s
- lack of accountability for scandals
Advice to Management
1. Invest in better management. Just because someone is top of the leaderboards doesn't mean they are going to be the best leaders. Managers stop progression and promotions of talented sales reps because they simply "don't like them." Hold them to a higher standard.
2. Focus on inclusion. All of my former coworkers who could be deemed unique or different were never fully accepted. When team members brought up the idea of recruiting more minorities and women, the idea was laughed at and brushed off in meetings with leaders. There is literally no plan to include all kinds of people in this company - very rare for a tech company. If you're a person of color or a woman, please think before you work here.
3. Race Issues. There were many incidents that were never addressed and it made the workplace highly uncomfortable. For instance, multiple white employees would use the n word and say problematic things as "jokes" in front of managers. Nothing was done. When the n word was written on the walls in the men's bathroom, the news went around the floor but leadership never addressed it. This was a weak and cowardice move.
4. Pay your people!!! You can't expect someone to work for a tech giant like HPE and get paid like they're at a start-up. If someone is being promoted, you have to compensate them fairly, not ignore their pleas. Also, pay people for all of their closed opportunities. It's not my job to calculate my commission check yet I was continuously doing the math and having to be "rightfully paid" for checks months late. This is why nobody stays here longer than a year or so here. You just get sick of the mistreatment and lack of progression.
5. Leaders not wanted. They only want submissive leaders here. If you have ideas or are looking to make a difference, they will get rid of you or put you a performance plan or threaten you with a bad territory/leads. Most leaders leave for this reason quickly.
7 people found this review helpful
Helpful
Share
Repor

pros:
- Free sodas and snacks
- Decent Medical/Dental
cons:
- Empty promises.
- Poor training.
- Managers with no Management experience.
- Lack of inter-departmental communications, every department is living on some island.
- Telling employees they are doing great and giving them some useless certificate of recognition but then telling them they are below average and not giving them a raise.
- No differential pay for people who work during non business hour shifts.
- Garbage ticketing system that belongs in the 1970's.
- Multiple VPN's that don't work when you try to work from home.
- Lack of direction.
- VP telling employees they are "expandable". 
- Some other VP quitting a day before visiting the office (big surprise)
- No pay for un-used PTO, no carry over for un-used PTO and not allowing the employees to use the PTO they earned. (So what's the point of having PTO?)
Advice to Management
- Realize the job market is different now, they are a lot more jobs and people will leave if they are not treated right.

Other advice? Not that I can see. HPE failed at this acquisition. Made employees feel as if they should be thankful they have a job, fired the wrong people, prompted incompetent people..............sorry, don't see a way to fix this. This will fail sooner or later.

review_title: Easy place to get a job if you're desperate
pros: Great company name on a resume
cons:
Low pay, rarely get raises (talk about progression, but you have to interview for a raise), sales floor is like a giant frat house (so many cliques), HR doesn’t take complaints/cases seriously, inside sales team is stretched too thin
Advice to Management
1) Figure out comp. Continuously screwing people out of their money is one of the main reasons you can’t keep sales people for longer than a year.

2) Hire managers/directors and promote MORE CAREFULLY. Lots of bullying. The SMB team is by far the worst of the inside sales organization. SMB leaders take pride in tearing their employees down. They’re full of empty promises and lies. If you ask the same question a few days apart, you could get different answers. They are incredibly manipulative. If you speak up about concerns or struggles of any sort, they will flip it back on you and make you feel less of a person or guilty. All they want are “yes” men. There are many managers that have no business being managers.

3) Take HR cases more seriously. If a woman comes forward about sexual harassment, DO NOT make her feel like it was her fault. Address the situation and don’t sweep it under the rug.
15 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: The people. Your colleagues in Erskine will be among the best you'll find in a workplace. Great, great people.
cons:
Really poor basic salary for a graduate program
Constant changes that have a direct effect on income
Offices are terrible, poorly maintained and constant downsizing in terms of facilities
Sales performance is dependent on account alignment which is entirely luck
Career opportunities are all down south
Advice to Management
Invest in the offices - a dark, dingy working environment is downright depressing. Particularly when so much time is spent there.

Try to maintain continuity with regard to account alignments as this has a direct effect on your employees - bonus is paid on that basis, which is appalling.

Higher management are so disengaged with their staff and constant forecasting and processes hamper any/all selling activities. 

Invest in your staff, promote them, encourage them and try not to manage them out the door - too many good people are overlooked based on how nice they are to higher management.

review_title: HP - An Organization that can be Amazing to Work at...but for Pathetic HR
cons:
ltant in Bangalore
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Overall a good organization to work for, with good working environment - but only as good as one's Manager/ Org Head
Cons
Pathetic, Inefficient & ineffective HR, Internal Moves just don't materialize
Advice to Management
Management should look into following issues:

1. HR is Pathetic, Inefficient & ineffective - actually it will be even better to say that the HR just does not exist here. Show is run by Managers & Their Managers...and HR just toes in their line..whether in terms on Appraisal, Bonus Payouts, IJPs or Retention.

No Team Activities or Outbound activities. Never saw a HR personnel for many years..not even during Appraisal Activity months of the year.

2. Internal Career Opportunities - whether Domestic or Foreign postings (IJPs), are just not provided & promoted (which again can be promoted by a Pro-active & Efficient HR). 

3. Bonus Distribution (Sales/Deal Win Bonus, Variable Component, etc), Increments & Promotions are all a big secret and no one ever gets to know as to who got promoted...!!!

Providing Internal Opportunities is a mere lip service (even though there are tonnes of IJPs listed, I never got a call..neither did hundreds of HP GlobalSoft India employees whom I knew).

If these issues are addressed, HP can be one of the best places to work.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Great heritage and proud history of innovation. After all the changes in recent years still a lot of extraordinary people around.
cons:
Way too much politics and meaningless internal marketing without real substance. Not everybody is up to a task but the existing human potential is much more valuable than the company itself. Strange case where a total is considerably less than a sum of its parts.
Turning back to roots (not really a good idea!) HPE is going back to predominantly being a hardware vendor with software and consulting services being totally neglected (although they will tell you a different story, but do not believe them; actions in the last 3-4 years clearly speak for themselves). It looks like they did not learn anything at all from the IBM story.
Apparent financial success does not reflect the reality because it's largely based on massive layoffs and closing down operations in many countries. This will once more buy some time but the reserves are very thin now.
Once a true giant and leader in the IT industry, this company has been disassembled and is now on its lowest level ever. Good people are leaving the company and with current ideas and leadership it can only go downwards.
Advice to Management
Go away, you have done enough damage already.

pros: Great benefits, resume booster, meet a lot of people which makes it great for networking.
cons:
Tools and processes are a nightmare. Lots of office drama both among the ISRs and senior management. No consistency in the workforce. 2 VPs and Directors have been fired within inside sales in the past 2 years. Very high turnover rate among ISRs as well. Poor company culture, poor work life balance. New hires are getting paid more than tenured reps.
Advice to Management
It seems as though the company might be headed in the right direction, but you cannot change a company's culture over night. Another re-org is not going to solve all the issues within inside sales. Focus on paying your employees a comparable wage to competitors and then maybe the turnover rate will lower.

Change is inevitable in an organisation, but the rate of change at HPE has become very distracting. review_title: Can be great but going through a lot of change
pros:
In my management role I had great flexibility, could work from home partially, start and finish time, as long as the work was done there was no micro management. 
Good benefits, health insurance, pension, death in service benefit, and the option to get flex benefits for Dental insurance, buy additional holiday days etc. 
Lot of opportunities to work in different areas, great company to get experience. 
Fun international group of people.
cons:
With all the company changes, lots of projects on hold or delayed. Cost saving became the priority, so Christmas parties, and the little extras all stopped.
Call Centre roles being restructured into key locations and lots of redundancies as a result.
Advice to Management
Make decisions faster, dragging things out really impacts morale. 
Don't waste money on fancy facilities areas, spend it on the people.

review_title: Direction of company is akin to that of an uncalibrated compass but slowly coming back on track
pros:
The vast majority of your colleagues will be smart, humble and down-to-earth
The back office team are friendly and ultimately do everything they can to ensure your success
Starting to reduce redundancies
Everyone treats each other with a huge amount of respect - a lot like a family - which if you solve the below-mentioned housekeeping errors - will flourish further
cons:
Lack of direction still remains prominent in some areas of the business, post-split
Acquisitions are not logically driven, burn time and a huge amount of cash. Acquire for strategic growth, not to impress shareholders
Small decline in market cap ($)
Average tenure declining - becoming a stepping stone rather than a company that invests in internal growth and longevity of those with the knowledge, IP and skills of the HPE solutions.
Internal integration between various BUs is lacking heavily - individual agendas - again, a very easy fix, but heavily weighted towards a mindset to cross-fertilise strategies among the various Senior Leadership Team members.
Advice to Management
Overall, I am seeing some key elements that show there is a great route to market / success - if done correctly and with consistency in mind. Great work to HPE and looking forward to more success in the future

review_title: Good Project practices gone out of the window
pros: Chance to work directly with customers on their sites. Work/life balance good but this is more to do with the limited support hours contracted to some customers rather than the workloads, which would merit a lot of overtime.
cons:
Stunning disorganization and lack of co-ordination by project management between different teams working on the same systems. New problems coming out of the woodwork almost daily, one thing after another, until the wheels started to come off. Critical technical staff leaving constantly; some months later the entire project was lost to a competitor.
Advice to Management
Plan, test, re-plan, test and test again before going Live with anything. Skipping test phases seems to be a cultural thing at HP when time is short, and system faults are then not picked up until changes go Live.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
Some interesting projects and potential for moving to different parts of the company (if willing to relocate).
Degree programmes available for those that wish to pursue.
cons:
Company is very different to the one I initially joined. Most of the jobs are being located back to States or in the core countries. If you are in a non-core county then there is really limited prospects for promotion or lateral moves.
Continual WFR programmes to reduce the workforce. You'll either be made redundant or have to pick up the pieces when your team members have to leave. Expect to take on more work but without gaining much more renumeration.
Most of the HP way has been abandoned to leave just another unremarkable American Corporation.
Advice to Management
Try and invest for the long term, rather than making short term gains to please shareholders.

pros: Great work life balance and working environment
cons:
Unfortunately it's who you know and not what you know working at HP. Even through the many changes including layoffs management stays consistently oblivious to historic mistakes and repeats them at the cost of the company and even more so at the cost of the employees in the way of pay and benefits.
Advice to Management
Look at the talent right in front of you and stop looking for answers by blinding feeling out new interns that are literally along for a short ride and not the long term haul. You're losing employees that know multiple job positions because of the social club mentality going on here. When you have something that works, don't try to fix it by replacing it with something else that costs millions and usually isn't any better.

pros: My colleagues are the greatest advantage, many of them are still my friends. Also, some departments allow work from home a few days a week. In general, employees are trusted to do their work without any need of close supervision.
cons:
Cost savings, cost savings, cost savings - the company has become one that is mostly about cutting the costs, so profits can be improved. Employees are promoted months, sometimes years, after they have started doing a certain job. What is more, salary is rarely adjusted, to match the new responsibilities. Pay raise is rare or it is insignificant. Supervisors do not know much about employees' success, still they have to rate employees once a year. That said, recognition is never received if you don't go and explain why you deserve it.

pros: Some of the people are really great. Unfortunately they are all fear ridden and bow to the toxic leadership and don't make recommendations for the greater good even if it's in the best interest of the customers and company.
cons:
Old school thinking, very hierarchical even if leaders are not providing much direction or value, lack of strategy and strategic guidance at Exec thru IC levels. They are not ethical when it comes to employee layoffs and payout of RSUs to employees. Negative culture. Everyone complains, no one takes on anything to help anyone else, finger pointing, etc. Very unproductive due to continuous re-orgs and lack of Sr. Leadership strategy.
Advice to Management
Get leaders who actually care about customers more than themselves. Lots of head nodding and pretending to address concerns and nothing is done. Be transparent and upfront if nothing is going to be done.

review_title: Used to be a great company...
cons:
lting manager, product manager 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
HP used to be a great company with very specific positive culture, caring for employees, promoting and rewarding great performance. It was also on the cutting enge of technology and had a great portfolio of products and services. A strong consulting arm was clearly determined to enable and support the classical core business - hardware and software.
Cons
Since Carly took over as CEO, the way to the abyss started and has continued until today. The HP culture (HP Way) disappeared, management by excel introduced, relationships damaged. Focusing only on the "core" business, a.k.a. "back to the roots", destroyed many great values in the services and consulting business, formerly valued employees and great contributors pushed out.
Advice to Management
Go back to the HP Way, value great employees, listen to people

review_title: They have lots to do to get back to great again.
pros: There is a team spirit at HPE and a general family feeling at the company which in the past has driven a lot of long tenure of employees. They offer flexibility of working locations in some roles which is helpful.
cons:
They have no focus on culture, equality and leaders do not appear to be accountable. Same mistakes or target misses happen yet leaders remain in post or get promoted.

Promotions are typically already agreed behind closed doors and then a pseudo process is run to try and demonstrate the decision is not already made. HR at there only to protect the organisation and not that of the employees. Leadership in U.K. is very clique and at best average in terms of talent outside of 1 or 2 exceptions. Many talented people have decided to leave but never an acknowledgement of this and what the organisation was doing to address this issue. A shame as the U.K. was booming both culturally and with a great talent mix only a few years ago.
Advice to Management
See Above

review_title: An Icon that lost its way
pros:
Employees were engaged and supported the company, good camaraderie

Managers empowered to support and mentor

Good products, bad execution
cons:
Letting the patients run the asylum - The constant executive churn starting in 2002 (Remember Carly?) became a debilitating condition for this company, board in-fighting and conflicting interests set the company a drift for many years

A squandered opportunity when rescued from the doldrums by a new skipper (Meg) who set course on unwinding the company by selling off assets, and "spin-merging" her way into a golden parachute as if she really needed the money. Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard must be wondering what happened to the "HP Way" I joined HP because of their reputation for employee commitment and innovation, and not the cut throat , scorched earth, bottom line. Even the company picnic and camping grounds were sold!
Advice to Management
I would say return to your roots, but I believe there is no one there left who knows what that means, I don't expect to see an HPE in the next 5 to 10 years if the current executive mentality prevails.

review_title: Great opportunity for career and travel the world
pros:
1. Huge company with many opportunities to move into new fields, find promotions, and build a great career.
2. If you like travel, then (depending on your role) there is plenty of opportunities here. I saw over 10 countries (multiple times), and plenty of demostic flights, during my time here.

cons:
Salary is quite average and not plus
No paid extra time

Security is always a pain in the neck

Care more about the people, care about their well-being and ensure the benefits are competitive, specially the salary and bonuses. We know there have been better times financially speaking, but that's not the employee's fault so reward your people as they deserve.

pros: Work Life Balance, Some interesting Projects, Fun Co-Workers, Frisbee Golf
cons:
One of my co-workers was extremely racist against me and when I brought it up to HR, I felt as if the company was attacking me, instead of trying to help and it really hurt my career. **I apologize if this language is profane but it is the only way I can articulate what happened ** One of my co-workers learned that I was jewish and in a training meeting started to try to instigate an argument with racist rhetoric. He said "The jews started WW2" which I ignored. Later when another co-worker explained that I don't like the food in the cafeteria and preferred to eat out, he said "Its cuz hes a jew..". When I brought up the racist remarks to HR they seemed to insinuate that it was my fault. I really thought that HP was more open and inclusive to diverse people but in reality they will defend bigotry and hatred. I honestly liked my job there but I felt as if I was being bullied for my race.
Advice to Management
Pay more attention to new hires and route out people with racist views against the Jews.

pros: As painful as the process was, I learned a lot. They sent me to some amazing workshops that changed the way I market things and pitch ideas.
cons:
HP was doing a lot of reorganizations when I was there -- about one every 12 to 18 months. And every time, people would be laid off and then they would contact me and say "your new job title is X and your new boss is Y". I was typically thrown into jobs I had no idea what to do and no idea where to find out how to do them, and my manager was in another country. I remember one manager coming to the US and seeing what I was doing to try and get my job done and he was amazed at how hard I was making it -- just because I had no idea what to do.
Advice to Management
Get a set of best practices together for each job description and provide guildance when you throw someone into a new job. More detailed assistance from a manager.

pros: Flexible working environment. People are on so little pressure that you can find many individuals who stay in a role for many years. Decent salary package.
cons:
Company is not supportive of career growth or rotation unless you are in a senior business manager role. Great opportunities are given time and time again to non-Asian locals, management seem to have strong unconscious bias. Benefits are not great - not much leave, medical benefits are low. Number of days of leave is pathetic, and on top of that they force you to take year end shut down period from your annual leave.
Advice to Management
Invest in your talent more. Maybe you need to enforce a mandatory reshuffling of roles every 2-3 years at first, until people get in the habit of hiring based on charateristics and skills, not just on experience doing the exact same thing for the past few years. Stop promoting people just because they speak like you, give other racial profiles a chance in senior roles, even if they don't know how to PR speak.

review_title: It depends what you are searching for
pros:
It is quite a laidback culture. Environment is so good. Generally people are nice. You will feel comfortable working in company like this. Pace can be slow or fast depends on your department. I am in manufacturing and logistic and i got a slow pace.

Benefits are good. Salary may not be as competitive as other companies but health benefits and flexi benefits are there especially for perm staff. 14 days of leave, 14 days of sick leave.
cons:
Too laidback. If you are the type of people who likes slow comfortable pace, this is the company for you. However if you are looking for more challenges and dynamic, you might want to look somewhere else.

Generally bonus is not too big. 1 month AWS. Performance bonus vary but generally not up to 1 month.
Advice to Management
Benchmark salary to what other company can offer. Encourage more dynamic pace.

review_title: Think carefully - Too much change is not good!
pros: While working at HPE, I was able to gain experience in different parts of the business. It does allow opportunity for growth.
cons:
Internal transfers can be political and it's difficult to move without manager approval. Based on offshoring many positions, they have eliminated many of the higher salaried roles and if you are promoted, a salary increase is generally not provided. Based on the spin-off and divestitures, there is too much disruption to organizational structures. When people are laid off and are part of your effort, there is not notice or transition and you may be left with a gap. With layoffs, people are stretched thin and expected to do more without support.

review_title: Great people with garage executive management.
pros:
Treat you like an adult. Get your stuff done and you’ll never feel like you’re being managed. 
Wonderful workmates
Friendly atmosphere mostly
cons:
The C-Level mgmt only sees the company from a sub-orbital Level (150,000 ft level). This leads to stupid, tenure based layoffs resulting in severe loss of talent. Not a meritocracy at all. Advice to Management

pros: Some great people still there. Great products and possibilities.
cons:
Nobody knows what will happen with the company in 3yr from now. Management keeps talking about amazing technology, and we do have great products and great innovation, the problem is that the IT world is moving on towards Public Cloud, and innovation is valued at the software level, not the hardware level. HPE's growth is a challenge in an environment were AWS, Azure and others are growing 40%+.
Advice to Management
HPE is not in the market of computers and storage. HPE is in the market of computing and storage services. Customers are shifting from a buying boxes to buying services, and they don't even want to care about their DCs anymore. We need to completely change the company, as Microsoft did, or HPE will just dither and die.

We need to completely change the company, as Microsoft did, or HPE will just dither and die.

review_title: Not too bad, but not great.
pros: Work-life balance is decent and there is potential for growth within the company. It is relatively relaxed and there are fun and interesting things to work on. The people are great to work with and there is an overall positive work culture.
cons:
Compensation is definitely not as competitive as it could be. Overall employee benefits are average at best. Perhaps expected for a large, old company. Definitely not a company that attracts the top talent or perceived as a "cool" place to work. It's a job and that's mostly it, assuming your business unit hasn't been shut down yet. Bonuses - What are those? Stock rewards - only for the executives.
Advice to Management
The general consensus from those in the workforce is that there aren't many other options nearby, so people just settle for mediocrity - both in compensation, benefits, and performance. Work hard enough to get the job done and go home. Some people work harder, but they sure aren't being rewarded for it. While the company seems to be shedding divisions left and right, maybe this is to make the company nimble enough to one day pay attention to and keep high performing workers, attract better outside talent, and be a first-choice for new graduates rather than the left-overs.

review_title: Hit or Miss depending on your job
pros:
HPE can be a great place to work depending on what you do at the company.
All employees get great benefits. Our vacation, pto, health insurance, etc are quite good. We also get employee discounts on just about everything under the sun (cell phone plans and car lease/finance discounts are the best).

You also have the flexibility to change roles often ( you can move around in as little as every 1-2 yrs). Theres a good amount of internal postings to consider.

And working in sales I do get the chance to travel on occasion, but vendors/partners do come in often. So there's always free lunches/dinners/happy hours/prizes/etc to be had. 

We also hire lots of college grads for entry level jobs, all the way up to highly experienced people for more senior roles.
cons:
I've only worked in sales so i cant speak on other functions but heres whats wrong with our department. It can be VERY hit or miss in sales at HPE: 

First off is pay. I've been here 4 years, and 3 of which they've messed up my pay at least once per year. The one year they didnt was only because I was salary then! The internal tracking system to measure quota attainment is literally never right (and been publicly ridiculed), and takes too long to be updated/corrected. One year I was even on draw since the software was so messed up that it took them about 7 months to pay me back owed commission. Pay is also mediocre given our industry. Pay in other companies (especially cloud and software is much better.

Then comes territory/quota. This is also very hit or miss. You might hit the "lottery", and get a territory where you dont have to do anything and you can hit multipliers. Or, you can get a bad one where its near impossible to hit your numbers. 

We're also constantly changing, but not in a good way. I know change is inevitable at any job, but its bad here. Ive had 4 different managers, 3 VP's, moved desks 10+ times, worked in 2 different buildings (and soon to be 3) all in 4 years. That doesnt even include all the job restructuring and comp changes either. We just cant seem to find anything that works right.

Last but not least, turnover is extremely high. Its no wonder so many sales reps leave in less than a year.
Advice to Management
1. Get compensation figured out. Pay us better, correctly, and in a timely matter.
2. Pick a plan and stick with it for longer than a quarter. 

You'd think a college grad hit the jackpot landing their first job at HPE, but when they leave in less than a year this is why. I hear it from them daily. Fix these and turnover will be much less.

pros:
• Colleagues were the highest quality professionals, committed, sharp, and driven, excellent cross-functional teaming. 
• For the most part very little micromanaging – direct line managers have trust in their people
• The newest solutions and products are highly impressive and exciting to work on, you feel you are part of a bold new direction for technology.
cons:
• Executive Management is arrogant 
• Executives protect their jobs while allowing the rank and file employees to absorb all of the risk in their constant downsizing.
• The company is too top heavy based on the drastically reduced company size; they need to flatten and simplify the organizational structure.
• Too much red tape and process to accomplish goals in targeted timeframes. 
• Constant layoffs and re-orgs disrupt business. Direction is never clear. 
• Talent is never evaluated in layoffs and typically high performers in key areas are hit.
• NO work/life balance and HUGE expectations. Not enough people to do the work and employees work excessive hours to accomplish goals with little to no recognition/reward.
• Nearly impossible to obtain market parity in salaries – increases are dismal at best regardless of level of accomplishments.
• Little to no upward mobility
• NO remote worker policy any longer which seriously limits their pool of qualified candidates and opportunities for current employees.
Advice to Management
They know what to fix, they've been doing yearly employee surveys for more than a decade with similar feedback, but nothing ever changes. They need new blood from an executive standpoint, leaders who know how to inspire an entrepreneurial approach that truly motivates employees as well as recognizes and rewards goals achieved. 
For God's sake, STOP the constant re-orgs! It is highly demotivating, devaluing, and disruptive to customers and employees alike. They can't keep ringing out profit on the back of the workers. Give highly paid advice time to work.

review_title: Meg didn't understand software and she broke it
pros:
My particular team/business unit was great! It's why I stayed despite everything else. HPE is a big place, and the specific team makes a huge difference to how happy you'll be.

Work/life balance was generally good.
cons:
Lots of churn, including layoffs and replacing high-value team members with cheap (offshore or new grads) who weren't equipped to perform at that level. Not fair to them and not fair to the team.

"New month, new re-org" became a thing in the year or so leading up to the Software spin-merge.

Too many WFRs smelled like age discrimination.

Compensation was stagnant and not tied to individual performance.
Advice to Management
1. HPE never found its way after splitting off from HP. They finally admitted that they didn't understand software, which is good, and the spin-merge had promise, but they put the same old guard that didn't understand software in charge of software going forward with the new company, dooming it. My advice is: when you're in over your head, ADMIT IT (no shame!) and ask the experts on the team for guidance, even if they aren't execs. The leaders in your software org had tons of relevant knowledge and experience and you neglected that valuable resource, to the detriment of everybody in the software org.

2. Stop living quarter-by-quarter and spinning tales for the stockholders. They know enough to spot BS, and meanwhile you lay off good performers and assume you'll back-fill them later with no cost in product quality or schedules -- unrealistic. But you let people who are well-connected slide by and spend huge amounts of money on boondoggles like Discover. None of this sends encouraging messages to employees.
3 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: My experience as a HPE employee
pros: I used to have working from home, medical insurance, transportation and in my last role I had low supervision from my manager, a good location, my manager was a very approachable person.
cons:

Also they used to pay more to new employees, instead of pay better to seniors that have done a lot more to rise the company.
Advice to Management
People want to be recognized, they want more challenges, and opportunities to grow, a better communication from management. Employees are the key for a successful company, don´t forget about them, or they might forget about the vision of the company.

pros: If you like working in a corporate that is structured then HPE might still be worth considering. HPE has some businesses that are profitable and on the cutting edge such as high performance computing, speciallized server computing...
cons:
Slow. Beaurocratic. Unrealistic. Red-taped.

I came from a much fast-paced environment so how things run internally at HPE shocks me. While HPE has tried to change its strategy recently, it's not enough. Mutilpe layers of management and blanket decisions made from the top who are so far away from reality just makes everything worse for day-to-day workers.

While the ongoing cost-cutting effort HPE is needed to turn around the business, it was so implemented in a stupid fashion that it actually hurts the company in the long term. There are painful decisions to be made but they should be selective and well-thought. So far, HPE fails at this and loses its best employees.

While Meg stepping down is a good thing as I personally don't think she brought any significant value to HPE, not sure what Antonio can do in the future to turn the tide around if core problems can't be addressed properly.
Advice to Management
Be realistic.

pros:
Some of the most sociable and enjoyable people I have worked with in my career.
Great entry level job to learn about the tech industry.
Benefits are great/ so is time off and PTO
Office is in good location in Plano
cons:
Wonky compensation system; you better count on your base only when paying your bills; comission should be considered gravy.
Lot of “fire drills” in this company where it’s Friday at 3 and the director comes around asking if you accomplished some unknown task for the week.
Not a clear career path for Inside Sales rep besides ISDM or Field Sales.
Budget is tight recently, my team was awarded a team outing but we were told to pay for ourselves.
Morale is low; you get the attitude from most people working here this is just a job that pays their bills for now until something better comes along.
Advice to Management
1. Stop micromanaging.
2. Look deeper besides the metrics and Brown bosses when promoting people.
3. Inform your reps about mistakes that were made by upper management; we will find out and we will call you out on it. It would be better to just tell us up front.
4. Don’t expect the ERG’s to produce the culture in the office when you won’t even provide them a budget.(Fun costs money shocker I know)

ltant III
21 Mar 2018 - Anonymous Employee 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I had a good 10 years with HP, HPE and various other company names over those years.
Cons
After many years of treating employees well, for the last 3 years or so they have been 'restructuring'. What the restructuring translates to is that they have devalued their employees. They have been having periodic WFRs offloading employees of long standing to replace them with lower cost alternatives.

I got a minimal severance as a remote support engineer but recent jettisons have not been as kind. 'Field engineers' were most recently unceremoniously dumped earlier this month.
Advice to Management
It is probably too late now but upper management should remember what gave them value. As Bill and Dave used to say, "Our greatest asset is our employees". That no longer seems to apply as they are outsourcing everything they possibly can as soon as they can.

review_title: Definitely not a place to have a career anymore
pros: The only pro I have for HPE is it's history. Where the company came from and all they've accomplished. I use to have enormous pride when I told people, I work for Hewlett Packard. All that's changed
cons:
They are not the same company anymore. They split from their personal computers and printers side of the company. They sold off their internal I.T. Dept. And 3 others depts as well. They've laid off and ungodly amount of employees. Some that have been with the company for 3 to 4 decades. They've systematically broken several support teams to the point where we are unable to properly do what should be our main goal, actually help and assist our customers. It's clear to me that the go forward strategy with HPE is not to look out for the employees or help the customers. It's to carve out pieces of the company little by little so it's small enough to be sold off. So why in the hell would I want to continue working for a company that acts like this?
Advice to Management
Honestly, the damage has been done. I know HPE will never get back to where we were in the industry. We were too little, too late in alot of different ways. All I would tell management is just be honest with your employees and let us know what's really going on. Let us know if we should be looking for other jobs. Because if HPE is not planning on selling off than why in the hell are these idiotic decisions being made?

Our Total Rewards program includes competitive base pay and benefits, and the chance to earn an annual bonus based on performance. pros: Ability to have a flexible work schedule and being able to work from home when necessary.
cons:
The company expects 100%+ from their employees and for them to be fully dedicated. Unfortunately the company is not dedicated to their employees and are quick to offshore roles to save on headcount expense. Hiring in low cost countries saves the company money however, the expertise is lost impacting the end user/customer.
Advice to Management
Be more creative in finding ways to reduce overall costs versus immediately looking to reduce headcount to save dollars.

review_title: Good career options if you can avoid layoffs
pros: Lots of autonomy, opportunities to learn, my manager was very supportive of my taking on new areas of responsibility even when I was not experienced in those areas.
cons:
The periodic redundancies have cast a pall over the organization. No one expects to retire from hp, or even to remain long term. It means many good people have left of their own accord rather than wait for it.
Advice to Management
UK management are in a tough position - they don't create product strategy / new businesses - that is done in California. Yet they still need to do more to address the sense among staff that their jobs could disappear with the next quarterly earnings report. This means creating an environment where employees have opportunities they might not have with more stable employers.

pros:
Good benefits and employee resource programs. They allow a certain number of hours per year to be used towards volunteer initiatives.
There's also different training videos available that employees can take on their own time.
cons:
Several. Operationally speaking, many processes are slow, moreso than need be. Most significantly, they have a long standing reputation for issues with employees receiving their sales commission on time, and sometimes at all. The task of looking into one's commission (tracking and claiming missing commission) is quite convoluted - to the point where it's been said on many occasions that sales persons felt the company made it so difficult and take so long in hopes that they just give up and stop requesting their commission that is being claimed/debated (this is just a feeling). There's published articles however, in online resources and outlets that detail this continent wide pay issue.

There's an obvious clique mentality where opportunity is more available to those within the clique vs those who are not but are excellent employees.

Employees within the same roles are not provided the same salary pay, despite at times some employees in a given role having more experience than the next. Additionally the salary in some positions are beneath industry standards/averages for the same or comparable roles in other organizations. 

Finally, personal employee information is often shared outside of appropriate avenues. Either from HR or at management level, private and personal details have been shared and unfortunately spreads.
Advice to Management
Many of these negatives can be avoided if the company makes a genuine commitment to improve employee satisfaction and internal operational efficiency with integrity. Be open to constructive criticism. Ensure salary is the same across the board per the role, or within reasonable frames, or based on experience coming into the role.
Treat others the way you would want to be treated. For a company of this size and global recognition, it should be leading the way in many if not all of these areas I have touched upon.

review_title: The worst company I have ever worked for by a country mile. Please avoid!
pros:
Relatively local to me.
Flex time.
Work from home.
Free parking.
cons:
This is a 'bargain basement' IT services company that invests the absolute bare minimum in their staff. You have to search far and wide for anyone within the company that actually has anything good to say about it. There are a lot of trainees (that replace good staff that are constantly leaving) that stay for 18 months to 2 years to get the name 'Hewlett Packard CDS' on their CV (it may be wholly owned by Hewlett Packard but its NOTHING like the parent company). Training almost appears to be a 'swear' word in this place but your constantly told that how much the company invests in staff training... I'd like to know where they measure this since it is clearly inaccurate!!
This company has the most frustrating 'job architecture' and they continue to not give you any salary banding for roles (although this has been asked for by 'the workforce' surveys many times).
Purchasing anything is a mammoth task. Nothing happens quickly and the level of justification needed is just insane.
Advice to Management
Pay your good staff what they are actually worth and encourage them to think outside the box. One of the many problems with this company is that upper management are so untrusting of their staff and its run more like a primary school. If you look at a lot of tech companies they employ good people that they rely on to make a difference to the company - there is no point employing someone with lots of good ideas and can think outside the box when they're told 'no - do it like this' and 'stop thinking outside of the box' - this is IMHO exactly why you have a BIG turnover of staff!!
Please Please Please act on employee feedback - voice of the workforce seemingly is completely ignored (when it ran) in addition to leavers comments in exit interviews (I know of at least 2 others who put poor pay on their exit questionnaires!) and yet touching base with some of my ex colleagues they confirm no pay rises continue to be a 'feature'.

pros:
-Large company = Big support network. You'll always have someone to go to, if there's something you don't know yourself
-Lot's of career opportunities, if you play your cards right. 
-Best in class products
cons:
-Large company = Some people could easily feel like a small piece in a very large puzzle. It can be disheartening depending on your personality. By all means, if you want to be that average guy/girl that wants a 9-5 job, average pay, this could be the perfect place for you. 

-Upper management has no appreciation for customer service, not even in the higher levels L2/L3 (Bangalore and Houston). They are severely underpaid and overworked, and when you work there, you basically feel like a liability to the upper management. Of course you get the occasional suit visiting your center, saying how important you are, but at the end of the day salaries offered are well below industry average.

-Salary levels is below industry average. Some managers will often cite "You can feel lucky you get to work with the products in the business"

-Staffing models is broken. In my center, they only hired the bare minimum to just about keep up with the incoming volume of calls and cases, if we were fully staffed. Thing is, we are all human. People get sick, need holidays, need training. So if you work in CSC, you can expect to have to work your as* off every single day. This constantly sets off a bad chain of events as people calling in sick because of a stressful job environment. That also leaves the remaining people that actually works, with an even higher workload.

-If someone is performing extremely bad, like not technically fit for his/her job and not doing much and has a very bad attitude, management will do little or nothing about it.
Advice to Management
-Raise average salary for workers in CSC. This will attract better talent and more motivated workers.
-Change your staffing models. They don't work
-Train your managers to handle difficult situations like when employees starts to underperform or call in sick twice every week.

employee_title: Advisory 6 Professional Services Delivery Manager EMEA
review_title: Was an excellent company until some years ago, spreadsheet managers have taken over, inspiring leaders got fired.
pros: Great team of high performing individuals. Good salary and benefits once you have broken through the invisible barrier. At the forefront of IT Technology with strong leading edge solutions portfolio. HPE is hungry and takes a ‘no prisoners approach’ in winning new and defending existing business. Interesting work in cross functional and cross geography setting.
cons:
High workload and stress level. Multi-year global company restructuring with massive layoffs in countries with high labor costs. Constant cost cutting. Many top experienced talents are leaving company, both voluntary and forced through workforce reduction. No salary increases since many years for big majority of people. Increased tendency to hire young talents for low salaries. Customer satisfaction mentality is deteriorating and is replaced by spreadsheet mentality: there is always a possibility to make something a little bit cheaper and a little bit worse.
Advice to Management
You need experienced talents to run the business and deliver value to customers. Focus more on value than on cost cutting.

review_title: Good people on the ground. Some mid level and upper management is terrible.
pros: Peers are fantastic. Good products for the most part. Acceptable work/life balance. Most lower level management is solid and there to help you succeed. Customer facing teams are full of good people.
cons:
You are a spreadsheet line item, not a person. Raises and promotions are scarce even for top performers. Pay and benefits are sub-par. Product quality has slipped so sales and CEs spend a lot of time with support issues. Product is often out of stock so even when you win a deal, you can still lose it due to logistical incompetence. 6 weeks to ship product is unacceptable to the field and customers but somehow not a problem to management. review_title: Like many others, I am leaving
pros: Hard to think of any at this point. After the HP / HPE split many of us really thought there was an opportunity to succeed. It never materialized. Even Meg has thrown in the towel.
cons:
I do not enjoy writing this, but work has become extremely unrewarding. High stress and tight deadlines were never a problem when we all felt we were building up to something. Now, the curtain has been pulled back and each of us is realizing that there is no light at the end of this tunnel. 

HPE is:
+ understaffed
+ running low on funds
+ lost in the market place
+ promoting only a small population each year
+ not paying 2017 bonuses
Advice to Management
Help those on your team prepare for the next phase in their life away from HPE.

pros: I lasted with HPE just over a year. The direct team (specifically my peers) I worked with was wonderful. Everyone was always willing to help one another. It was one of the only reasons why I stayed with the company, albeit a short time.
cons:
I had hoped to stay at HPE long term but unfortunately, there were several red flags that caused me to jump ship. First, my direct manager never supported our team. Because of this, myself and my teammates could not do the job we were hired to do. We were supposed to be the "voice" for our external customers, only to have our ideas ignored and swept under the rug . On staff calls, when we had concerns, we were told it was not the right forum to be bringing them up (still shocks me to this day). This hampered our ability to think creatively and outside of the box because everyone felt like it was a waste of their breath. The team I was on had so many talented, smart people and we were never leveraged to the fullest of our capabilities. Second, our team ended up taking on responsibilities that were not even part of the scope of our role. A lot of things were thrown at us at the very last minute causing extreme stress and frustration. The straw that broke the camel's back for me was the extreme micromanaging done by the direct manager and that manager's manager. It was an incredibly terrible environment to be working in (even though our team was remote) to the point that I no longer enjoyed my job.
Advice to Management
Make sure you hire managers (especially with direct reports) and executive management, who are open to hearing feedback (good and bad) from their team and do not shut them out. Make sure that they want their team to be collaborative, to share ideas and concerns among one another without feeling like they will be reprimanded.

review_title: Focused on Hiring Low-Skilled, Low-Cost Employees
pros: My colleagues were the reason I went to work each day. I worked with some of the very best people around, both professionally and personally ... until they were laid off and replaced by young, unskilled, inexperienced people who do not know enough to make sound decisions.
cons:
Management doesn't value loyalty, hard work, knowledge and experience. Rather, they care about cutting costs through layoffs and replacing workers offshore. They are replacing valuable, knowledgeable and experienced long-time employees with brand new people in low-cost countries with very few skills who have no loyalty to the company, HP's reputation or level of quality. All of that has decreased in recent years since Meg started on her quest to "trim the gray hair" company-wide and send jobs outside the US, where HP was founded. Meanwhile, the execs take multimillion dollar bonuses in money, stock and other incentives while long-term, loyal employees lose their jobs, their homes and have to re-plan their retirements.

Work-life balance is horrible with all of the layoffs and all of the inexperienced workers. Everything is done the hard way, nothing the smart way.
Advice to Management
Value and reward the knowledge, experience and skills that made this company succeed for decades. Be loyal to the employees who have been loyal to HP/HPE. Bill and Dave believed and ran their company like their employees were family. That is what made them so successful. You have totally missed the boat in this regard!

review_title: Great company to begin your career, not to continue it.
pros: HPE has vary good salary and flexibility options for new employees. There are many free learning opportunities available to gain new skills.
cons:
The company culture has decayed from vibrant and exciting to dry and depressing. There is a constant threat of being laid off, even for highly-skilled, experienced employees. Management has no idea which direction they want the company to go in, so goals are often unfocused and seemingly pointless. The office environment has moved to an "open concept" seating arrangement, which is not only horrible for employee focus and comfort, but also employee trust in their managers. Jobs are constantly being outsourced to places like India or Brazil where the employees are cheaper but vastly less capable. Our small team in the US was responsible for fixing all of the mistakes that Brazilians had made in our software. These people can be smart, but they have no respect for accepted conventions or best practices.
Advice to Management
Quit outsourcing software work. You'll save money if you don't have to hire people in the US to undo their mistakes. Restore employee privacy in the workplace and stop the constant layoffs to improve employee morale immensely.
6 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: A large established company, friendly modern working environment and active on conforming to standards of business conduct ethics.
cons:
Management is still mostly from Legacy HP, Compaq, Digital era and maintain that old mindset. 

Hardly any 'fresh blood' in influential positions. 

As generous employee perks have fallen by the wayside in the whole industry over the years, most managers are treating it as a 'job for life' and that hardly inspires revolutionary or evolutionary thinking or provide opportunities for innovators to get into positions to make a real difference.
Advice to Management
Don't allow production managers to create the matrix with which their bonuses are calculated, 'yield' sounds good but in practice, it's all just 'smoke and mirrors'. 

Link management bonuses more to customer feedback, not on if it left the factory on time.

Charge all 'internal' support costs for new orders within 6 months of delivery, directly to the 'production' budgets - that'll drive up production quality and refocus the company on the customer 'experience', which is more important than hitting revenue in the long term.

pros: Work life balance is what you'd expect at a large company and is mostly family friendly. Vision is good (execution is not). A strong engineering company with a great portfolio, and promising acquisitions filling in gaps.
cons:
Process is king here. Execution is very poor. It's near impossible to get anything done at a normal pace, and the silos are mind boggling. The marketing organization gets blown up every year, yet no one (management) takes it upon themselves to actually put the pieces back together again, and make any sense of it. Rinse and repeat year after year. What a mess. Reorgs are common and often necessary however at HPE, what follows is a weird blend of chaos and inertia. Morale here is the worst I've ever encountered due to rolling work force reductions.
Advice to Management
EXECUTE. Do your jobs and actually try managing the change you prescribe. There is an art to change management, hire some people who master it. Throw out your clunky home grown BI tools and utilize those developed by experts who are not motivated to keep their archaic systems in place to keep their jobs. Hold your ad agency and the team managing many millions of dollars accountable. Save some money on media buys and implement some new marketing tools in place of marketing ops people to trim the fat vs. just cutting people across the board. And this should be obvious, but treat your people better. Invest in your work force.
