pros: Flexible schedule, decent work environment, fairly decent pay.
cons:
Working here is like working for a government constantly feeding you BS propaganda. The higher ups are never truthful with employees about anything, and your direct manager is also probably being lied to by everyone above them. 

The morale in the office I worked in was abysmal, even I first started back in early 2016, before everybody was being let go. The people who were here suffer from Stockholm Syndrome, as they're almost all over 40 and feel like they can't get work anywhere else. 

The company doesn't reward it's own employees, as I got a 1% raise after my first year. Turns out everyone on my team got a 1% raise at the same time because HPE couldn't afford to give out any more. When I was WFR'd in October of 2017, I figured I was being given an opportunity to move on. My next position had a 20% salary increase over what HPE had been paying me...

Also the companies products tend to be incredibly broken and the teams producing new releases are so beyond and mismanaged, it's a wonder they have anything that WORKS on the market as of now. I would avoid this company at all costs as it would a complete SHOCK if they were in business still, within the next few years...
Advice to Management
Stop lying to employees, start being TRANSPARENT, start making smart decisions instead of cutting your nose off despite your face. Stop allowing off shore development to ruin all your products, stop selling broken products, stop killing off product lines in favor of "new" untested BS. Or maybe, just shut the company down and stop disappointing everyone.

pros: Great products, and great people
cons:
In the two years that I have worked here, there has been nothing but one false start after another. Meg Whitman and Antonio Neri are just throwing garbage at the wall and hoping something sticks. They have zero vision for the company and the great products and people that work their. Every couple of months they would do a complete change in direction. Sadly they are running the company into the ground.
Advice to Management
The board of directors should clean house. Though, I suspect that the next move that will happen will be they will get bought by a company that sees the value of their products and employees and hopefully the new company will get rid of the people at the top that have decimated a once great company. Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard must be turning over in their grave to see what current management has done to the company.

pros: Solid products. Sales people are terrific and, the people/fuel that keeps HPE running!
cons:
Weak management. Have made very poor decisions relative to cloud strategy. Director level and above - can't make decisions without hiring third party consultant company. At this point, it's too late for HPE. Althoguh they have some of the finest technology in the industry, there is no one left at HPE that will or can keep them afloat. pros:
Reputable organisation
A great place to start your career and to develop on a professional and personal level
Fantastic coworkers, partners, and customers - the people make the difference
Flexible working, with a good work-life balance
Benefits are in line with the rest of the industry
Interesting customer projects
cons:
Severe lack of diversity in management - not all views are equally represented
Lack of opportunities to move in the organisation. As HPE has downsized, so have the number of places available to move laterally
The best people are leaving, looking to leave, or have left
Morale is at an all-time low due to constant threat of redundancy and lack of leadership direction
Technical knowledge-base has been substantially reduced - the organisation is no longer an engineering company but a sales company
The move to product-focused sales is a huge mistake. The industry - and customer demands - are becoming ever more complex and HPE is moving in the opposite direction
Toxic sales culture
Advice to Management
Increase diversity in upper management positions
Continually and appropriately reward people - don't wait until it's too late
Value the people with technical know-how

Management favor individuals

Read these reviews and take note (Something you never did with voice of the workforce)

You are running this company into the ground, the figures might look good today, but tomorrow your company will crumble beneath you. Do something before it is too late

pros: Good Salary, but only because I came in on a good salary. Flexible working hours and location. Working from home a regular thing.
cons:
Continual threat of redundancies. No pay rises or training for years.
As a manager, I was continually expected to cut more headcount each quarter, even though we already had not enough staff to deliver the workload. Automation only goes so far, and staff are needed to carry out the work.
Advice to Management
Support staff, and give them stability instead of threatening them with redundancy each quarter.
Allow your managers to make decisions, without everything being decided on from above. Allow lower level managers to actually manage a budget instead of dictating to them always from above.
Pick a plan and stick to it, without changing direction every month or so.

pros: I was with 3COM for 7 years, we were acquired by HP were I worked for 4 more years. Good people below the higher management ranks will too work their butt off to keep their jobs and make the company profitable.
cons:
At first, this seemed like a good acquisition then massive layoffs and split to HPE and HP Inc. Work escalated as there was no plan to manage the work with fewer people. Numerous changes yet management levels remained the same impending production and performance. Benefits went from okay to lacking, HR was totally unresponsive to the worker and very arrogant to our needs. It seemed they were there to do corporate bidding, reduce benefits, pay not to competitors and raises almost nonexistent unless you were very high up. Basically, they were and from what I hear of those still there they continue to tailspin and lack direction and leadership.
Advice to Management
You can't expect the same product with such deep cuts at the engineering and project/product management levels. If you want such deep cuts then remove the management layers, farm out your HR, improve the employee benefits, reduce at the top end. Find someone that is less interested in self-promotion and more interested in making HP what it once was a trusted brand backed by engineer excellence.

review_title: Not a great place to work
pros: It was a job and a paycheck, that is all.
cons:
They had laid off so many people, everyone in my immediate group was doing the work of 6-8 people with no hope of ever getting additional resources to do the required work (which of course, was never reduced). Everything was due yesterday, management was always coming up with the next "bright idea" with no additional resources to implement the idea, work/life balance was non-existent, 50-70 hour work weeks were the norm AND expected, recognition was non-existent, salary was sub-par and reviews were always guaranteed to be average (they had to raise the bar on you, of course).
Advice to Management
Streamline the work NOT the people. Pay your people what they are worth NOT what you can get away with. Get back to the real HP Way, not simply pay lip-service to it.

If you leave the company voluntarily or involuntarily before December 31, you're just out of luck in terms of the employer match portion. Travel has been virtually frozen for non-revenue producing trips. Company is cutting costs rather than growing revenue.

Get back to valuing employee experience and move swiftly to a growth strategy.

review_title: HPE can't figure out what they want to be in a company.
cons:
III 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
When the benefit packages were there: Rewards program where you can use points to "purchase" HP equipment. Health insurance was always top notch. My People Managers, as well as my ITO leadership was always the best in ITO Services! I will always miss working with my network team members.
Cons
Constant layoffs constantly affected morale. Account Executives with a bloated sense of value and given too much say in a decentralized, leveraged account. Online HR ticketing to fix account profile issues always seemed to be in limbo without status updates. The internal training opportunities were always computer based training with little more than power point recorded slides & content that were mostly dated.
Advice to Management
Take all sexual harassment and assault claims seriously. Stop blowing them off for the sake of profit when your turnover & history of inability to hire and keep people has been historically shown. When you have people who are still employed as managers & executives refused transfer to other state projects, constantly toxic to the work environment because of their reputation & repeated complaints from employees, sets a standard that harassment will continue because the accuser (and witnesses) are dismissed by the same "leaders."

Stop changing job titles to gibberish that the common person can't understand what the title means or responsibilities: "ITO Svc Delivery Cons III" - Systems Administrator/Engineer is much more commonly understood and less marginalized. 

Sadly, the people who read this now will likely be laid off within two years and won't be able to address the issues long term.

Helpful

review_title: No longer a great place to work
pros: Colleagues; I've made some good friends.
cons:
The past few years of splits, acquisitions and continual layoffs has left everyone with change fatigue.
Overall long term strategy is communicated to an extent, albeit piecemeal, at an overall company level but poorly communicated and executed at a department level.
Most business decisions are made at corporate level with little autonomy or ability to effect much change at a country level.
Poor attention to developing people, mentoring or providing training within each role and little guidance or feedback from direct management.
Work environment used to be flexible but working from home now is generally frowned upon and staff treated as if they're not to be trusted unless they're in direct line of sight. Staff are just numbers.
Lip service is paid to employee engagement with various programs but management rarely put in appearances and very, very few will put any of their own effort or even simple vocal endorsement behind them.
Staff amenities are cut further and further. Don't expect a Christmas party, there hasn't been one for years.
Advice to Management
Put some effort into developing proper processes, role development and education. Really, properly train your people - particularly first time managers who are generally fumbling around trying to make sense of it all.
Stop treating your employees like errant children.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful
Share
Repor

review_title: Only if you have no alternatives
pros:
There used to be good things about this company, but not so much anymore.
Pro's: 
-- It's a paycheck.
-- Decent dental and vision coverage.
-- Decent learning resources and paid for certifications.
cons:
-- Company does not honor their contracts to their employers but will fire you if you look for alternative sources for income. They literally converted me from a salaried to an hourly employee despite my contract slating to to a salary.
-- Does not pay very well for the work involved. The work is worth about $65 - $70k annually but you will be lucky to see $45k.
-- Medical benefit is absolutely horrible. The only available plan has a high deductible of which you will not meet within a year and must be paid before even general exams and doctor visits are covered.
-- Absolutely NO Job security. Even if you get your certifications they WILL lay you off with absolutely no warning.
-- Completely unorganized and expect your role to change about 20 times a year, no exaguration.
--If you're hired as a full time employee, you're going to be replaced by a contractor. If you're hired as a contractor, you're going to either receive bare minimal compensation or be terminated at the slightest mishap, or both.
-- Certifications they offer are absolutely worthless in the real world outside of HPE, they hold no weight or value to anyone except HP, unless you get the Aruba certs.
--Does not provide clear and concise learning material for even obtaining the above and mentioned certifications...
--If you're in a pinch, need overtime, need additional income, need help, expect them to be the first one to throw you under the bus. 
--Despite what they say, there IS no moving up. There were several qualified candidates for Tier II, but Tier II is reserved for either brand new hires or a very small click. There have been candidates who were well qualified for it trying to get into it for years.
-- Negotiate your salary WISELY from the start. If you're on-boarded with a low salary, expect it to stay low for a very long time. Their annual raise percentages are lower than the increase of annual inflation.
Advice to Management
Support a better employer.

review_title: Work-life balance is good but the penny-pinching is demoralizing
pros: The salary is good and the work-life balance is exceptional. Flexibility is given to manage out-of-work commitments when they arise.
cons:
This is the cheapest and most disorganized company I've ever worked for. The benefits are substandard, benefit options paltry, and the IT infrastructure is a hodge-podge of 3rd party tools that almost never work. A portion of your paid time off is forced during company shutdowns and vacation time does not carry over into the next calendar year.
Advice to Management
Spend a little money on improving the quality of life for employees and offer more comprehensive benefit options. This will go a long way toward retaining key employees.

review_title: Great products, lack expertise to deliver outcomes, and have a 'Customer Culture' but don't understand their customers.
pros: When first starting with HPE it had a portfolio that serviced the needs of its customers and delivered (some) outcomes rather than focusing on products.
cons:
Trying to transform and have senior/middle leaders that have been with the company 20+ years and have not had the experiences/skills to deliver what they are trying to achieve. Cutting costs to the bone, without understanding what value they are getting rid of. Too reliant on Management Consultants. Whilst trying to maintain a focus on the customer, they really struggle to understand the outcomes required by the customer and revert to product focused sales.
Advice to Management
Get some people in who have gone through transformations they are trying to achieve. Understand the value of your people when making cost cutting decisions. Act like the global company you are supposed to be.

review_title: Good Company, broken team and organization
pros: Dependable company, good benefits, generally good culture. Large company provides opportunities for long term career growth.
cons:
Higher pay available at competitor companies, convoluted team structures, broken reporting systems, lack of accountability by upper management.
Advice to Management
Don't shoot the messenger. System issues prevented reporting accuracy on a regular basis, but management would rather criticize the work instead of the data. Even when data issues are known, the focus is rarely on correcting the reporting systems. Matrix organization inhibits accountability, so blame tends to fall on whoever is worst at politics. Upper management fails to recognize a problem manager when most of their team starts dropping like flies.

pros:
HPE still believes strongly in the Proliant brand continues to drive the product to new heights

New company direction to focus on key hardware and IT solutions for the SMB and the enterprise

New company promises to be more agile and quicker at execution due to less overhead 

R&D budget for growth areas in server and storage are still generous, giving engineers the right tools to work with

Worldwide partner pre-sales network is far reaching 

Global travel opportunities for the appropriate job functions
cons:
The last 6 years has been a roller coaster of layoff cycles

More company acquisitions and less internal innovation. 

All employees must work from an office location, even if their virtual team is spread around the world, they are the only one in their location, and their role is 100% doable from home (or remote locations)

Spin off of software, services, and even some hardware development has had some effects on benefits. This years group health plans are not as comprehensive as previous years 

I have seen several pre-sales engineers with a wealth of technical expierence and work ethic get let go not on performance, but because their job was in the wrong location at the wrong time and a salery cut number had to be met. 

Salary increases and bonuses have been minimal to none over the last 3 years
Advice to Management
Some of you are great leaders. Many are not. Encourage and engage your teams to strive for the best they can do but don’t cut your staffing below a reasonable level and then expect the remaining few to work nights and weekends to hold a schedule that isn’t appropriately resourced for. Cross polanate your engineers to help them understand more of the products end solution rather than their piece of the widget. I would enjoy a bit more job rotation within my team

Hewlett Packard Enterprise | HPE Response
Global digital media
Hello and thank you for providing your feedback, we are happy that you have enjoyed the experience in HPE, working with great people! We'd love to see this kind of feedback more in the near future

pros: Worked with HP and HPE for more than 10 years. Early on I had a number of growth opportunities as the company was rapidly growing with new leadership positions. Working with HP was a good experience for most of the years.
cons:
Meg cut a lot of positions which impacted a lot of families, based on a focus of reducing expenses through cutting people rather than focusing on adding value through people. As with many publicly traded companies, Leadership is short sighted and not able to adequately assess the value of contribution or determine areas of profitability to get the ROI required for each employee. She chose the path to cut employees and shrink the company to size she could lead and manage. After splitting and spinning off various division the company went from 320000 global employees to 50000 in less than 2 years. More focus on expense reduction than value creation in the competitive IT global economy.
Advice to Management
Create a plan and vision where you can leverage the value employees are bringing each day. Also, I received less than two week notice after more than 10 years with the company. It seems you could have done better.

review_title: Inside Sales--- more like Inside Secretaries or Inside Politicians
pros:
-Quality products: HPE truly revolves around innovation. They have great products that you can support. They have been making a lot of strategic acquisitions, very prime for HPE. 

-Resume builder: beneficial to have a fortune 50 company on your resume 

-Schedule: work 8-5 and you're done. They don't want you working after hours because they don't want to pay overtime. Great work/life balance.

-Vacation/PTO: ISRs get a great amount of hours for just starting at a company.

-Partner Spiffs: partners throw quarterly incentives. You have the chance of getting various products/gifts/gift cards which is always nice.
cons:
I'd like to start off by saying that I am a former Plano ISR who hit their quota and was in the top half of the Leaderboard so Inside Management can't attribute this post to being from an angry ex-Conway employee or a low-performing, emotional ISR...HPE Inside Sales is Toxic.

"People don't leave companies, they leave management."

-Inside Sales Culture: dismal and defeating are just a couple words to describe the inside sales environment. Anyone who offers a suggestion, highlights an injustice, or simply voices their opinion in a respectable and professional manner is immediately reprimanded and disregarded or even put on a performance plan with no viable justification. Management cares more about reps wearing jeans on Tuesday than they do your quota attainment or commission checks not being paid! (HPE officially and legally has proclaimed they do not have a dress code by the way). Management says the leaderboard is the true determining factor of a successful sales rep. They'll reprimand you for being low on dials or Talk time, yet never applaud you for overachieving on quota attainment. 
Management has clear favorites and choose to openly show it. "All men created equal" does not apply here at Inside sales! I have never witnessed a more openly biased environment of managers blatantly showing their favoritism or hatred for certain ISRs. There is such a high turnover for a reason. You will only be successful based on how many fake dials you make in a day, how many 'partner sent' opportunities you send in a week to mandated partners (even if they're unqualified opportunities), and how much you suck up to management... not actual quota attainment, your book of business, drive, or rapport being built with end clients and Channel partners!



-Daily mandates: as an ISR you're pulled in many different directions. Management will issue one order then change it by lunchtime. There is no consistency. They say they want you to sell but really they want you to play politics. Upper management makes unofficial deals with partners to pass a certain amount of opportunities to them per quarter. The ISRs are forced to comply even if these partners aren't who the end client wants to work with. One Member of upper management mandates that ISRs send unqualified opportunities to partners to skew his numbers in a positive light. He treats the ISRs, CEMs, and ISDMs as scapegoats. He is scattered and dismissive in tone to his Subordinates. 



-Pay structure (or Lack there of): Commission has issues every year I'm told...I only stuck around for a little over my one year mark. One can only hang around for so long after not getting paid properly. There are multiple Business Insider articles over the years on how deplorable HPE MYCOMP is. So many people have open HR cases that aren't getting resolved. HPE is UNDERPAYING its employees as they keep withholding accurate commission checks. If HPE were overpaying us, they'd resolve these issues ASAP. How can a Top Fortune 50 company like HPE not implement a legitimate and efficient compensation platform? Inside Sales Management ignores it or makes you feel insignificant for caring about your next pay check. 


-Lack of Promotions: HPE is investing heavily in Inside Sales, which while great for Inside Sales, correlates to cutbacks in Field positions. When you interview, they'll highlight the career path of moving into the field. But with 250+ ISRs (a majority of which were hired on at the same time), there won't be that many field openings when you hit your one or two year mark. Management will also highlight the Progression structure with HPE offering pay increases....this is a dangling carrot. The ability to get paid and promoted is not as easy as they say. You could make every criteria but if you miss a progression training because they didn't offer it to you or you were sick or on vacation, they hold it against you and won't promote you! 



-One member of Upper Management serves as a wickedly brilliant oppressor who is impossible to get hard evidence on for any potential HR case. He will manipulate and alter your words to break you and meet his agenda. When asked a direct question, he will avoid the answer like a politician. He will say one thing then his message will change completely the next day, and he'll verbally and publicly humiliate you for being confused by a diluted and inconsistent message. He is very hard to work under/for. He was a strong catalyst in why I left the company. He is not an inspirer nor a leader; he is a nonsensical bully who stifles creativity and passion. 

Lastly, I'm told by former coworkers who are still at HPE that he's aware of this low extremely glass door rating and is incentivizing reps and directors to go write false-positive reviews (any review that is 5 stars for Inside Sales is one that's been bribed to post)
Advice to Management
People don't leave companies, they leave managers. A majority of inside Sales management has decided that 'managing up' and playing politics was more important than managing and leading their sales reps. 

HPE ISDMs--- PLEASE truly lead and inspire your reps, and above all don't keep us in the dark; please explain the reasoning why on certain mandates/justifications so we understand what we are being forced to do. Speak up when wrongdoings are done by the VP, the Directors, etc. Be an advocate for your ISRs. Also, please continue pushing upper management to resolve MyComp. I know it's out of your hands directly but the more you press the issue, the higher chance HPE works to resolve it.

My advice to ISRs is to network. While Inside Sales is a hard environment, HPE as a whole is a great company full of positive influencers. There are many great leaders within HPE, you just need to network outside of Inside Sales. Build your network, perform well, and find the influential leaders who help keep you sane in this role.

review_title: Nice place to work if you disregard management issues
pros:
I was working as a QA engineer at HPE for about 1 year

- a lot of opportunities to learn
- great infrastructure, a good set of tools to choose on
- freedom and support in applying your ideas (at least in my case)
cons:
- bad predictability - things were changing very fast
- salaries are medium to low, no bonuses (not for Christmas or anything)
- hard to set up objectives, projects are the most important even if you are assigned on a project that you do not necessarily fit 

Overall the experience in HPE was a positive one. If you do your job well and gain respect, your life will become much better.
Advice to Management
Try to listen more to what people need and what to do and assigned people on projects that will somehow fit their needs and desires

review_title: direct leadership was great but everybody else higher?
pros: most people I work with are nice
cons:
stressful to almost impossible to meet project timelines, low resources so they swamp you with work, you always have to work nights and weekends just to meet the deadline. and even with nonstop working, you still dont meet the timeline! You kill yourself just to maintain employment and even with that and NO increase for the 4 years I was there, I still get fired.
Advice to Management
Know the people that actually do the work and keep them. There were only a few of that does that can help you keep your business but it seems that you don't even look at the resource you fire. Last in First out don't always work to your advantage especially if you have lots of work that needs to be done. Keep the good resource and let go of the mediocre if you must. But at the rate that you are going, good luck finding good people!

pros:
-some of the friendliest coworkers that I ever had
-nice office environment (very clean, lots of desk space)
-opportunity to have 4 paid volunteer hours (your choice of organization) per month
cons:
-new grad hire program only served as a funnel to bring cheap labour (government subsided salary employees) into company, did nothing to promote or train/develop talent
-people left the company in my team left and right for better opportunities and the work was transferred to existing employees until we've all experienced burnout
-I wanted to get into another department, and the administrative cycles were unbearable, waiting 6 months to hear back on an interview result is crazy
-train your lower level management to be actual good people "managers" and not just good sales people 
-compensation is low
Advice to Management
-change your approach to hiring and focus on training and development
-you are losing new grad talent every day if you don't do something about it 
-don't do useless floor walks every week without actually engaging with your employees

pros:
THE PEOPLE! Nearly everyone I worked with was fantastic.
Some good benefits, but on-par or less than other large corporations.
cons:
Constant pressure of layoffs for 16+ years created bad behaviors and incredible stress.
NO worklife balance.
Upper-management unaware or uncaring of the reality of decisions filtered down to individual contributor level.
Began forcing people to move to just a few offices around the country, siting "teamwork", but no programs in place to ensure unity and no metrics tracking success.
Loss of many benefits.
Most hiring reqs have been frozen for 1.5 years at this point.
Advice to Management
Make a decision as to what HPE should BE in the future and execute on that. STOP playing "me too" - it's sad when one of the worlds most innovative companies stops innovating to "save money" and instead, becomes irrelevant.

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: There are still pockets of the old "HP Way" to be found around the company.
cons:
Not too long ago this company was very employee focused, developed great cutting edge products, and had a tremendous focus on high quality. The company is a shell of its former self at this point. None of the above stated things are true anymore. Almost every function in the company has been outsourced to some oversees supplier, no real R&D happens in the states anymore, quality has fallen off a cliff, there's constant WFR's, salaries go nowhere, medical/retirement benefits get reduced every year, and there's almost no hope for advancement for most front-line employees. All of this helps the executive level make huge financial gains for themselves at the expense of their lower level employees. I've been with this company for almost 20 years and am disgusted at what has transpired over that time.
Advice to Management
Focus on long term growth that will benefit everyone in the company as well as customers. Do not keep going down the path of short term gain at the cost of future growth. The current environment heavily favors the executive level while leaving most employees behind. Not to mention, product quality has been going down over the years due to an employee base that's getting incredibly demoralized.

review_title: Once a powerhouse, now a dud.
pros: Once a great company. Unfortunately not much positive to report over the last 10 years. All great talent has left this company.
cons:
Current Executive team and board needs to be replaced, lots of useless management levels.
Stop squeezing your most important resource, your workforce, for you own personal gain.
Constant turnover from CEO to 1st line management over the last 10 years
Constant pressure to outsource to low cost countries that cannot do the job. You get what you pay for !
Toxic work environment, most just there for a check until they find something else.
No solid vision for the future, changes ever several years, always late to the "industry party", another sign of poor executive leadership.
All in all a terrible place to work now.
Advice to Management
For many years now you preach rebuilding for future success. When will it ever end ?? Employees are tired of hearing the same old line. Take a hard look at your business model ( what ever it is today), then your competitors and your stock price over the last 10 years. Basically poor executive management, controlled by a few at the top, who have had many years to correct things yet continue to fail .

review_title: Good for a start but don't stay too long
pros:
- Flexible working hours while adhering strictly to the Polish labour code.
- Work from home possible (depending on the manager).
- Many benefits which are basically standard on the local job market.
- Possibility to take lots of self-paced online trainings about various business topics.
cons:
- Constant restructuring, mergers and splits on global level.
- Many global managers with no understanding of international markets (at least when I worked there).
- Managers can very easily block career advancement by not giving good enough yearly ratings (in order to not lose you on your current position) and therefore making you not eligible for certain trainings which would qualify you for higher positions within the company.
- Even though you get a yearly salary raise with average performance, you will be behind your peers in the local job market after 2 years. But there are worse employers in Wroclaw which don't give any salary raise.
- Salary is apparently below the local average.
- I hit the glass ceiling immediately after having been hired.
- I have heard from my ex-colleagues that the work climate has deterioated significantly shortly after I left.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: Flexible work schedule, fun work, amazingly talented coworkers- a wonderful position for lifelong learners.
cons:
Misguided middle and senior management. My project recycled almost zero code between versions, combined with increasing expectations from management (faster releases with more features) caused an increasingly 'good-enough' mantra toward product development, resulting in increasing technical debt and critical support issues.
Advice to Management
The market has spoken- the boutique servers HPE's entire business model are built around are increasingly being seen as wasted money since commodity hardware is increasingly viable as HA failover platforms such as Kubernetes mature. I know the revenue generated from high-markup servers was good while it lasted, but perhaps it's time to shift the focus from theoretical computing (The Machine) and top-tier server hardware, and focus on generating the kind of hardware and software platforms that are actually being bought to power the E-conomy.

pros: HP was a great place to work until it split in 2 to become HP Inc and Hewlett Packard Enterprise in 2015. It was the people who made it a fantastic place to work.
cons:
Since the separation the atmosphere within HPE changed. The constant cost cutting and re-structuring was unsettling to employees. Enforcing process and structures that are only suitable to a large business that have all appropriate resources in place. Unfortunately the Ireland business is a drop in the ocean in relation to the overall global organization and don't have the same level of resources or support but yet are expected to follow processes and procedures that are totally irrelevant to our local business. Let alone the time it takes to get approval to do anything.
Advice to Management
I understand process need to be followed but taking 'a once size fits all' approach is crippling the local business and employees.

review_title: Being "Number 1" in the market doesn't make it a great place to work...
pros: Easy to get in the door with customers, honestly...HPE is either first or second in most hardware categories.
cons:
Terrible work environment. Horrible culture. Pitiful benefits. Avoid this company like the plague.

You are lucky if you get paid on your commissions. Always another excuse to not give a bonus for top performers (I've received "Accelerating", "Significantly Achieves Expectations", "K") throughout the years. Each performance review ends with "....but....due to the economic environment we can't only provide a 1.05% pay rise....keep up the great work!"
Advice to Management
Stop telling everyone the customer is #1. Everyone knows the current order is shareholders, customers, then employees.

pros: The people I work with are great and some of the brightest people I have ever worked with in the industry and I love what I do.
cons:
The compensation for individual contributors is embarrassingly low for a majority of the employees. Real compensation only happens to upper management. Anemic raises and bonuses are borderline insulting, even when performance has exceeded expectation year after year.
Advice to Management
Clearly state the bonus and compensation plan. 10% bonus plan, 15%, 20%, 30% etc all the way up to Meg. Total compensation is based up 3 metrics: individual performance, division performance and company performance. This should be the pattern from the lowest paid employee to the highest ranking employee. If any of the 3 are not met, the employee earns a percentage of the goal. To see executives's total compensation not tied to company performance is absolutely maddening and symptomatic of what's completely broken in corporate America today.

pros: Stable company, large portfolio of products, option to move around
cons:
Management by walking around is a forgotten motto. Upper management is disconnected from what is going on in the trenches. Moving R&D to "low cost" geos has resulted in slashing costs, slashing innovation and slashing revenues. As a hardware company HPE has never understood software. Company makes it difficult to do business and to do your job, a technology company that uses old technology for most of its internal business processes
Advice to Management
Figure out how to rekindle the spirit of innovation before its too late
Come down from the ivory towers and mingle with the masses, listen to them, you will be surprised how much you may learn about what works and what doesn't
Upgrade your technology and understand what makes technologists tick, we are technologists because we love technology, we want to work with the latest of this year, not of 10 years ago

pros: Mostly well-meaning people with a good history of innovation. Many nice folks in engineering, sales, service and support organizations. More focused, nimble company than in the past. Solid margins on the business so generates good operating income. Lots of activity in M&A. Physical work environment is improving as some offices are getting good face-lifts. Budget seemingly always available for high-priced consulting firms - many of which work for HPE at any given time. World-class at planning and executing cost reduction/layoff plans. Always bringing in new external talent at very senior levels of the company. Good pay and benefits for executives. Good comp plans for sales professionals.
cons:
HPE is in a difficult product market with flat to declining revenues, which leads to all kinds of issues, including but not limited to the following list: Very few opportunities as there is a focus on reducing executives. Annual planning cycle is composed of constant downward revisions to revenue plans followed by cost-cutting to maintain income as much as possible. Sr. Exec hires are NOT told ahead of time about the operational limitations that HR and Finance will place upon them, which leads to frustrations all around. Per financial statements, "investments" in layoffs are pretty comparable to investments in acquisitions - not a good place to be. Constant stream of sr. level executives that present ideas to Meg without sanity-checking ideas with the business leading to unreasonable expectation in the Executive Suite and frustrations in the rest of the organization. Not a good place for former big-3 management consultants. Very poor track record of attracting and retaining people from McKinsey, BCG etc.
Advice to Management
Determine whether the millions of dollars spent on consulting firms might not be better spent on retaining current management and perhaps hiring a few mid-level folks that will stick around. Institute 360 degree feedback for Directors & above (including SVPs and EVPs). Many poor leaders in Director and VP ranks in Palo Alto stick around for much longer than they should. Sucking up to EVPs/SVPs is not equal to thoughtful leadership and value creation.
6 people found this review helpful

review_title: Not the company it used to be
cons:
ltant in Detroit, MI
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Lots of room to grow. 
Lots of fringe benefits (although not as many as there used to be)
Big name recognition for your resume
Cons
Busy cutting their way into extinction. 
Endless layoffs and cost cutting
Management is more interested in the bottom line than the customer
Terrible backoffice processes
No raises, bonuses or rewards in years. No sign of any change here.
Pension plan is history. 
401k matching is now annual, if the company decided they will do it that year. 
Immediate leadership is often in another country...very little positive feedback.
Performance goals have no bearing on salary, raises or bonuses...
Advice to Management
Your employees are your #1 asset. They make, install, maintain and manage your products, and ultimately that is what your customers are buying. There are lots of companies out there that do the same thing - your differentiation used to be quality and comprehensiveness - now you are so busy focusing on price that what made you stand out is lost...and you are just another name in the crowd. Your internal processes are horrible - I've been fighting for over 6 months about my last paycheck, and it's still not resolved. Your payroll department still can't do basic math. I left the company voluntarily, got a 15% pay raise, cheaper benefits, better environment. Remember who got you where you are, and remember that without them you'll be nowhere.

review_title: HPE used to be a good place to work
pros: This used to be a great place to work. However it has taken a few turns for the worse as the company has split from HP to HP Inc. and HPE. HPE has only continued to deteriorate as segments of the business have been out sourced or sold off. The only pro is that it looks great on a resume if you can stick it out that long.
cons:
There is no reward for hard work here. You can hit your quota and work 12hr days on special projects, but there is no reward in the end. Positions are passed out to upper managements relatives and friends over a hard working individual. The Sales managers would refer to themselves as the "boys club". There is little diversity in the sales teams.
Change is constant and not for the best. Every year account assignments and roles change. Which makes for very unhappy customers and partners. Things are left undone and everyone is great at passing work along instead of taking ownership here to get things done. With it being a large corporation simple tasks such as getting a quote back can take weeks. 
Then you have the constant fear of being laid off. Lay offs are something you get used to and expect here. Once a quarter someone or a department is cut. I have seen dedicated individuals who have been there for over 20+ years get laid off with no explanation as well as early career hires that have been employed for less than a year. No one is safe. 
There is little direction and explanation on what the plan for the company is moving forward. Management is hardly around and most managers are able to work from home remote offices. Which means leadership and direction is scarce. 
I would highly recommend looking at other companies instead of this one. At least for now till they figure out that they are doing in the long run.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: It has become an awful place to work
pros: Many good people left at the coal face, but most spend time working on their resumes and looking for other work. Many would leave and go to work for customers if they could Morale is very, very poor. Management has succeeded in destroying much of the team work and pride associated with HP EDS. But still a few good people remain.
cons:
Very poor leadership. Lack of raises and bonuses despite promises. Having HP EDS on your resume no longer works for you, rather, so many ex senior employees out in the I T world, with such bad memories of the company, it actually works against you. The entire edifice is wrong, it has seriously lost its way. It has become all about signing sales contracts, even if the company cant deliver, just get the numbers and let the teams work it out. Make sure no contracts have any worthwhile penalties and the word guarantee never shows up. Lots of weasle words.
Advice to Management
If it is possible, tear it down and start again. Perhaps rehire some of the old time management and try to regain the enthusiasm and desire to do good I T work, not just focus on squeezing money and signing contracts. Many contracts are failing because the company lied to the client, both in terms of what they could deliver and the quality of the staff.

cons:
ltant in Boston, MA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
There are some great people there; you can learn a lot in almost any discipline/area if you just ask questions. Casual work environment. Flexible schedule
Cons
WFRs are ever-present anvil hanging over everyone's heads. The reasoning behind layoffs seems scattershot; when good people are let go, it kills morale. Employees are underpaid for their position, but are left feeling grateful that they at least still have a job.
Advice to Management
The company changes direction too frequently and too rapidly.

Several years ago, the company provided for teleworking - to the mutual benefit of the company. Offices were closed and consolidated. Now, they are attempting to move everyone back into an office - but those who now have no local office to report to are left with the choice of adding 3+ hours of commute time to their work day, or finding a new company to work for.

In my group, we were encouraged to provide training and guidance to newer engineers, in order to enhance ourselves for raises and promotions. Instead, WFRs began to whittle our group down, as the engineers we helped were promoted to take our places.

pros:
Great technology and brilliant engineers, although a somewhat diminished resource over the years, has and always will be the core of HPE's strength.
Good for fresh graduates (Business Degree) looking to learn about sales and management in large multinational corporations, at least for a couple of years.
cons:
Poor management from top to bottom, aside to being very top heavy in the first place. Terrible choice of new graduates with Comp Sci or Engineering degrees, a lot of better tech companies out there today. Too many changes in personnel and strategy, each time seemingly without a clear objective in place. Every new manager or VP comes in with a short-term goal and a "slash and burn" approach. Far too many Directors and VPs who are just sitting around, playing politics to keep them around at the expense of others while waiting for their golden parachute. If you want to watch Game of Thrones, get HBO or come work for HPE!
Advice to Management
Seriously relook at the people working for you. Go back a to a technology-first, people-first company with a longer term strategy. Get rid of VPs hiring their buddies into jobs they don't know anything about. Also rethink golden parachutes, way too many people hanging around doing their bare minimum waiting for a final "reward".

pros: HPE has been a great company to work for. Great benefits.
cons:
Over the years, the company focus has been far and wide. They have been trying to hone there focus down to just the Enterprise Markets. This has entailed cut after cut with little fore thought of how to manage the employee pool. 

There has been little job security. Even great engineers are being let go.
Advice to Management
The ethics that the company demands of its employees, are NOT the same ethics shown to employees as they exit the company. Yes we have room to be a bit bitter. But you have room to improve and do the right things vs the minimum expected by state laws. You expect more than the minimum ethics from your employees. 

Bring back the HP Way... it is lost... The upper level management is no longer able to recite the rules of the garage. 

- Valuing the people 
- working together to overcome adversity

Are no longer expected.

pros: Great Benefits including; healthcare;401K and match; company car with service and gas paid by company; employer paid cell phone plan
cons:
There are so many, I am not really sure where to begin....
HPE has recently made some major business decisions to sell off parts of the company that have greatly, negatively impacted their workforce, position in the industry, and customer base. These spinoffs of divisions have eroded and eradicated a clear strategy, vision, and value proposition to customers. While its competitors are growing, HPE is becoming smaller and less competitive. 
The sale of business units have led to massive company reorganizations that result in fast changing directives; and employees and customers being jerked around. The company is not generating revenue from new streams as much as it is cutting costs to increase company and stockholder value. This cost containment has left employees and customers on the short end of the stick with little to no resources; unclear objectives; no funds for travel to customer sites outside of immediate territory; marketing funds; inability to discount solutions to compete and win; and massive amounts of turnover. Positions are left open and not backfilled, leaving large gaps within account teams. Workforce Reductions are a way of life at HPE with at least one big round for WFRs per quarter. 
Management is mostly comprised of pompous men with an overwhelming sense of self-importance who are promoted to their level of ineptitude rather than experience. Managers are not concerned for their employees and will not stand up for them as management is more concerned about covering themselves. This culture has turned management into "yes men" who carry out Meg Whitman and her executive's plans regardless of whether it is good for HPE, its customers, or its employees. 
There is a lot of posturing, changing loyalties, and politics within management. Align yourself with the wrong person and you will soon find yourself out of a job. If you are a female of child bearing age who is starting a family or has children; or are a mature employee close to retirement age, you will be targeted for public embarrassment, constant putdowns and verbal abuse by your direct manager, and termination or WFR without reason. 
This company culture has led to a disengaged workforce made of either inexperienced new hires, or employees with a lazy, "it is not my job" attitude. Customers are beyond frustrated with the ever changing account teams, fragmented solutions, and constant change of HPE's state of business.
Advice to Management
Really take a look at who is leading this company and the role the Board desires HPE to play in the industry. Do these two things match up? In my opinion, they do not. 
In today's volatile Technology industry, treatment of women and mature employees in the workplace is under a spotlight. For a company led by a woman who preaches inclusion, the actions of HPE towards females and mature employees sure is suspect.

pros: Some of the best coworkers I have ever been around. They are talented, outgoing, and have a desperate desire to be led and coached.
cons:
Upper Management treats you like school children. You get pop-quizzes, and they are always looking for "gotcha" moment. You can be a strong leader, top of the always changing leaderboard, but you walk down to the cafe to get a drink you will be asked condescending questions about how productive you are being. The Directors and Up do not have a desire to understand your book of business. They look at each account set as equal, but that is just not the truth. They have no personal skills to even greet you, yet the assume they know your daily struggles within your account set and will set the arbitrary leaderboard based off this. Zero desire to help you progress or improve your career. You are a warm body to them. Just a number. 

They are bogged down by slow processes. The VP verbally dresses down his Managers and threatens to fire them over insignificant things. It is a unnecessarily stressful job, that makes you constantly worried about your job security. This is a top down issue in the Inside Sales Organization. There is no voice of strong leadership.

The simple fact that we cannot get paid correctly is frustrating enough. But when Management sends an email about dress code, but cannot even give you a quick email saying "Team your commission is top of mind, we will get this fixed" it gives you a terrible feeling of where the priorities lie. Again, you are a warm body. They do not care about you, your career, or basic human interaction that lets you know they remotely care about you as an employee. 

It is a entry level job. Understand that. Use it to build your resume, but understand you will need to network outside of HPE in order to move up. There are few examples (2) of Reps moving up and out to field sales in my time there. In the last 3 months, 15 people have left HPE because of the lack of opportunity and investment.
Advice to Management
Exercise basic level of human interaction. Say hello. Say "I appreciate how hard you are working, and I know you are covering for people who have left so I appreciate you going above and beyond" 

Treat your employees like Adults. You might be a parent, but you are not our parent, or a babysitter. If you feel you need to babysit- hire better people. 

Find a mission, stick to the mission, and move forward. 

Reward good employees. Recognize them. Coach employees who need it.

ltant in Baltimore, MD
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Now a smaller company with less than 30,000 employees (down from 300,000 employees in 2014). They also don't let you visit customers without a minimum 3 week lead time/advanced approval and enforcing that all employees use Skype to meet with and to sell/design complex solutions to their customers. Also, no need to worry about cloud experience as everything they sell is all about hardware on-premise. Work is almost 100% remote which means you can stay home 99% of the time.
Cons
You may not have a job with all the downsizing taking place the rest of the year. Also, no real upside for exceeding quotas since they are set quotas extremely high for sales. It will be tough to compete with companies without travel restrictions. They also pay less than all their competitors but that is understandable since you will be working mostly from your Webcam at home.

review_title: Legacy company desperately trying to cut their way to growth
pros:
Big Brand and good products.
Endless Certification training and business conduct training.
Dozens of passwords to login to all the different tools and systems which can't talk to each other.
cons:
Struggling with slow bureaucracy, outdated systems and heavy policies. They make up for this by cutting their way to growth and eliminating perks, reducing benefits to drive away talent. I've never felt so much like a cog in a wheel going nowhere. In order to make me feel valued I got to hear a recording of Meg Whitman telling us how critical the employees are to the success. When I ask why things are so confusing and broken the HPE veterans tell me this is the HPE way.
Advice to Management
Hire an IT company to fix the internal maze of IT systems. The HP way of innovation apparently died decades ago ... it's not a privilege to work at HPE - people with options continue to walk across the street and customers continue to buy superior technology from others. Sub par benefits don't make up for the bad work environment.

pros:
good career opportunities
decent salary 
flexible working schedule
excellent team spirit and collaboration 
medical coverage
cons:
lots of bureaucracy 
slow to adapt to market's needs
inefficient C-levels - selling everything will not turn around the boat
salary not aligned to industry/experience/performance 
inefficient and stupid HR policies - off cyclesare rare and have hidden rules
managers who just manage people but don't want to understand what their teams are doing or what the company is doing have no room in a business environment, you are just encouraging laziness
Advice to Management
- processes are useful when they serve a purpose and they work efficiently, rarely happens in HPE
- in some areas of the business it feels like contractors/3rd parties drive the business and the your employees have little to no influence
- for god's sake hire some managers who actually think and are good leaders!
- listen to your own employees, don't dismiss their opinions just because they don't have your visibility and/or experience, you might even learn something useful from them
- in business reviews with higher management show what works but also what doesn't and actually put some effort to fix those gaps, they are not going away if you ignore them - sometimes same issues persist for more than 5+years and WW/HQ just ignore them

pros: - You work with fantastic, inspiring people. I have gotten a lot of support and help from both my manager and mentor.
cons:
- Pay is horrible. I could almost double my pay going somewhere else.
- There is no culture. This is not the old HP anymore.
- Constant cost cutting measures being put in place, including ones that end up wasting employee's time, such as not having sufficient resources, or not replacing 4 year old laptops.
- Work life balance is horrible. 50-60 hours a week is not uncommon. Managers will not bat an eye if you are spending 70+ hours a week for months on end.
Advice to Management
Focus on the employees. Figure out where to be adding resources, whether it be more compute nodes in labs, or updating employee laptops with solid state drives, etc. There is a lot of time wasted trying to bypass these issues, and it is hurting growth much more that the cost cutting is saving.

alot of people and talent leaving company.

CEO webcast seem to be repeated, no actual positives from the CEO or HR leaders. Employees seem to be forgotten, in regards of incentives, we are asked to do more with less, and other companies are taking talent away. pros: For me, work life balance and training were the pros. Also working around a group of very smart individuals.
cons:
No raises (unless you're your manager's favorite or you're a manager). Barely removed from the bottom of the barrel when it comes to receiving a bonus. 

The company has a culture of the "good ole boy system" which clearly gives favoritism to its members. If you're in, you're good, if you're not, be prepared to fight to receive something near the fair line or be prepared to leave. The employees (especially managers) portrayed themselves as if their race is superior to all others (within the company and to customers).

Benefits are decreasing, a lot. The company is trying to save itself from going under, so they're squeezing everything they can out of the employees to meet numbers for board members and investors.
Advice to Management
Stop trying to use up your best and most valuable employees without compensating them or providing a means to show how much you value them and their work. 

Stop wandering and trying to find yourself (re-brand)! Find better mid-level management and a new top executive to lead the company.

Get rid of the culture that illustrates that one race of US citizens is superior to all others.

review_title: Your Generic Corporate Environment, that isn't doing well
pros:
- Pay is decent (definitely better out there though).
- Despite spin-offs and splits with HPI/HPE/DXC/MF, company stays relatively the same as far as work goes.
-Work Life balance is pretty good being corporate, rarely need to work beyond 8 hours/day.
cons:
-Layoffs everywhere due to bad management and unknown direction. They always talk about how great their products are and how the next step will be taken, but all I see is failure, uncertainty, and politics.
- Raises? No raises, rarely any bonuses. Almost 3 years has yielded about <3% raise, and <4% bonus, doesn't even keep up with COL.
-Mobility for younger employees is pretty tough. Every time a position opens up, whether laterally or to management, it is either filled externally or with a friend of the Director or colleague. Politics play way too much of a factor here.
- If you're in a department that doesn't generate money (aka anything but sales/marketing) it's tough to get any expenses approved and takes forever.
Advice to Management
Everything. Seriously. Employee Morale is super low. I talk to many employees on a daily basis and everyone either fears for their jobs, colleagues jobs, or just plain don't know where the company is headed to. There's practically no perk in working for HPE.

review_title: Execute your Plan B now if you're a current employee/Don't join this sinking ship
pros: Once upon a time, I could've given you a whole list. No longer the case. Insurance and benefits are OK, not what they once were. For a 401K essentially has no matching any longer. Very meager amount is added at the end of the year if you are still employed on 12/31.
cons:
Where to begin? The company doesn't seem to know where it's headed. Many divestitures, numerous small company acquisitions. Senior management makes decisions to appease the stock market pricing with no apparent long-term vision. This means massive layoffs of skilled, seasoned workers in favor of hiring early career, offshoring jobs and H1B visas. The internal climate is currently very demoralized. Massive layoffs are currently occurring, and employees learn their colleagues have been laid off when they are no longer accessible in the system.
Advice to Management
Don't talk about giving yourself bonuses during the all employee call where you advise you're executing a plan for massive cost-cutting and WFR's to decrease $200 to 300M in second half

review_title: If you want to sell security solutions, this is not the place
pros: Benefits, technical presales team is solid
cons:
Sales pipeline, lack of focus, sloppy execution, not customer-focused enough, tons of red tape, slow to innovate, took an otherwise great solution and drove it into the ground.
Advice to Management
Take responsibility for the internal changes that have impacted sales performance (taking away rockstar inside sales reps, replacing them with a digital sales team with little experience, taking all of the growth accounts away from the seasoned field reps, instituting a policy that requires all customer facing travel to be approved - even hotel stays with no flights). You can't sell enterprise security solutions over the phone. Focus on the customers as much as you focus on primping your financials for the merge with Microfocus, and maybe you'll be successful.

review_title: Be happy to have a job?
cons:
dered the leader in the industry; Great to have your resume!
Cons
In the last few years, since the split with HP, the company has taken a downward turn in taking care of it's employees:
- lack of work life balance
- little to no annual bonus (except for the C-Suite)
- little to no salary increase
- The general philosophy is "be happy you have a job" because there have been tremendous job cuts, and many many more to come.
- Also, little to no promotion opportunity, unless you know how to suck-up.
Advice to Management
Overall employee moral is quiet low. Restructure your thought process and make it all about the employees, and watch how hard / how creatively your employees will begin to work, and thus resulting in increasing revenues / cutting costs.

pros: Relatively stable place to work until they are layoffs, they will fire older workers because they are too expensive and focus is on the bottom line, always.
cons:
Last three years had 1% raises. You do not get rewarded for long term employment. Promotions, raises, and bonuses are not granted because there is no budget to invest in existing employees, only to make hasty acquisitions that rarely work out, plus most acquirees figure out the long term career potential is nil and move on, leaving young'uns to be assigned to the new new thing while firing all the seasoned engineers that could have helped integrate the project into HPE, with greater insight and knowledge.
Advice to Management
Stop firing seasoned talent. Honor the HP way, respect employees for their potential. Go back to Bill and Dave's original model, where the business units wer. e autonomous and controlled their own destiny. Employess in acquired companies quickly realize they are only providing revenue to the company cash account for future acquisitions with no reward for the employees that made the business success for their formerly independent unit possible. Once their sales staff and development strategy is morphed into HPE, the product wallows and eventually is discarded in favor of something else.

pros: The team I worked with was really solid. All the way up through to my manager's manager's manager.
cons:
The organization at large seems to suffer from some disorganization, as well as from a bit of the echo chamber effect. Luscious fruit dies on the vine, if not properly cultivated; don't be surprised when you come back months later, wondering why the fruit is all dried up.
Advice to Management
When acquiring promising companies, try to actually invest in them, rather than squeezing the talent out and trying to profit from the rinds. 

Not every product (very few, I imagine) can be outsourced to offshore organizations where the average offshored engineer's go-to move is not to actually think and solve, but rather to simply pass the buck back to the original (now much smaller) team. 

The result is that the original team succumbs to the weight of not only trying to support the product, but to also support the outsourced organization which, given how their own employees get moved around, contributes to the erosion of knowledge and experience, furthering the decline of the customer experience. 

TL;DR A paper tiger isn't a terribly useful support model.

pros: Great, talented people to work with and has decent but not exceptional benefits. Competitive pay and good work/life balance. HPE is good at providing the hardware needed to do the work.
cons:
HPE is a hire & fire company so don't expect a long term career here. Upper management focus is on short term stock price only. Layoffs are frequent and management's vision for the future is still very unclear. There is lots of lip service but little action and they change their minds frequently. Many good people are jumping ship because of the frequent layoffs and uncertainty caused by management's pinball decision making.
Advice to Management
Stop being reactive and focusing so much on short term profitability. Give the analysts a vision they can get excited about and make an effort to retain your people so you can execute that vision. The stock price will take care of itself when you're doing the right thing.

pros: Great vacation offerings, holidays off, and Brand recognition
cons:
Cumbersome sales comp system, lowest pay in the industry, complex processes, constant change in processes, high turnover, and low morale. The metrics are useless and don't contribute to revenue growth and pay. There are people that are top on the leaderboard but getting paid the lowest. There is a new process every week and it gets changed again the follow-up week. You hear employees complaining everyday about how they are looking for another job and want to quit.
Advice to Management
Stop treating your employees terribly. This is forcing everyone to hate it and quit. Also keep the dress code consistent and not change it every week. Set clear expectations for everyone and align them to revenue growth and quota attainment. This is not a "true" sales environment if reps are doing work to hit metrics instead of hit quota. Make the call center fun so that everyone wants to get up and come the work instead of complaining about it everyday decreasing morale.

review_title: HPE Software Israel is a great company to work for, managing change gracefully
pros:
Working at HPE in Yehud is often a pleasure. Terrific benefits, great teams to work with, a caring and supportive work environment that values recognition and compensation. 
They are currently going through a great deal of change with the MicroFocus spin-merge coming up. My feeling is that management is handling the change as gracefully as possible. The message at the moment is that anything might happen, the way forward isn't entirely clear, but hey - we can handle it and we're going to as best we can. There's a lot of patience required at the moment until the company settles down again in its new form.
cons:
There's a lot of change, not a lot of stability. Priorities change at the drop of the hat, and sometimes U-turn. There's a lot of wait and see right now.
Advice to Management
Keep listening to the teams. Provide space for creative expression.

review_title: Too many changes, Too many managers, No clear mission.
pros:
- There are no such thing as sick days, so you can take as many sick days as you need. The downside is that many people abuse this policy without repercussions. 
-Flexible schedules if you need to take care of a personal appointment.
cons:
- Rotational opportunities are advertised but rarely ever given because we are constantly doing more with less people, however management will tell you, you are responsible for your own career

- You are not compensated for accomplishments, you are compensated largely for the number of years you have been working at HPE. In many cases, you have very low level employees doing high level work but are told they need more time and experience

- Consistently declining revenues are forcing management to cut any where they can

- There are no opportunities for travel unless you are a mid-level manager, 

- 401K contribution matching was decreased from first 4% of salary paid out quarterly, to 50% of first 3% of salary, paid out yearly at the end of year. You must be employed on 12/31 to get the matching. Of course, in recent years, major layoffs occur around Thanksgiving 

- Focusing heavily on the contractor model

-Recently an email was sent to employees asking for donations to lobby Washington to prevent import taxes from products manufactured in Mexico. Of course, the Trump election threw a curve-ball in their plans to off shore more jobs to Mexico. What was insidious however, was her ask from the employees she was going to lay off, for money to lobby Washington to send their jobs oversees

- Pay and Bonus structure significantly lower compared to the market

review_title: Just don't plan on a career
pros: I worked with some great co-workers
cons:
After 17 years of hard work... about to turn 60 y.o.... and became a statistic of the latest work force reduction. So much for career. And....had to train the person who was taking my job (offshore) for 3 months or I wouldn't receive my severance. This is not the way to treat good, loyal employees that got the company to what it once was. Now...morale is horrible, workload for those still there is ridiculous, and still talks of more layoffs.
Advice to Management
I watched some of your top talent either go out the door during work force reductions or run out as soon as they got another opportunity. Better stop the bleeding before your knowledgebase is totally gone. You are causing total burnout for the ones left. I was on one of the largest accounts that HPE has....and the people left on the team now are just getting the bare minimum done. That's going to catch you sooner or later... and the client won't be happy.

pros: The people at HPE were great to work with, dedicated and friendly. Through 2015 work schedules were very flexible and working from home was no problem.
cons:
Too much process. When the organization decided to switch from waterfall to agile, they used the agile tools and GitHub to gather statistics with which they rated engineers. I don't know which was worse: waterfall with no detailed statistics, or agile with too many numbers. IT processes were constantly a bottle-neck to development.

Starting in 2016 Meg Whitman started the "Back to work at HPE" program where work-from-home was no longer an option. Unfortunately, it seemed to be US-only. I saw no effects in other countries.

The constant split/spin-merge disrupted productivity. We had good engineers working on that rather than on products that would make the company money.
Advice to Management
Reduce process; re-empower the engineers; stop the constant reorganization; treat the employees as the skilled individuals that they are, not fungible resources.

review_title: HPE has been lost and can't find it's way
pros: Decent benefits package with medical, dental, vision, 401k but the prices have been creeping up and limitation added to limit payouts.
cons:
Seem to be bi-polar. First, work from home is okay then they change their mind and tell everyone they need to come in. Remote workers were first to get laid off if they would not move to a main campus. Old workers are being given involuntary retirement to bring in college kids who will work for much less. Most development work is now in Taiwan, China or India, even the Program Manager jobs.
Advice to Management
Dell went private and is doing very well because they can focus on the work at h and and are not obsessed with Wall Street opinions. HPE was given a pass from Wall Street in that Meg stated that the HPE transformation would take time, but it's never really happened. Also, stop trying to fix your problems by buying other companies and then shuttering the people and technology. You are just wasting money.

Due to constant internal reorganizations, mergers and spin-offs no sense of stability and ever-changing processes to keep up with.
Ongoing lay-offs (since years) impacting employee morale.
Advice to Management

pros: Vast types of opportunities. Some of the lowest attrition rates in certain divisions. Most divisions have great work life balance.
cons:
Some divisions have poor growth due to low attrition in upper grades. The Internal Job change procedure requires one to NOTIFY existing manager even before applying for an internal job. This is beyond ridiculous, especially when a large majority of positions are posted on the tool only for procedural purposes after filling the vacancy. 

As I said, your mileage will vary. Due to absence of uniform management oversight, some divisions are terrible to work for. 

Risk of future business downturns. They are in severely legacy businesses, all growth comes from inorganic acquisitions.
Advice to Management
Change the Internal Job change (IJP) procedure, you will immediately see the best talent move to the best divisions. Then you can take to task the divisions where most people are leaving.

review_title: Changes, Changes, Everywhere! (And THAT'S a good thing!)
pros: Here are my three favorite things about working at HPE. The people: I have a great manager and incredible team mates. The work: My work is recognized and I am encouraged to find new and better ways to do things. The community-mindedness: I LOVE that HPE gives employees opportunities to volunteer, promotes volunteerism (with 6 days of paid leave per year for volunteering!), and allows employees to decide where foundation funds will be spent through Kiva.
cons:
The culture: We are at a strange place in the evolution of HPE. With the tremendous changes over the past few years we seem to have lost our focus from an organizational culture. I think that is starting to change and I'm looking forward to seeing how we really make "Partner/Innovate/Act" come to life both internally and externally.
Advice to Management
Keep doing what you are doing. As we focus on a return to growth, continue to invest in and improve manager capabilities and skills to manage the entire performance continuum--from moving low performers out to motivating top performers to stay.

review_title: You will probably accept a job here, and then come to agree with the following.
pros: great benefits, 401k match, vacation/pto, flexibility and trusting management depending on your org. Promotional opportunities are abundant if you battle through the uncertainty, monotony and keep your head down, if you can make it through the constant hiring freezes/payroll freezes, or timeline requirements of your current role.
cons:
No direction or clarity, frequent layoffs and leaders are never able to discuss the future with confidence. 
Extremely stressful, partially due to lack of training and direction. HPE talks the talk but epically fails to walk the walk. 
I will leave in a heartbeat if I could find a better paying job in my area.
Advice to Management
A lot to be thankful for here, in terms of experience on paper, but it is somehow boring yet extremely stressful. Improve training programs, encourage workers to care about what they support. Hold management accountable for training and supporting their teams. Hold workers accountable for supporting their areas.

review_title: The fall of a great company
pros:
Great company history
A lot of investment in internal positive marketing to employees
Strategic acquisitions to boost portfolio of offerings
Many openings for early career hires
cons:
Age discrimination class action suit currently in play
Laying off and spinning off long tenured employees in divestitures
Primarily hiring in low-cost locations
Management has lost its sense of ethics and historical values
"Trust and respect for the individual" (Bill and Dave's core value) is dead
Advice to Management
Start treating experienced, long tenured, loyal employees with more dignity.
After many years of service, many were, and will be spun off in mergers, and then laid-off within weeks of joining the new company. In the case of the DXC merger, 30 years with HP nets 8 weeks of severance. One of those 8 weeks includes your last week of work. This move was planned in advance to reduce the cost of the workforce and save HPE severance payments. It is unconscionable. If management is committed to treating its employees with a lack of transparency and respect, the same treatment of its customers can't be far behind.

pros:
I was part of an acquisition 7 years ago and I have seen excellent growth in the security market and HPE became an authority in cyber security with multiple acquisitions. HPE allowed their M&As to continue to operate like an autonomous, small company during their transition.
- Competitive salary and benefits
- On the job training and industry certification
- 90% of sales team are teleworkers
- Great leadership team
cons:
My portion of the company will be spin-merged with Micro Focus this year and our Enterprise Services team have already spun off to CSC. Anticipate a lot of change and more lay-offs.
- Due to M&A activity, internal communication is scarce with many unanswered questions regarding strategy, operations, migration and future state.
- Numerous rounds of work force reduction has impacted overall morale and requires us to do more with less.
- Senior leadership entirely focused on earnings to satisfy mergers.
Advice to Management
Handle the M&A delicately and communicate the impact to encourage the innovation and loyalty from existing team members and avoid losing top talent. I've witnessed what happens to products when key stakeholders leave the company.
