review_title: Lowsey Comp for years and now the benefits match it
pros: Better than being unemployed I guess
cons:
I don't know if it's the merger or what but literally I can't pay my bills due to the Ins alone this year. I went from a $650?deductible with average benefits that was costing me about 7k/yr personally. To nothing but worst case scenario options this year. I don't say this out of ignorance either, having worked in healthcare for more than 40 years I feel I can state this with the knowledge required to make such an assessment. There were a few great options on our "marketplace" this year, but literally they cost (employee portion) more than I make (well I would be left with under 10k/yr not counting taxes) after paying my portion of my healthcare for those great plans. There's no major illness in my family (1 person is a diabetic which is controlled with medication and that person sees the dr MAYBE 3 times a yr). The other plans were all awful. This yr we have a $2,600 deduc/per person and it is costing just under 20k/yr (that's inclusive of the $5k I'm putting in my HRA-for those that don't know- this isn't the same as an FSA where all that money is put into you account on Jan 1, it's added to that account per check. So day 1 you will have access to $0 (until it clears their account after being paid, which takes a few days and in my situation that's approx $204ish twice a month). So if something major happens before the middle of the year you will probably be paying out of your own pocket your huge deduct as you won't have the money accumulated yet in your account). Not to mention the mail order scripts for my Aetna plan this year is OUTRAGIOUS. Typically we will get scripts that way because it's much cheaper. With our new plan it's literally (for a couple of scripts that a member of my family takes) 3 times MORE expensive then you typical Walgreens/CVS/RiteAid. Now I know some ppl will think that this type of situation is based o the ins comp, and while they would be correct, what isn't often understood is an employer can pick and choose and basically build different plan options for their employees (which will effect the cost of said Ins). What is typically used by patients (mail order pharmacy from their insurance carrier pharmacy carrier) isn't even an option for Aetna. Just google it and you will see whet I mean.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the ppl who care about only themselves and not the company (now DXC). Harvard and Princeton mean nothing if that person doesn't care about the longevity and success of the business but only how their personal account grows. Maybe that's why Meg isn't the CEO of the new merger, but even being on the board is bad. Meg became CEO of HP and did not perform, then CEO of HPE and again didn't perform (not to mention the general concensus by those employees under her agree she's terrible -this line of work Isn't eBay or Disney Meg, just don't allow her to take down DXC too.

pros:
Prior to the merge with CSC, HPE had great health insurance benefits. Since the merge, I am still waiting to see the aftermath of the merger. I've been an employee with EDS, then known as HP, then known as HPE, and now known as DXC Technology for 9 years. 
I do have one good thing to share - I have to say, on my account, the work-life balance is better than average.
cons:
Pay is not comparable with other IT companies. Other IT companies offer bonuses from 8-17%; we rarely receive bonuses and if received, they are extremely low. Overall company hasn't received a raise in 3 years. Continuous threats of Workforce Reductions. We are lacking resources and although we escalate to management; no help received.
Advice to Management
There are many employees who are extremely dedicated; however, they are still treated like numbers. My advice is to senior management - a little acknowledgement goes a long way.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: You can gain experience with a wide variety of customers, solutions and technologies. HPE is an innovative technology leader. Generally good compensation and benefits. Many creative and hard-working people.
cons:
Cumbersome processes. Talk about employee support, training and mentoring, but little application or follow up. Greater focus on numbers than people. Lack of middle management engagement. Difficult and time-consuming systems and processes as a result of several mergers and spin-offs.
Advice to Management
Provide better support to valuable employees, including mentoring and training. Gain firsthand knowledge/experience on the systems and processes being mandated. Ensure separation of responsibilities (i.e. A customer or delivery PM should not have to spend significant time on Procurement, Payment, Legal and Finance activities). Enable access to the right people for vendor invoicing and payments (not just support tickets, which are prematurely closed).

review_title: Graduate program is false advertised, no company culture
pros:
Big company name great for resume 
People with sound knowledge
Meeting some lovely people in work 

Great learning experience about the opposite end of a good and positive work place.
cons:
Absolutely no work culture. The company does not treat employees and reward. Do not expect events, treats etc. They're all about keeping costs low, getting people productive constantly. Thus, treating employees as a number and people who need to be used frequently. 

People will get laid off frequently and be replaced with younger people as grads.

The graduate program is advertised with rotations and this does not happen at all. It is unstructured and you only find out through previous graduates you must network to find your own opportunity or anything available. The jobs are scarce. 

HR management is not up to standards like other big companies taking care of their employees concerns.

As a graduate you will do a lot of menial tasks which do not reflect what the job description is or what they tell you from day one.

There is barely any raises or bonuses. A lot of employees complain about their input and pay. It appears the organisation is not in its best time or simply greedy on wages. 

Being present for long hours is seen as very important. They want you to do typical hours and will not be happy if you want to manage your own time. If you finish your assigned work, you're expected to stay still and told to look busy. Do not expect a flexible career here.

Working from home is treated as a joke and hard to ask for. 

Some people will not share knowledge to you because they're concerned about their jobs.

Explaining suggestions to colleagues as a young person is not taken seriously. Expect the "matured age" effect.

Expect within teams there is competition and lack of trust.

Leaders and managers lack EQ. Expect rudeness and only concerns of deliverables.

Leaders and managers are not concerned about your passions and what gets you motivated.
Advice to Management
Figure it out.

pros: Great starting point for young individuals looking to open doors in the technology space.
cons:
HPE is a great environment for early employment individuals. Senior professionals should look elsewhere. The company does not promote individual thoughts, vision or innovation in the sales organization. The senior leadership seems to want robots to carry out orders without question or individual thought processes. Team is an excellent concept until you limit individual input and ideas. Furthermore, the leadership is making decisions in a vacuum that affect customers, partners and employees negatively without any input. The latest of many reorgs was a huge mistake and HPE will feel the carnage of those decisions for years to come. Most of the partners are looking on an exit strategy because HPE has not been consistent with direction or deliverables.
Advice to Management
Find high level leaders that understand the market and can align resources to address customer, partner and employee needs while also meeting corporate objectives. Most importantly, stick to the plan for more than 2 years. Everyone is tired of the constant changes.

Leaders are more defined as managers who are not very proactive in assisting the team for the better cause. Health care cost increases are passed onto employees. Benefits coverage have gotten worse over the years. Selective rules/treatment for co workers. Not to sound nit picky but to be noted-the building besides the Lobby/bathrooms are very dirty and rundown appearing on the inside.

Learn how to be more of a leader and less of a manager. Fight more for your team.

review_title: Great work/life balance. Used to be leading edge, but not anymore
pros: There is a good work-life balance. You almost don't have to work overtime at all if you don't want to - that probably makes up for the low salaries. For fresh college graduates, HPE also has a good policy converting interns to full-time employees if they do well. 401K matching and holiday leave (15 days for up to 5 years of employment) is reasonable.
cons:
HP used to be a leading company attracting top talent, but not anymore. Salaries do not match other companies looking for the same candidates, and there are few interesting projects, so the company isn't able to attract good people. Mediocre people leads to canceled or delayed projects and not being able to keep up with the competition. Leadership is also poor - company politics is rife with those talking loudest getting the most credit, rather than people who really do the wok.
Advice to Management
Don't just blindly focus on delivery dates without knowing what is really being delivered - know your employees and understand what it takes to get products delivered too!

pros: HPE has great technology. The technology is robust. HPE has a great beta program so that when the product is released, the product is excellent. HPE's marketing department provides strong assistance in the selling life cycle. The sales training enables a trusted adviser sales role for sales representatives. The sales technical support is excellent. Easy sale.
cons:
The downturn in the economy was a reality when I left. I was offered the opportunity to relocate and that was thoughtful but I like the weather in California.
Advice to Management
My advise is to keep the good work environment. Keep the marketing department support, keep the employee training, and work on Channel sales. Channel sales needs more attention. They need more touch and support. More touch, I mean, Channel sales reps need contact often, weekly, to brainstorm strategies to move sales cycle along. As well as Channel training and forecast update conversations. Channels needs an HPE sales rep to go onsite with them to customer presentations. The Channels needs responsiveness and support.

review_title: Good place to work for some folks (including me)
pros: HPE engineering treats people with respect and offers opportunities to work on cutting edge technologies. The benefits are in line with the rest of the industry, and there is a reasonable amount of flexibility in working arrangements (work at home some days, no strict working hours).
cons:
HPE is unfortunately in a business (hardware infrastructure) that is rapidly being replaced by cloud providers (AWS, Azure) who build their own hardware and data center management software. It's going to be a serious challenge to overcome these trends in the long run.
Advice to Management
Stop buying companies for a high price and either running them into the ground or selling them for much less than you paid. Run the company you have rather than trying to acquire companies you don't. I can't think of a single acquisition that worked out well (Palm, 3Com, Tipping point, etc.)

pros:
Flexible times, understanding about kids or personal issues, mostly hands-off management, good for somebody who can work through and around the bureaucracy of a large enterprise and be self-motivated.
Good women representation, lots of women in management.
Ever-changing company, lots of opportunity to be exposed to different jobs and groups. You can speak up about moving to different orgs and learning new areas.
cons:
So much change that raises tend to take a long time as they put in freezes while getting through a large company change, and often fairly low.
Bureaucracy of a large enterprise, while trying to change and transform at the rate of a small company.
Advice to Management
Fight for your good employees so you don't lose them to a faster-paced young company with flashy benefits like dogs at work and free meals.

review_title: Too much turmoil and chaos in managing direction of companies before and after being split.
pros: Ever changing and evolving product offerings.
cons:
The management cannot keep up with the ever changing directions of the offerings or how they are going to execute them. Laying off experienced older employees and losing core talent and experience at an alarming rate. The product offerings are suffering due to all the upheaval and direction changes. Emphasis is placed on speed to market and not as much as value to market. More recalls and problems with products.
Advice to Management
Streamline and define product selection and cut down diversifying into too many areas of product offerings. Value and reliability in a set core offering would help stabilize the companies on both sides. More uniform processes and go to market values need to be brought back to the core of the company process. In my opinion it is better to offer a select number of excellent products as opposed to offering an over abundance of mediocre ones. The value gets lost in the chaos.

pros: Well-established supply chain network,
cons:
ructive work environment, Standard working hours, Decent benefits/coverage, Fast-paced industry, Healthy company culture, Many career paths, Focus on industry and skills training
Cons
Disjointed MRP tools and reports, major delays in launch schedules are normal; not exceptions, Tendency towards working in departmental silos, Too much corporate restructuring, Supply planners are responsible for many goals and metrics but not the owners of a process/task/relationship, Can be difficult to find upward mobility.
Advice to Management
Keep investing in human capital even when quarterly or yearly revenue is down. When more people leave the team or company, the bigger the burden becomes for employees who stay. If management doesn't hire on new talent when teams are already understaffed, it makes the probability of more attrition even greater.

review_title: Great company to work for, but with a few big company problems
pros: I loved working with smart, talented people dedicated to building awesome products and services. Good work/life balance.
cons:
Management tended to listen to development over test. Also the development team that we worked with would repeatedly over promise and under deliver. The first few times this happened, I thought that these were just growing pains of switching to Agile. But as time went on, all of our concerns brought forward by our group about unrealistic expectations created by the development org were actively not listened to.
Advice to Management
Listen to your test organization, and failing that, if a group repeatedly demonstrates that they can over promise and under deliver, you should expect that next time they will do exactly that. So stop letting them set themselves up for failure.

review_title: Awful, awful company that regards employees as an inconvenient overhead. Avoid !
cons:
ltant in London, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
None. Seriously - I cannot think of one advantage (ignoring the folks I worked with - who have since all left). You can't travel to meet clients, there are no team events (because that would involve travel) no training and no work.
Cons
Almost too many to list. The worst work 'culture' I have ever seen. Senior execs are only interested in their bonuses. Meg Whitman is just intent on selling off parts of the company to whoever will give her the cash - to the point where there is no value left. And ok they're 'merging' HPE ES with CSC - and
Keeping *neither* brand. That speaks volumes. 

I read a review before I joined that referred to management as 'awful, awful people'. At the time I ignored that comment - I wish I'd heeded it. 

This company (and DXC) is circling the plug hole. They are relying on their company reputation from 20 years ago. Do yourself a favour and just look elsewhere.
Advice to Management
No point in typing anything here - they won't read it or act on it if they did !

cons:
I saw more WFRs than I can stand and I'm glad to be leaving. The jobs of good talented workers, even those that are top performance ranked, are flowing to India quarter over quarter throughout the organization. I'd encourage you to Google it; Meg announced the company would be increasing offshored workers to 60+% over a year ago. I wish I could say this is because there is a talent pool that US workers can't compete with but the truth is that, in my experience, they are just cheaper and lack the appropriate skillset that was present in the folks they just laid off. In the end, your skillset doesn't matter and your dedication and performance doesn't matter. Middle management will keep playing shell games and reorganizing quarterly so they are not held responsible for their bad decisions. Promotions/rewards are for the friends of management chain, regardless of appropriateness of skillset and performance, so don't chase carrots you are never going to get. My advise, in particular for new college hires, is to go elsewhere! The corporate values and culture exist on paper only. Over time, benefits have become more and more costly and coverage has declined to the point that most companies can provide the same. As for raises, expect around 3%, if any; generally less than the cost of living is increasing; yes, even when corporate profit targets are met.
Advice to Management
Focus on quality and the profits will come. Realize that your well trained employees are going to work for your competition and your customers will see all your dirty laundry in the poor quality of your products, then act accordingly. It won't take long for bad decisions to damage the brand and it will be far more expensive in the long run.

review_title: Treading the well-worn path to bankruptcy
pros:
Many really good people at the operational level.
A few managers who properly recognise the efforts of the many.
cons:
Appalling absence of meaningful leadership.
Abject failure to grow revenues.
Brutal and ongoing cuts, now severely impacting client-facing areas.
Merger with CSC anticipated with a feeling of impending doom. (I don't see how welding two shrinking, dinosaur companies can yied anything but more rapid failure.
Advice to Management
Take some responsibility for your failures. How can you be so "excited" about everything that you announce when all you have achieved is to have broken this once amazing company.
Hand over your responsibilities to someone who can make the necessary changes (and I don't mean constant rounds of debilitating redundancies alone). Talk about "one trick ponies".
Instead of going from 8 layers of management to 6 why not be a little more savage here...say 4 (or less). How much cost do these clowns generate? Your inertia as far as generating new sales and assisting delivery is astounding. You are mighty fine at workforce management because that's been your only area of focus really.
Your processes suck. What happened to agile/nimble? Jargon Busters? Simply more cost down the drain.
Why can't you trust your managers. No-one can make a financial decision without going to European regional heads of sheds for approvals. You have a pathetic lack of trust in good people.
Have a look at how you might manage to build morale because it seems to me that the company is on a death spiral and the merger will aggravate it further. Your people are broken. Almost everyone I know is looking to escape and their inertia is the only thing keeping them with HPE. Not sure how you will alter that...
Good luck. You absolutely need it.

review_title: I thought HP has a good work life balance until i get into support team. Not all teams in HP is the same. Read on
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Good starting salary for fresh grad, high night differential pay, not strict in time-in. Can swap shift with teammates if needed, can work from home if needed
Cons
Workload is not proportional to the salary. Don't ever work in a support environment, especially if it is a 24 by 7 support team. You'll lose your life. no career growth. More and more customer demands added to your workload but no salary increase! No overtime pay as well. 

And the annual increase gets delayed for 6months??! Wth. That's half a year! What kind of management is that? You only get a bonus of around your food allowance for half a month. Not beneficial. No xmas gifts, no freebies for employees. Salary and night differential pay is the only thing that can keep you going here 

And what happened to your certification programs?? What i get from employment is just a couple of training. While those other people who has very light workload, they have already been certified, when in fact you were the one who needs it the most. Cost cutting at its finest.
NO WORK LIFE BALANCE -leaves are hardly approved even if it is filed within the lead time.
You cannot go to company events or activities because you cannot leave your work!
FOR APPLICANTS, DO NOT APPLY IN A 24 BY 7 SUPPORT TEAM IN HP. please check first the workload and what you will be doing before you say yes to the offer.
Advice to Management
Your managers should be sensitive to the needs of their people. You cannot just throw more and more work but no perks or additional pay coming! Also, you cannot just delay the increase and expect people to just say yes! Please check why attrition is high at a certain team. Some teams in HP even do nothing yet they get paid the same.with the team who almost do everything! You must do something to compensate your employees if the customer cannot finance addition workforce, otherwise you'll just lose people one by one.

pros:
1. Great vacation
2. They have good ethical training
cons:
1. Team Leads are non-technical. They know 0% of whats in code. LOE are done senior technical.
2. No moderate bonuses. More than 95% will get 0.7% bonus i.e. few hundred dollars. Only those who have very good repo with clients will get moderate bonus of 2-3k.
3. The environment is not the one that gives challenges to employees. They would reserve it to few, for e.g. architects.
4. Freedom of thought: The management would most likely kill your idea, even before it starts.
5. Transperancy: There is little information provided by management of whats going on.
6. Training/Cost re-imbursement: They would have contract worth millions. But, wont re-imburse even $150 on attained certificate, which is relevant to the job. So that, you dont have motivation to grow.
7. Career Oppurtunities are non-existent. If you are developer, you will retire as a developer. Period. There is absolutely 0% promotion in technical fields
Advice to Management
More technical people with Project Management certificates should be given chance rather than non-technical ones. You have boat load of them, good for nothing.

review_title: 10+ Year Employee Burned 8 years post EDS take over
pros: Was able to keep my job, took pay cut fist year which was refunded at the end of the year because my contract was the most profitable for the company.
cons:
Major culture shock from EDS to HP, then Gradual culture change decline on employee care over the 8 years and more focus on milking employees to passively force employees to move on. Also change in practice from coaching employees on corrective paths or making the tough call to let them go, and more passing poor performances from manager to manager.
Advice to Management
Evaluate annual Mission statements and then review whats happening on the ground level. there are some low-midlevel managers who are mucking up the gears and our customers are seeing this and we are loosing good people who would gladly take pay cuts if it is about the figures, I;m not one of them. but I know we have talent still with the company and talent that has been lost to competitors due to lay WFR and it is a shame.

pros:
HPE has historically been a great place to work with a pleasant working environment, positive attitude and good benefits.
Co-workers are almost universally friendly and cooperative.
In the software division, there has been some recent good innovation.
cons:
The forthcoming divestiture of the entire HPE software division (called a "reverse spin" by mgmt) to Micro Focus (expected to complete in Aug 2017) clearly shows that HPE is not committed to the business.
There have been extensive reassurances that things will remain mostly unchanged at Micro Focus, but this has not been borne out by the large-scale redundancies in the field sales, development, support and marketing teams globally in Q4 2016/Q1 2017.
Much of the sales activity is being migrated to new online/inside teams offshore in Dallas and Barcelona. Micro Focus clearly did not want to absorb such a large, complex organisation and the move to online is part of the transition.
It isn't clear what the future will hold, but the concept of selling large value enterprise software solutions mostly via remote/inside teams is flawed, and there is no clear commitment to a strategic platform to deliver value to customers.
Advice to Management
Customers need a clear enterprise strategy for software. Simply retaining software product lines for support revenue, and having several competitive solutions (the Mercury versus Compuware/Borland tools for example) will lead to confusion. There needs to be a full commitment by management to staff without the constant fear of ongoing redundancies.

Get serious with deliveries, not just sales chasing sales figures then collect their bonuses and let delivery teams sort out the trouble projects
Stick to proper governance, have the courage and maturity to knock back deals if the fundamentals don't look right.

pros: Great people in my team and great line managers. Employer pension contributions up to 8% of your salary.
cons:
The C-suite does not know what they're doing. Redundancies are called "workforce management program" - which tells you what they think of the employees. Generally bad, outdated HR practices (performance reviews forcing people on the bell curve and the like). Don't know which is more prevalent: internal bureaucracy or internal marketing telling you how great the company is (yeah, sure...), direct managers have no power to manage - the big, faceless corpo keeps their hands tied. No career progression, no pay rises, yearly bonus (if you're lucky to get one) is only enough for 1 night out, lack of support.
Advice to Management
Make your minds of what kind of company you are: old fashioned "Brazil" style (I'm talking about the film here, not the country) bureaucracy or something best fitting in the XXI century.

Morale since the split from HP has suffered due to relentless divestitures and workforce reductions. No sense of stability. Far too much red tape. Freezes on hiring, promotions, and raises. Upper management is giving lower level employees literally no reasons to stay.
Advice to Management
Stop looking for short term stock boosts, respect employees and reward them for their efforts. Company is severely damaged at this point due to low morale and attrition. Invest in your people. They showed loyalty through the Split but far too much has been asked of them since then and the cracks are showing and widening daily.

review_title: How about some honesty in these reviews ?
cons:
ltant in Houston, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Pays a professional salary albeit not a competitive one. Better than working at some fly-by-night I.T. shops.
Cons
Constant layoffs, constant churn. Divisions continue to be sold off. The downturn started with Carly Fiorina, then Mark Hurd, then Leo Apotheker. I give HPE another 3 years before it is broken up or absorbed by one the big players. I keep seeing current references to being able to telecommute. This isn't happening at any of the offices I know of as I keep in touch with former coworkers across North America.
Advice to Management
Workers can't give advice to management. The results of the VOW (voice of the workforce) employee survey are ignored. For five years our team endured an incompetent manager and despite our VOW input he remained a manager.

review_title: People are professional and good at what they do, the company treats them as commodities.
pros: Varied opportunities expand career experience. Global reach. Internal training easily available. Easily mobile across organizations. Professional environment at the office.
cons:
It's like musical chairs. Even the best employees get lay off notice. Also, lack of modern day philosophy regarding allowance for virtual or remote work. After previously allowing this, the company made everyone come into the office regardless of how far they were, even if over a hundred miles from the nearest office. If employees couldn't, they were told to quit without lay-off benefits.
Advice to Management
Go back to how the original EDS leadership treated employees. As a result, people worked so hard and were very loyal to the company.

pros: HPE does many things well. And you can learn a lot from working for a large organization. And there are resources to assist in learning.
cons:
1. Lay-offs are continuous and without cause, yet wide enough and just under the legal limit to not have to state them, per SEC and labor regulations.
2. The work-life balance is to balance your life to work more.
3. First line management is remote, and therefore little visibility into the real work, outside of status reports and the occasional phone discussion.
4. Mid management and upper management are hired, mostly, from outside of the company. These are managers, not leaders, that bring in their own ideas, that may or may not fit HPe, it just being a random-shot.
5. Pay is stagnant. Bonus's are a joke. They would be better to just have an additional three day weekend instead of the insult of the bonus or lack of bonus or no-pay raise after working your butt off and making solid contributions to the company's bottom line.
6. The company needs to start to grow again organically, instead of managing the financial statements to appear to have the company grow.

pros: When remote work was encouraged, it was a great work/life balance.
cons:
- constant fear of layoffs
- raises are rare
- management changes rapidly so priorities are scattered
- they want the experienced/older folks out to pay kids right out of college low wages
Advice to Management
Company culture switches with each CEO. Current CEO wants all employees in an office, although the majority are contract workers to whom that rule does not apply. It is a way to say "all employees are co-located" athough the majority of workers are contractors. It's a silly rule since sitting in an office with people that are not on your projects really doesn't help the culture. Through all the lay offs there is never any compassion from upper management acknowledging that it must be hard to continue working with many of your coworkers gone but only get "keep focused." There must be some management guidelines that say to never empathize on this matter. It is crystal clear that the stakeholder is priority and employees are expendable.

Instead of laying off all of the people who do the work, start laying off the overhead of upper management. The company is way too top heavy in executives. Be loyal to your employees who have done the work for you and are your face to the client.

pros: It was possible to keep workload to a minimum while working on outside courses, working on CV and looking for other positions outside the company. I had a lazy boss so when it came to travel, his secretary approved the expenses and as we got along, my expenses were always approved. However, my boss abused them so he really couldn't say much. But it did enable me to travel and have a very good standard of living.
cons:
If you pay as little as possible, people will do as little as possible. This was very common in the UK. A lot of resentment toward the management. Bullying is not leadership. A lot of work is contracted to India, but this never works well. We had many contracts that we won solely on price based on low cost contracting out, and these savings were never made. We relied on changes, restricting quality control, training, documentation etc. to make up any shortfall. Don't understand why any respectable company would do business with EDS HP.
Advice to Management
It is the culture to charge as much as possible for as little as possible, to exclude any financial guarantees in contracts, to always promise employees they will be looked after Tomorrow, when tomorrow never comes etc. Just a Shyster company and no advice would be taken.

review_title: HP Enterprise Security Services - noble idea, horrible execution
pros: Massive company, easy to glide by if one was inclined to do so.
cons:
Innumerable layers of management makes it impossible to get things done. I was a Sr. Director within HP ESS and still had 7 layers of upper management above me. For the most part, most people at HP are just a number to the leadership, i.e. employee # 214,755 out of 350k+ employees. A strong tendency from upper management to prefer sugar coating and avoidance of problems vs candid truth and fixing obvious (and fixable) problems head on. If you are not a sugar coater and can't tolerate idiotic process then definitely stay far away from HP ESS.
Advice to Management
Flatten the hierarchy, stop just giving lip service to the large scale problems and actually do something to fix them. Remember that HP was once a very highly respected company with an excellent reputation and that you should be embarrassed to have let that reputation die. Get back to core competencies.

review_title: Once proud company with no cars in the garage anymore
pros: None today. Exciting days long time gone. If you like a place where customers have no idea what the company does, with no idea of what they are or where they're going or what they are proud of -- then this for you - enjoy
cons:
Lost its way - no people care - HP Way is gone - no strategy other than satisfying executive bonuses and investor returns - purely an M&A organisation run by external investment advisors - employees face redundancy every quarter for last 10 years leading to stressed out people with low morale. Many with no increased wage for over 8 years. Advanced training has been almost zero for years. Not a place to start your career, promotion easier if you join from an external company, internal promotion very limited.
Advice to Management
You need a massive step change - new remit, structure and values. Rapidly becoming a commodity company in a flooded market, with decreasing contracts and out of touch dinosaurs looking forward to their cut of the M&A booty at the expense of hard working employees - take a look at yourselves, you're out of touch with reality - there is a massive communication gap between good managers and those tasked with corporate management.

review_title: Once fabulous but is quickly fading
pros:
Knowledge of the ins and outs of the IT industry working for a highly recognized brand 

Work with world class companies and partners

Good health benefits in terms of low deductibles and an FSA

Some really great upper management here and there 

Work with people that have years upon years of industry experience
cons:
Low morale due to seemingly endless layoffs, bad training, bad leadership - either have only worked for HP(E) so they lack in insight on how to manage and due to poor training and endless shifts in direction have no clue how to properly manage OR they have been so beaten down by working here they just don't care anymore. 

A company who's trainers preach "be open to change" and answer a question with a tag line "well the HPE answer is 'it depends' " is a HUGE red flag. 

No one knows the direction of the company due to its never ending changes. You can feel them and see them yet no one can tell you why and executive management preaches the strategy has not changed. 

Upper level management will tell you a direction to go in and what they want and you will get an email or be called into a meeting later with your direct manager and they will proceed to tell you something different. How confusing. 

Increased benefit cost because company is paying less. 

Reduced 401k match. 

Very hard to get promoted so don't expect a change in salary or to make a long term prosperous career here anymore.

Cuts in workforce have slowed down our already slow quoting and procurement time.
Advice to Management
Talking about how great things are for stockholders is one thing but you're forgetting why you can even make that statement in the first place - you have a company that's able to do things that is great for your stockholders because of all of the people that work for you. Your people are scared and morale is low. Your people are afraid to move positions because no one knows if that department is safe from the next round of spinoffs or WFRs. Your people are confused as higher ups continue to leave the company and we are wondering what do they know that we don't. Your people make HPE tick. Don't forget about us.

review_title: Salary discrepancy in the same team
pros: Great colleagues, friendly atmosphere, good work environment
cons:
You cant help but feel conned when certain members of the same team, doing the exact same work are earning more than double your basic salary, obviously then any over time will then reflect that person rate of pay which is double yours. You don't feel valued at all and the work just keeps on getting more and more. There are no end of year functions, for that matter no socializing or team building at all!! This all causes frustration and resentment with the people that get payed so much more than some other members, in turn it takes a tole on the morale of the team and productivity suffers.
Advice to Management
Take care of your employees!!!!! They are the company, not you!!! They do the actual work, NOT YOU! Treat them fairly and they will perform, threat them badly and YOU will suffer the consequences.

pros: Highly skilled engineering talent that work hard. Decent benefits.
cons:
Get on the wrong project and your prospects for career advancement are gone for the foreseeable future.
Some managers try very hard to establish a sense of community, but it's difficult when 90% of your interface with colleagues is email or phone.
Not allowed to telework--which makes no sense when the vast majority of your team members are scattered all over the world. Bad call, Meg.
Some good people, but turf battles are frequent and nasty and it's easy to get caught in the middle.
Trying to cut travel costs. Hard to establish relationships with customers when you're not allowed to visit them.
The very worst part of HPE are the financial accounting and reporting tools utilized from opportunity through project execution--the most complex, unmanageable mess I've seen.
Advice to Management
Got to start at the top--Meg, many of these VP's don't trust each other, don't like each other and hide things from each other. Get down in the dirt with lower level employees and look at the tools they are expected to use and the experiences they are having. Allow more local talent to be hired and quit relying on offshoring.

review_title: Was a great company, now avoid like the plauge.
pros:
Hewlett-Packard was THE technology company 20 years ago. Today, it's a corporate dinosaur, shedding employees faster than you can imagine. Nearly all technical positions have been offshored, middle management positions have been gutted to the bone marrow and the threat of Workforce Reductions in the United States is in the back of the mind of each and every employee unless you're in the upper tier of management. 

HP isn't alone in this, most large IT firms in the United States have most of their staff in India or other low-cost areas. If you're good, do yourself a favor and find an internet-focused startup where you'll have a future and more importantly, steady employment. You won't find it at HPE.
cons:
Everything I wrote above, as I can't find anything positive unless you're looking for an office or sales position where your smile and appearance or voice are your assets, rather than IT technical knowledge. HP needs to sell stuff, and go to customer's offices and smooze with IT managers. It can't do that from Banglaore, Manila or Costa Rica.
Advice to Management
Make sure you have golden parachutes. Meg will chop you fast if you don't produce.

pros:
Flexibility
Good work / life balance
Cooperative environment
cons:
Raises seem like lower than average for the industry.
Layoffs due to shrinking server market make the morale low
Benefits cut - 4% 1-1 matching 401k became 6% 1-2 matching (for 3% match total).
Advice to Management
Don't go on crazy hiring sprees and then start cutting employees shortly after
Faster release cadence - we follow and are at the mercy of Intel chip life cycles. 
Investment in employees - We need to start encouraging employees to innovate and revolutionize new technologies, not be another lean machine in a dying industry. Stop doing the same thing and expecting things to get better.
Trust in employees - Stop making top down decisions from high above and making us feel like we're out of the loop. What is our real strategy?

pros: It was a clean, safe, and stable environment, with, over all, enjoyable co-workers. Situations were always handled in a professional manor, with an open door policy, to discuss whatever may be troubling us.
cons:
Underpaid, with no raises for over 4 years, at which point insurance was boosted to ridiculous costs, for individuals, let alone those with dependents... it would've been cheaper to quit, and go on public aid, which is what I think is what management was hoping for. Bringing in temps, at a base rate, with no insurance coverage, and save every penny you can, until you realize that you're getting rid of the people who know how to run the show... then what will you do, when you have temp hire turnover?
Advice to Management
Re-evaluate who you terminate... If too many long term employees are cut, then nobody will know what to do, when it comes time to train the next batch of employees. With each batch, less knowledge will get passed on, regardless of how many notes are left behind, from the person before them.

cons:
ltant
17 Jan 2017 - Anonymous Employee 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Worked with some of the brightest in the industry. Learned hardware, operating system, and application side. Full time remote work at the time was allowed. Unfortunately, that is no longer an option.
Cons
Terrible pay and benefits. Most of my peers did not receive any raises year over year. Asked to work extended hours and on call. Annual workforce reductions in the excess of 10k+ employees per year. Hiring strategy is to interview and offer jobs to college students two months before other companies start interviewing, make an offer early, and only give a few days before the offer expires.
Advice to Management
Stop getting rid of older engineers and talent and replacing with college hires. It makes the good older engineers either paranoid about their job or they leave on their own. The younger crowd views the job as a job and plans to leave after a year or two.

pros:
For a corporate environment, it really wasn't that bad:
-the technologies that they were using were closer to current than to archaic and there was room for suggestions to use newer technologies
-the co-workers were great, very professional and well-educated - could really learn a lot from them
-working from home was possible up to 3 days a week - of course that would have to be worked out with your boss
-the environment wasn't overly stressful - even when the projects got heated people were still able to keep their cool and enjoy a healthy work-life balance - nobody was forced against their will to work overtime (instead people that wanted the overtime pay volunteered to do the overtime duties when necessary)
cons:
-corporate environment (naturally) - boring mandatory training sessions, etc
-projects could have been managed in a better manner - this was likely a side-effect of the IT consulting market however
-didn't feel that bosses were always completely honest with their staff and the dishonesty became contagious

pros: There are always opportunities during changes, but only for those who are willing to stay.
cons:
Nothing committed for those who stay, nonexistent retention program
Advice to Management
Motivation without the right compensation is not the best strategy to improve results and people commitment at the same time. When a contract renewal implies to improve productivity by automation and reducing the workforce, you must be ready to properly motivate and compensate those who you want to stay and those who you want to relocate/reuse, but you must know first who do you want to stay with. Last years was a success in reducing cost and improving margins but was a definitive nightmare for the people who never knows where they are going or for having seen people leaving while increasing their workloads to deliver the same service with less people.

review_title: Very old fashion IT services company
pros: Large corporation with a lot of opportunities to learn, different career paths, good general non-monetary benefits, good average salary (as long as you don't have to rely on promotion off-cycles)
cons:
Very old fashion strategy, practically very poor one with a lot of make up rather actual change, poor greeedy senior executives all being one clique from the ex-EDS time that in the past collapsed EDS now they collapse ES. This reflects to multi-years promises for change with zero improvement, holding of on salary changes for years even in their strategic growth locations, example 2013 was with zero budget for any salaries, 2014-2015 were with 0.5% average which lead some employees to get 1-2% increment after 1-2 years waiting promotion increase (equal to $100 annual gross increment). Lot's of lies and corporate 'hot air' just to make money from stock price for a few top executives and the board of directors. The employee mass is super disappointed and the average annual attrition for the last years since 2013 is 15% across all growth locations.
Advice to Management
Useless CEO Meg Whitman unable to cope with such large corporation and specific business, politically surrounded by his connection with the US Republicans and focused only on the promises makeup keeping stocks up until all get spin off. Keeping around her C-Level focused on their retirement plans (names cannot quote because Glassdoor rules don't allow but literally all) afraid of really shaking the corporation. - Change all or sell all... this is the future of this corporation after 75 years growth and development of their founders. I feel sorry for them, good that they are dead.

review_title: Sad to See this Historically Great Company Torn Down
pros:
Hewlett-Packard was a great place to work for before Carly began the destruction.
They believed in promotion from within and the value of their employees. Bonuses were a shared percentage and encouraged teamwork. You differentiated yourself by delivering value which could lead to increased salary (and indirectly bonuses).
A diverse company provided opportunities to move and learn new technologies and skills.
cons:
The management team is tearing apart this previously great company. They are intentially and systematically getting rid of long-term employees and replacing with younger / cheaper and low-cost off-shore resources.
Mid to high-level management is more and more hired from outside the company because they are not grooming their current employees.
Advice to Management
Find some of the golden nuggets from Bill and Dave's The HP Way and mold them into the new company. The first of which would be to groom your current employees and show an appropriate level of devotion to your long-term employees.

ltant in Alpharetta, GA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Most of the "Technical" people within the company (at least at my Alpharetta Location) are eager to learn and discuss technology so making friends and discussing actual technical items is a positive aspect of this job.
Cons
wow, many cons...
1. Training is awful then they throw you into the fire and only desire warm bodies to answer phones. 
2. There is no growth plan for many of the positions and while they point to WBTs/CBTs (web/computer based trainings) senior people who actually know the product are very reluctant to part with information due to the WFRs (work force reductions) as they expect you will take their job.
3. Salary is now (2016 figures) about 22-35% lower than many regional jobs and probably lower still for national figures. 
4. Constant layoffs - daily in fear of losing your job. Only hear feedback when you screw up which happens a lot since the lack of training, etc. In the old days this would be referred to as "20 goto 10". My understanding is they are still offshoring until 2018 at least even though they brag about U.S. based jobs and are constantly hiring, but there is no "backfill" as this is actual attrition and turnover.
Advice to Management
I have tried to suggest things, but immediately shutdown so don't think they'll listen here.

review_title: HPE Fortify on Demand - Web App Security Tester
pros:
The real definition of work-life balance.
Flexibility to do work from home during holidays or weekends.
Lot of opportunities to showcase talent and be given the essential growth needed.
Good opportunity for fresh graduates or career shifters to start and become adepth with IT Security. 
Standard procedures and IT process have already been established and higly documented.
Employee can easily move up for a management role if given a chance without much process needed.
Nice compensation package for those beginning in their IT career.
cons:
Lacking essential trainings and seminars to those who need them the most. Certifications are also lacking.
Roles are too narrowed down. There's a high chance for the person not to be exposed in the true scope of IT security. Not good for those who want to accelerate their potentials. 
Constant change and reorganizations have impacted the overall progress of the organization.
Management is a hit and miss. At one point, you could be at one of the best employers in the world and the next thing you know, the organization is falling apart. 
Too much politics going around (lately) which could lead to the dismantling and downfall of the team.
Bonus and increase is too low for the success and efforts made by the organization.
Broken promises for plans with the individual employee and the organization.
Advice to Management
Take care of the employees who are really putting an effort. Do lot let people who built the team from the ground up leave just because a manager think they underperform when in fact they have established and built a strong team. Listen and learn from your employees.

pros:
Large company stability
People leaving creates opportunities to grow
Education opportunities for career growth
Great on-site gym at Moffett Towers
Nice peers lower in the food chain
cons:
HPE's software conglomerate model didn't work. The strategy to acquire diverse and independent software assets created a big structure with little in common. The more layers of management that got added, the more insulated the decision makers became from the businesses that drive the revenue and their customers. Add a consolidated, bureaucratic, antiquated sales and fulfillment infrastructure, too many SKUs in the sales quiver and no sales specialization, and you've got declining revenues and declining market relevance across the board, leading to decreased investment in R&D and overall attrition and decline. Appearances of the spin-merge with Micro Focus so far make it appear that the strategy going forward will be largely unchanged.
Advice to Management
Re-diversify the software assets and re-specialize them in their respective markets. Hire leaders who understand the industry the individual software businesses cater to so they can set business goals that are relevant in their given industry. Hire better, more inspiring leaders who can move the needle and generate real growth instead of filling out payroll rosters in low-cost regions just to save money from an ever-declining revenue pool.

pros:
I was on a fantastic team. My coworkers were wonderful and my manager was the best I've ever had. We built a great product that was the first in its category and was successful in the marketplace.
Overall, the company has a culture of innovation that is unlike anything I've seen anywhere.
cons:
There is no vacation carryover to the next year. Though everyone gets at least 3 weeks vacation time, 4-6 days must be used for an annual shutdown (Christmas to New Year in USA, other major holidays in other nations).
The pace was exhausting. It seemed like we were always in crunch mode. Our managers were good about reducing scope after workforce reductions cut our team in half.
Advice to Management
Follow through on promises. Stating that a particular site is a center of excellence for networking and then dismissing the entire networking R&D team from that site a month later doesn't promote trust.
